Flat_1024_summary: – Eleven Secret Service agents have been placed on leave amid allegations that they brought prostitutes back to their Cartagena hotel rooms before President Obama's arrival in the city for the Summit of the Americas. King says the matter was reported to the US Embassy, which in turn notified the Secret Service. Prostitution is legal in Colombia, as long as it's conducted in a "tolerance zone." Flat_1024_summary: – A volunteer for Ben Carson's presidential campaign was killed Tuesday in a car crash in Iowa, Politico reports. The other three people in the Carson van were treated and released from the hospital.

Flat_1024_summary: – Google's new holding company, Alphabet, officially became effective Tuesday, and one of the first things it did was snap up the domain abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz.com, CNBC reports. "We realized we missed a few letters in abc.xyz, so we're just being thorough," a Google rep tells media.com. Flat_1024_summary: – A New York woman is suing her 8-year-old nephew for $127,000, alleging that the boy's exuberance at his 2011 birthday party caused her to fall and break her wrist, the Stamford Advocate reports. "All of a sudden he was there in the air, I had to catch him and we tumbled onto the ground," Connell testified in court Friday. "I remember him shouting, 'AuntieJen I love you,' and there he was flying at me." Flat_1024_summary: – Online dating companies are rushing to beef up background checks on would-be users after the arrest of a man accused of kidnapping and raping a 4-year-old girl, the New York Times reports. One company, MyMatchChecker, offers a basic search for $9.95, and a number of mobile phone apps offer background checks as well. "What we want to do is provide some degree of safety," says a retired New York State Police captain and former police chief who founded the company. "You're talking pennies per check." But the chief of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children says background checks don't go far enough, and he wants the government to create a national database for sex offenders. "It's not a matter of if, but when," he says. "We're not there yet."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Online dating is a billion-dollar industry, and with some 20 million Americans using it, it's time for some sort of safety check, the New York Times reports. Still, New York and New Jersey have begun regulating dating sites, and legal experts believe changes to the liability laws that protect such sites are on the horizon.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Supreme Court wrestled with the question of whether Aereo's streaming service violated broadcasters' rights during arguments yesterday, and the early consensus is that it's going to be a close one. Here's what people are saying: "If you're comfortable with the Supreme Court resolving disputes over technology, the transcript of Tuesday's oral arguments in ABC vs. Aero should change your mind," writes Lyle Denniston at SCOTUSblog. The court "struggled to get past a simplistic view of the technology involved," he writes. "That's physically impossible, not just because antennas aren't sensitive enough to detect signals from outside the local market but because the world isn't, you know, flat. And that sounds so much like what a TV system does or what a satellite system does, that it looks as if somehow you are escaping a constraint that's imposed upon them." "Everyone outside the court should be disturbed by a question like that," writes Eugene Robinson at the Washington Post. "At stake here is the degree to which innovative companies are going to have to seek permission from copyright owners to enable people to do in the cloud what they can do for themselves at home." "Most of the energy, at least from the bench, was about the risk that the Court might rule in this case in a way that would smother the infant of digital innovation in its electronic crib," writes Denniston. "She confessed her concern, saying 'this is really hard for me.'"

Flat_1024_summary: – President Trump is said to be "happy" with his legal team—but not so happy that he's considering a third special counsel to investigate Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. Sources tell the Washington Post that Trump's legal team, including attorney John Dowd and White House lawyer Ty Cobb, have concluded that the Justice Department and FBI are the ones to blame for the investigation into Russian interference with the 2016 election and possible obstruction of justice by the president. The sources say Trump is not happy with his current legal team because they are not doing a good job representing him. "One thing I like is Cobb and Dowd are of the same generation as the president." Flat_1024_summary: – President Trump's former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, says he will plead not guilty to tax evasion, bank fraud, and campaign finance violations before a federal judge in New York on Tuesday, the AP reports. Cohen says in a letter to US District Court Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein that he will also plead guilty to money laundering, conspiracy to launder money, and other charges. Cohen's letter says Trump directed Cohen to arrange payments to buy votes for Trump in the 2016 election in exchange for information on Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. Cohen also said Trump directed him to make payments to the Clinton Foundation in order to help pay for her trips to Central America, the Middle East, and Africa, among other things. Cohen said in the letter that Trump told him the payments were for his "personal use" and that he did not know about the payments before he made them. Trump said in a statement Monday that he has "a great deal of respect" for Cohen, but that he "will not be entering into a guilty plea to any of these or any of the charges." He added: "I hope to God it won't happen. I hope not to."

His company has produced X-rated video fare like Asian Fever 12, Barely Legal 151, and The Porn Identity, and he says his company also created a parody porn specifically targeting Trump, where he searches for a running mate. reference: – President Obama didn't mince words today when asked at his end-of-the-year news conference about Sony Pictures: "Yes, I think they made a mistake," he said of the company's decision to pull the movie The Interview, reports NBC News. "We cannot have a society in which some dictator someplace can start imposing censorship in the United States," he said. Obama added that he was "sympathetic" to Sony's concerns as a corporation, but he said the precedent set over a "satirical movie" is a terrible one. "I wish they would have spoken to me first." Of the hackers: "They caused a lot of damage, and we will respond." Of the movie's star, Seth Rogen: "I love Seth." Other topics: Black America: It is better off "in the aggregate" than when he came into office, said Obama, but work remains. He spoke of a "growing awareness" that law enforcement isn't always "applied in a colorblind fashion." Cuba: "Change is going to come to Cuba. It has to." Fidel: Obama said that when he was on the phone to President Raul Castro about renewing relations, he apologized for talking at length. Castro replied that his famous brother once spoke for seven hours' straight and that Obama was a young man who still had a chance to beat that record. 'Resurgence': Obama opened the news conference by ticking off improvements in the economy, job creation, and health care, and asserted that "America's resurgence is real. We are better off." Congress: Obama said he "sincerely" wants to work with the new Congress, citing areas such as simplifying the tax code, boosting US exports, and rebuilding infrastructure, reports CNN. Keystone: Construction of the pipeline from Canada would create some jobs, but the pipeline in general would not make "even a nominal" difference for US consumers.
TreeSum_summary: – President Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital "is a victory for the people of Israel," Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Friday. "The president of the United States has made a great and courageous decision." Netanyahu, speaking at a Cabinet meeting, said the move was in line with the country's "long history of struggle against oppression and for the right of the people to live their lives as they see fit," the AP reports. Trump announced the move Thursday, saying Israel had "proved its power" after years of "unprovoked attacks" on the city. The White House said Friday that Trump had signed a bill into law making the city the capital of Israel, the first time such a change has been made under a president who has called the city a "shithole." Trump said Thursday that he had decided to make Jerusalem the capital because the city "has been failing for a long time" and he wanted to make it "a great place to live and work." The move angered Palestinians, who called it a "gross violation" of international law.

Flat_1024_summary: – President Trump pardoned Dinesh D'Souza on Thursday, and the conservative pundit wasted little time in mocking the man who put him in jail. "KARMA IS A BITCHT: @PreetBharara wanted to destroy a fellow Indian American to advance his career," he tweeted. "Then he got fired & I got pardoned." He later added, "I love it when my tweets score a direct hit, measured by the intensity of shrieking on the left." As Mediaite notes, Trump fired Bharara last year after he refused to resign from his post as US attorney for the Southern District of New York. D' Souza was sentenced to five years in prison in 2010 for violating the Dodd-Frank Act, which bans corporate campaign contributions to federal candidates. He was convicted for using his website to solicit donations fromstrawberry.com, a company owned by Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner. The conviction was eventually overturned by a federal appeals court, which ruled that the use of the website violated the campaign finance law but didn't. The 59-year-old was also arrested Tuesday for allegedly making racist and anti-Semitic remarks, the New York Daily News reports. Police say he was wearing a baseball cap and holding a sign that said, "Make America Great Again." They say he made comments about African Americans that were "highly offensive," "racist," and "insensitive," among other things.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Dinesh D'Souza may have been pardoned by President Trump, but that doesn't mean he's off the hook on a felony campaign finance conviction. The conservative author and pundit was sentenced to five years in prison in 2010 for violating the Dodd-Frank Act, which bans corporate campaign contributions to federal candidates, reports the Washington Post. He was convicted for using his website to solicit donations fromstrawberry.com, a company owned by Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner. The conviction was eventually overturned by a federal appeals court, which ruled that the use of the website violated the campaign finance law but didn't. In an interview with the Weekly Standard, D' Souza said Obama's economic policies are "demonstrably bad for working-class white people," and that black people should be allowed to "go color-blind and let the African-Americans rebuild their culture on their own," reports the Post. The comments were denounced by conservatives including Rush Limbaugh, who called them "deplorable" and "cruel," and by Obama himself, who said he was "appalled." In a letter to the board of trustees at King's College in Virginia—where he was president until he was released from community confinement in May after pleading guilty to making illegal campaign contributions in 2012—D' souza said he had to step down because of "differences with the board." He also wrote a new book, Downfall, which explains why he thinks Trump is the best candidate to beat Hillary Clinton.

Flat_1024_summary: – For the first time in three years, Chipotle has been named "Brand of the Year" by Harris Poll for fast-casual Mexican restaurants. Moe's Southwest Grill, a Tex-Mex chain with more than 650 locations, took the top spot in the annual survey based on more than 97,000 responses from US consumers. Taco Bell finished second, Qdoba Mexican Grill third, and Baja Fresh Mexican Grill fourth, reports USA Today. Chipotle, which had been atop the list for three years running, didn't even make the top four this year. "We really view the competition as share of stomach," says Moe’s president Bruce Schroder. The chain, which got its start in Atlanta in 2000, is part of Focus Brands, which also owns Auntie Anne's, Cinnabon, and Carvel.

Don't take off your shoes: It might be tempting to wiggle those toes under the seat, but this isn't your house, and that "water" you're stepping on in the bathroom isn't actually water. Don't let those hands wander: If you're tempted to tug at your flight attendant's clothes to get his or her attention as they walk by, just don't. Ever. reference: – Predicting earthquakes is shaky business at best, but that detail isn't stopping Italian officials from prosecuting a group of prominent scientists over their failure to do exactly that. Six scientists and one government official face charges of manslaughter for allegedly failing to provide adequate warning of imminent disaster to locals after the region was struck by more than 400 low-magnitude tremors in the months preceding a major quake. The group of experts met in 2009 to analyze the risk posed by the seismic activity, but didn't find cause to raise alarm. Six days later, a major quake devastated the central Italian city of L'Aquila and killed 309 people, reports the AFP. Among the defendants are some of Italy's top scientists in the field. "You cannot put science on trial," says a defense lawyer, citing his client's statement during the expert panel meeting that "one cannot rule out a major quake." The group has gained the wide support of the scientific community. But "no one expected to be told the exact time of the quake," says a doctor who lost his wife and daughter in the quake. "We just wanted to be warned that we were sitting on a bomb." The trial opened today, and the BBC notes that seven defendants face up to 15 years in jail.
TreeSum_summary: – Six Italian scientists and a former government official are on trial for manslaughter over the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake, which killed 309 people. Prosecutors accuse the seven of "negligence and imprudence ... of having provided an approximate, generic, and ineffective assessment of seismic activity risks as well as incomplete, imprecise, and contradictory information," the BBC reports. The defendants say there is no way to predict major earthquakes even in a seismically active area. "No one expected to be told the exact time of the quake. We just wanted to be warned that we were sitting on a bomb," a doctor who lost his wife and daughter in the disaster tells the Independent. "This is a trial which opens on very shaky foundations. You cannot put science on trial." More than 5,000 scientists signed an open letter in support of the defendants last year.

If the Democratic county councils in the district can't come to an agreement, the governor will appoint a Democrat to replace Freeman for the rest of his two-year term, the Times notes. reference: – Election results are still trickling in in Washington state (it's a vote-by-mail-only state, KOMO News reports), but it looks like voters are giving Democratic Rep. Roger Freeman of Federal Way a second term with about 53% of the vote, NBC News notes. There's just one problem: The 48-year-old Freeman died last week after a long battle with colon cancer, the Seattle Times reports. Many voters either didn't know Freeman had died or had already sent in their ballots, the Washington Post reports. "I did not know that. When did he pass away?" one voter told KVAL. "This is extremely rare," a spokesman for Washington's secretary of state tells NBC. "But there are protocols in place." Those protocols would be much simpler if voters had simply elected the very much alive Republican candidate, Jack Dovey. However, since Freeman is apparently the victor, Democrats in the district will pick three names to serve as his temporary replacement; the county councils will then vote one of those candidates in to serve for one year, with a special election next year to pick someone for the final year of the two-year term, NBC notes. Dovey, now known as the challenger beat by a deceased candidate, simply tells KVAL, "It's a tragic thing that happened." (This county candidate dropped out of the race after his dead friend supposedly voted for him.)
TreeSum_summary: – A Democratic state representative in Washington state died last week, but that didn't stop his supporters from voting for him in yesterday's election. Roger Freeman, a 48-year-old first-term representative from Federal Way, had about 53% of the vote to GOP challenger Jack Dovey's 47% when he died, the Seattle Times reports. "This is extremely rare," says a spokesman for the state's secretary of state. "But there are protocols in place." Democrats will select three candidates to fill Freeman's seat for a year, during which time the seat will be on the ballot to fill out the remainder of his two-year term, Reuters reports. If Dovey wins, he will take the seat in Olympia at the start of the next legislative session. "I think that's something that he would personally want," says his legislative director. Freeman was battling colon cancer that spread to his liver and lungs. When he died at the end of October, 15% of voters in his district had already mailed in their ballots, and he had a six-point lead over his Republican opponent. So why did they vote for him? "I did not know that," one voter tells KVAL-TV. "When did he pass away?" It's not the first time a dead person has been elected to public office. Last year, Oregon voters elected a man to the Aberdeen City Council five months after he died in a plane crash. Missouri elected a dead man who was running unopposed to serve as county commissioner in 2010.

Prosecutors say the 36-year-old was charged as part of an investigation into the posting of nude images of numerous celebrities, including Jennifer Lawrence and model Kate Upton, but he is not suspected of being involved in releasing those images. "By illegally accessing intimate details of his victims' personal lives, Mr. Collins violated their privacy and left many to contend with lasting emotional distress, embarrassment, and feelings of insecurity," David Bowdich, the assistant director in charge of the FBI's Los Angeles Field Office, said in a statement, per NBC News. There has not been any evidence that Collins himself posted any of the photos, or that he was directly involved in leaking them, officials said on Tuesday. The charge carries a maximum of five years in prison, but prosecutors will recommend a sentence of 18 months.

Flat_1024_summary: – The makers of Zero Dark Thirty were given "top-level access to the most classified mission in history," but no classified information was revealed to them, according to an investigation by the Pentagon and CIA. The investigation was prompted by allegations that information from the Osama bin Laden raid might have been leaked to the filmmakers, but investigators found no evidence of that, the Washington Post reports. The filmmakers, Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal, never met with the Navy SEAL who carried out the raid. Investigators also found that the White House and Pentagon discussed allowing the filmmakers to interview the SEAL, but that the meeting never took place and that no secret techniques or tactics were revealed to the pair. Rep. Peter King, chair of the House Homeland Security Committee, requested the investigation. "If it’s wrong enough or questionable enough for the IG to refer it to the Justice department, that means it shouldn’t have been done," a senior defense official tells McClatchy.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The makers of Zero Dark Thirty were given "top-level access to the most classified mission in history" when they made the Osama bin Laden movie, the New York Times reports, but an investigation has found no evidence that the filmmakers were given classified information. Rep. Pete King had asked the Pentagon and CIA inspectors general to look into whether the filmmakers had access to SEAL team members or undercover CIA officers, and whether any leaks about the raid had hurt the CIA's intelligence collection. Investigators found that no such consultations took place and that the special operations planner's identity was never revealed to the filmmakers. "This does not appear to be a cover-up or a wag-the-dog media stunt," a US official tells the Washington Post. "Rather, this is about who gets to break the law and leak information for their own benefit." A senior defense official tells ABC News that Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence Michael Vickers was asked by the Pentagon to talk to "the 'Zero Dark Thirty' filmmakers and others in the entertainment industry to provide unclassified information on the bin Laden operation. He wasn't doing this on his own. It's appropriate for department officials to work with the entertainmentindustry to try to inform how stories are told."

Flat_1024_summary: – For 14 years, California-based Spinal Solutions produced the world's best-known brand of spinal implants, one that's used by more than half a million people in the US. But an investigation by the Center for Investigative Reporting finds that the company's products may have been counterfeit, and that the FDA knew about it—and didn't do anything about it. The FBI says it's looking into the allegations, though the agency won't say whether it contacted it. What's more, some of the screws Spinal Solutions is alleged to have produced were actually made by a machinist. More than two dozen plaintiffs have signed on to a massive lawsuit concerning an alleged scheme in which patients received non- FDA approved screws during spine and back surgery. "The fraudulent non-FDA conforming devices were installed in people's bodies at a very low cost to the providers," attorney Brian Kabateck said Friday. "They were then fraudulently billing the insurance companies, the worker's comp carriers, and making thousands and thousands of dollars off of each patient." Officials said 28 new cases were filed at the Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday, making a total of 32 pending cases.

reference: – Pooping in space "isn't glamorous, but it is necessary for survival," an astronaut explains—yet it's presenting quite a challenge for NASA. See, while the International Space Station has a pretty fancy toilet, an astronaut must wear a diaper during launch and landing activities or while spacewalking. But as NASA looks toward future missions in deep space, it's also looking for a way for astronauts to relieve themselves while remaining in their space suits for up to six days, reports Time. That's where you come in. The agency is offering a $30,000 prize in a "space poop challenge" if someone can create "a system inside a space suit that collects human waste for up to 144 hours and routes it away from the body, without the use of hands." There are plenty of stipulations. For example, the system "needs to take no more than five minutes [to set up]" as an astronaut might be forced to jump into their suit quickly in an emergency, per Space.com. While such a challenge might seem humorous, a solution "could be the difference between life and death," notes the contest website. "You don't want any of these solids and fluids stuck to your body for six days," NASA adds in a release. "Given enough time, infection, and even sepsis can set in," says astronaut Rick Mastracchio in a video. Inventors have until Dec. 20 to submit their entries. NASA plans to test the top entries next year, with a solution executed within three years. (A scientist thinks humans could get to Mars in a month.)
TreeSum_summary: – NASA is offering $30,000 to the winner of its Space Poop Challenge to design a spacesuit that can separate waste from body parts and collect it for up to six days, CNET reports. " Effectively managing human waste is critical for the health and safety of astronauts in space," NASA states. "It could be the difference between life and death for astronauts in emergency situations that require extended (like days) periods of time." Right now, astronauts at the International Space Station use a vacuum and tube to help evacuate fecal matter when they pee, Space.com reports. To urinate, they use a funnel attached to a hose that can be adapted for a sitting or standing position, and uses air to move urine away. NASA says future missions "may require long-duration waste management for use by a suited crew member." The winner will have his or her design tested on astronauts on the Orion spacecraft, which is scheduled to lift off from Cape Canaveral in 2018.

Flat_1024_summary: – The FDA is warning people who have St. Jude Medical implantable cardiac pacemakers to take steps to protect themselves from hackers who say they've figured out how to gain access to the devices. The hackers, who call themselves Lizard Squad, say they were able to access the device's wireless network through a vulnerability that allows them to "listen in" to the heartbeats of patients who have the device hooked up to their chests, Ars Technica reports. The problem is that the makers of the pacemakers don't control the programming of the devices, and researchers at Johns Hopkins got their own test devices from an auction website for as little as $500 to as much as $3,000, reports Gizmodo. The team also found that doctors' monitoring systems didn't require log-in names and passwords when pacemakers connect to them, and the data was stored. "It's still true that various security researchers have been warning manufacturers about pacemakers' and other cardiac devices' vulnerabilities for years," the site notes. "Unfortunately, it sounds like very few listened." The FDA says it will "continue to assess new information concerning the cybersecurity of [the] implantable cardiac devices and ... keep the public informed if the FDA's recommendations change." Abbott, which makes the device in the US, is also issuing a firmware update. The update will be available starting Aug. 29, but you'll need to visit a health care provider in person to do it; it can't be done from home via Merlin.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The FDA is warning people who have St. Jude Medical implantable cardiac pacemakers to have their devices inspected by their doctors before getting a new one. The problem is that hackers could be able to alter the device's settings, which could lead to "rapid battery depletion or administration of inappropriate pacing," the agency says in a press release. The warning applies to all models of the device, which are implanted under the skin in the upper chest and "provide pacing for slow or irregular heart rhythms," per the FDA. Abbott, which makes the devices, says it has "developed and validated this firmware update as a corrective action (recall) for all of their RF-enabled pacemaker devices, including cardiac resynchronization pacemakers." The update, which will be available Aug. 29, will be pre-loaded in the device and can't be performed from home via Merlin.net. It "will operate in backup mode (pacing at 67 beats per minute), and essential, life-sustaining features will remain available," the FDA says. The agency says there are no reports of patient harm caused by the vulnerabilities, but it wants doctors to talk to patients about the risks and benefits of having the device inspected by a qualified health care provider before getting it replaced.

Flat_1024_summary: – The US is by far the most obese country in the world, with 13% of its population considered obese, according to a new study. But that's not the only bad news in the study of 188 countries, published in the Lancet medical journal. "It's going up everywhere," study co-author Christopher Murray tells USA Today. The number of overweight or obese people worldwide rose from 857 million in 1980 to 2.1 billion in 2013, with rates rising among men, women, and children in rich countries and in poor countries. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," Murray says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." In developing countries, rates are even higher, with 50% of men in Tonga obese and 13% of women in Kuwait, Kiribati, Micronesia, Libya, Qatar, Samoa, and Tonga, the study says. In developed countries, increases in obesity have slowed, but rates are accelerating in developing countries. The study doesn't examine causes, but suggests increased calorie intake, changes in diet composition, decreased physical activity, and changes in the mix of bacteria in human guts, Reuters reports. More than half of the world's obese live in just 10 countries: the US, China, India, Russia, Brazil, Mexico, Egypt, Germany, Pakistan, and Indonesia.

Prosecutors and the owners of the cats alleged that Farmer sexually assaulted one of the felines, but the judge rejected that argument. "We are disappointed that the judge did not" require him to do so, Gayle Goodson, a supporter of the cat owners, tells the Mercury News. "But we understand her reasoning, though we may not necessarily agree with it." The judge credited Farmer for twice the 646 days he's already served since his arrest. His attorney, Wesley Schroeder, says Farmer's meth addiction was an "accelerant" to his "horrific"—"It's so hard to grasp I did this. I stole a member of their family. The fact that I was out of my mind was no excuse." So wrote the son of a retired San Jose police captain in a letter to the court.

reference: – A grisly and bizarre animal cruelty case has come to a close in San Jose, with a serial cat killer sentenced to 16 years in jail. Police say Robert Farmer killed at least 16 cats after stealing and torturing them in 2015. Prosecutors also alleged that he sexually abused at least one of the cats, but the 26-year-old avoided having to register as a sex offender, reports the San Francisco Chronicle. He had pleaded guilty to 21 counts of animal cruelty prior to sentencing. Pet owners celebrated the maximum sentence, though Farmer's attorney says he could be released in about 4 years. “It’s so hard to grasp I did this,” Farmer wrote in a letter read by his attorney in court, per the Mercury News. "It feels like another man committed these crimes, but I know it was me.” Neighbors in the Cambrian Park community began sharing stories when their cats started disappearing without a trace. Most of the time, the bodies would turn up discarded in dumpsters or elsewhere. Farmer was arrested after being captured on a pet owner's surveillance camera snatching the family's 17-year-old pet from the property.
TreeSum_summary: – A 26-year-old man who murdered as many as 16 cats in a San Jose, Calif., neighborhood was sentenced Friday to a maximum of 16 years in jail, the San Jose Mercury News reports. Robert Farmer pleaded guilty in October to 21 felony counts of animal cruelty. Prosecutors and the owners of the cats alleged that Farmer sexually abused one of the slain felines, but the judge rejected that argument. She did not, however, require Farmer to register as a sex offender. The judge also ordered Farmer to undergo psychological treatment and stay away from Cambrian Park for 10 years. "It's so hard to grasp I did this," Robert Roy Farmer wrote in a letter to the court. "I stole a member of their family. The fact that I was out of my mind was no excuse." The Los Angeles Times reports Farmer was arrested in September 2015 after he tried to lure two cats into a backpack, one escaped, and the other was treated at a vet for a "bite that was not an animal bite, as well as the bleeding head injury." Prosecutors say Farmer killed the cats in or near their homes, left their bodies in trash cans, and stole their food and water. His attorney, Wesley Schroeder, says the cats were killed by a meth addiction that spiraled out of control.

Flat_1024_summary: – All 54 people aboard a passenger plane that crashed Sunday in Indonesia's easternmost province of Papua have died, a national search-and-rescue official tells the AP. The Trigana Air Service plane, which was carrying 44 adult passengers, five children and infants, and five crew members, lost contact with air traffic controllers about half an hour into its short flight from Jayapura to Oksibil, CNN reports. The area in eastern Papua where the plane crashed is steep and difficult to reach on foot, Reuters reports. "Smoke was still billowing from the wreckage when it was spotted by a helicopter," says a rescue official. "The fuselage is covered by a layer of volcanic ash." The airline has been banned from flying to Europe because of safety concerns.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – All 54 people aboard a passenger plane that crashed into a mountainside Sunday in Indonesia have died, officials say. The Trigana Air Service plane was carrying 44 adult passengers, five children and infants, and five crew members from Jayapura to Oksibil in Papua province, CNN reports. There were also four postal workers and five members of the Bintang Highlands district parliament on board, Reuters reports. Dense fog has hindered efforts to reach the crash site on foot or by helicopter. Search and Rescue Agency spokesman Heronimus Guru says terrain in the rugged area may have been a factor in the crash. "There's a possibility the aircraft hit a peak and then fell into a ravine because the place that it was found in is steep," he says. The airline was banned from flying to Europe because of safety concerns, the AP reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – A North Augusta, SC, woman was arrested Monday for allegedly leaving her 9-year-old daughter alone in a park while she went to work. Police say Debra Lynn Harrell, 46, dropped the girl off at the park around 9:30am, then dropped her off at work around 2pm, WFXG reports. When a woman asked where her mother was, the girl told her mother drops her off all the time so she can play while her mother is at work. The girl also said she sometimes walks over to the McDonald's inside Walmart to buy lunch, according to the police report. Harrell confessed to leaving the girl alone at the parks and was arrested and booked into jail on charges of unlawful neglect toward a child. Instead, May would be expected to stay on as prime minister until a new leader is selected by the party, which could take up to six weeks. In Wednesday's vote, about two-thirds of the Conservative MPs in the House of Commons wrote in a letter to May saying they no longer believe she is competent to lead the country after Britain leaves the European Union in March. They cite her mishandling of Brexit, her failure to forge a good relationship with the UK's European Union, and her refusal to set a date for the country's departure from the EU. May said in a statement that a leadership election would "only create more division just as we should be standing together to serve our country." She said she was making progress in her talks with EU leaders and vowed to "deliver on the referendum vote and seize the opportunities that lie ahead."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – British Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote in her leadership of her Conservative Party on Wednesday, the AP reports. According to the BBC, 200 of the party's 533 MPs voted in favor of May, while 117 voted against her. The vote was triggered by 48 Conservative MPs who called for a vote of confidence in May over her Brexit deal with the European Union. May had warned that if she lost the vote, she would be forced to resign before Britain leaves the EU in March. She promised to step down before the next general election in 2022. May said in a statement before the vote that she is "ready to finish the job" and make Brexit happen as scheduled on March 29. "A leadership election would not change the fundamentals of the negotiation or the Parliamentary arithmetic," she said. "Weeks spent tearing ourselves apart will only create more division just as we should."

reference: – When Prime Minister Theresa May entered a room in the House of Commons to speak to Conservative lawmakers ahead of a no-confidence vote Wednesday, she was greeted by table banging—a customary sign of approval, reports the AP. It ended up being a prescient gesture: The BBC reports she needed the votes of 159 MPs to remain the Conservative leader, and she crossed that threshold, winning the confidence vote 200 votes to 117, reports the Guardian. It adds that after the words "does have confidence in..." were announced, it could not hear the rest due to the eruption of cheers. But Reuters reports May won't be in it for the long haul. In her pre-vote comments, she pledged to step down in advance of the 2022 parliamentary election. "She did say she wouldn't be fighting the next general election," one minister was quoted as saying. "It was quite emotional the way she put it, she said in my heart I wanted to do that but now I recognize that I am not going to."
TreeSum_summary: – British Prime Minister Theresa May fended off a challenge to her leadership from within her own Conservative Party on Wednesday, winning a confidence vote by a vote of 52 to 48, the AP reports. May had been widely expected to lose the vote among her own party's backbenchers over her handling of Brexit and the future of the UK's relationship with the European Union, but she emerged from the meeting with what the BBC describes as an "emotional" plea for support. She told them she would not lead the party into the next scheduled election in 2022—but wants to stay on to deliver her Brexit deal. The vote was triggered by hard-line Brexit supporters in the party who opposed herBrexit deal with the EU. Reuters reports May had warned that if she lost the confidence vote, she would have to step down before Britain leaves the EU in March. But after two hours of voting, 200 Conservative lawmakers voted in her favor and 117 against. "A leadership election would not change the fundamentals of the negotiation or the Parliamentary arithmetic," she said in a statement early Wednesday. "Weeks spent tearing ourselves apart will only create more division just as we should be standing together to serve our country. None of that would be in the national interest."

Flat_1024_summary: – It's that time of year again: time for the annual Ig Nobel Awards, which honor research that makes people laugh and then think. This year's winners were announced Thursday in Cambridge, Mass., NPR reports. The awards, organized by the magazine Annals of Improbable Research, are "intended to celebrate the unusual, honor the imaginative—and spur people's interest in science, medicine, and technology," per the ceremony's website. The economics prize went to Mark Avis, Sarah Forbes, and Shelagh Ferguson of New Zealand and the UK, who studied the "set of human characteristics associated with the brand"—think wholesomeness, youth, intelligence, and sophistication—by putting pictures of rocks in front of 225 Kiwi students. One rock, Rock G, was described as "a big New York type businessman, rich, smooth, maybe a little shady" and "carries a black brief case, slick hair, quick thinker, and quicker talker." Another, Rock H, was called "modest," "farm mechanic," and "down-to-earth." The peace award went to a group of philosophers from Canada and the US who published a paper titled On the Reception and Detection of Pseudo-Profound Bullshit.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – A British man who lived as a goat in the Alps for three days and a group of philosophers who studied how people understand gibberish were among this year's Ig Nobel winners, chosen based on "improbable scientific achievement." Volkswagen took the chemistry prize for its research into how it cheated emissions tests, while a team that tested the effects of wearing polyester, cotton, or wool pants on the sex life of rats won the economics prize, NPR reports. The peace prize went to a gang of philosophers from Canada and the US who published a paper titled On the Reception and Detection of Pseudo-Profound Bullshit. The researchers asked 280 students at the University of Waterloo to rate their paper. The biology award went to two Britons. Among the studies: A German team's 2013 study of itches, which involved injecting a chemical under the skin of people's arms and asking them to scratch one arm while looking at themselves in a mirror. Sometimes the participants scratched the itchy arm but it looked like their nonitchy arm was being scratched, and vice. A team from New Zealand and the UK whose study looked at the "set of human characteristics associated with the brand"—for example wholesomeness, youth, intelligence, and sophistication—by putting pictures of rocks in front of 225 Kiwi students. Two Britons won the biology award.

reference: – Investigators believe an ex-con in an Oklahoma City suburb murdered his 8-year-old neighbor and got away with it for 18 years. Kirsten Hatfield disappeared from her bedroom in Midwest City on the night of May 14, 1997, and Anthony Palma, who lived two houses away, was arrested this week on charges of kidnapping and first-degree murder, KOCO reports. The breakthrough in the cold case came after a new investigator took over in June and discovered that key pieces of evidence—including bloodstains on the girl's bedroom window sill and on her underwear, found in her backyard—were never tested for DNA, reports NBC News. Palma, who was released from prison in 1986 after serving time for assault with a dangerous weapon, still lives in the same home, and an arrest warrant states that he probably stayed there "to conceal evidence of the crime and/or the location of [Kirsten's] body," reports NBC. Fox 25 reports that the 56-year-old was interviewed after the 1997 disappearance and provided a DNA sample this year when investigators finally tested the evidence and spoke to 10 suspects in the case. Court documents state that the DNA match to the evidence was 293 sextillion to 1. Police believe Palma targeted the girl for sexual assault and killed her soon after her abduction, reports KOCO. Her body has never been found. (A woman thought to have been murdered in 1984 was found alive and well in Dusseldorf.)
TreeSum_summary: – "It's proverbial needle in a haystack—how fortunate, lucky we were in this case." That's the police chief in Midwest City, Okla., who announced the arrest of a suspect in the 1997 kidnapping and murder of Kirsten Hatfield. Anthony Palma, 56, was arrested Monday and is being held on suspicion of first-degree murder and kidnapping, NBC News reports. Police say a DNA match found at the State Bureau of Investigation's crime lab in July puts Palma's odds of being the girl's killer at 263 sextillion to 1, according to an affidavit. But it was only in June, when the case was reassigned to a new detective, that that detective discovered that several pieces of evidence—including bloodstains on Kirsten's underwear and on her bedroom windowsill—had never been tested because of a lack of technology at the time, the Oklahoman reports. "It is likely that Palma has been motivated to stay in the same home to conceal evidence of the crime and/or the location of Kristen's body," the affidavit states. Palma—who was convicted of assault and battery with a dangerous weapon in the early 1980s and released from prison in 1986, according to state corrections records—lives just two homes down from the Hatfields' home.

But Broward County Circuit Judge Kathleen McHugh said she would tack on an additional three months' probation because Johnson had failed to meet with his probation officer during three previous months. It was all set until Johnson, when asked by McHugh if he was satisfied with his lawyer Adam Swickle, gave the attorney a light swat on the rear—as football players routinely do to each other on the field. The courtroom erupted in laughter and at that McHugh told Johnson she wouldn't accept the deal. "I don't know that you're taking this whole thing seriously," McHugh said, the plea deal document down on her desk. "The whole courtroom was laughing. I'm not going to accept these plea negotiations. This isn't a joke." Johnson tried to apologize, telling the judge, "I have no intent to make this a joke. It's not funny. My life is in a shambles right now and I try my best to laugh and keep a smile on my face."

Twitter was going nuts for the trailer—Katy Perry, for example, simply tweeted, "IM SCREAMINGOSBEJRMF$&2@!K." TreeSum_summary: – "I'm in love," says Lady Gaga in the new trailer for A Star Is Born. "That's the first time I've ever been in a love story where I'm not in love." She continues, "I don't know if you've seen the trailer yet, but I love it. It's so beautiful. I can't wait to see what he's going to do with her." Gaga, who made her feature film debut in the film, co-stars alongside Bradley Cooper, who plays her character's boyfriend, played by Michael Jackson, People reports. "It all came down to this broken love story, and there's no better way to express that than through singing," Cooper told Entertainment Weekly in December. "Your whole body is electrified. That was the initial igniter of the passion for me." The remake of the 1976 movie starring Barbra Streisand and Kris Kristofferson opens Oct. 5.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Guardian calls it "one of the most stunning allegations of Russian intelligence ever to come out of the West," and the BBC says it's "astonishing in their detail and their openness." On Thursday, the US, UK, and the Netherlands accused Russia's military intelligence unit, the GRU, of hacking into international bodies, including the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, which was investigating the nerve agent used to poison a Russian ex-spy in England. The US charged seven men, four of whom were expelled from the Netherlands, with hacking the OPCW; the other three were charged in July with hacking Democratic officials during the 2016 US election, per the AP. The OPCW is the world's watchdog over chemical weapons, and it had been investigating the use of the toxin sarin on Sergei Skripal and his daughter, who were found poisoned in England in March. Per the Guardian, the hackers allegedly used specialist hacking equipment in the car boot of the suspects' hotel room in the Hague, which is next to the organization's office. The laptop seized from the suspects in April was found to have been used in Brazil, Switzerland, and Malaysia.

Under current FDA standards, caffeine in sodas can register no higher than about 71 milligrams per 12-ounce serving. "Today, any child can walk into a Starbucks and buy an unlimited number of 'Grande,'" the lawsuit reads, per the San Francisco Chronicle.

reference: – Conspiracy theorists, take a deep breath: A Texas judge has officially deemed Antonin Scalia's death a natural one, WFAA reports. Presidio County Judge Cinderela Guevara says the Supreme Court justice died of a heart attack. Guevara says she heard about Scalia's death from a sheriff, and was planning to travel to the luxury ranch where Scalia died, when a US Marshal called her. "It's not necessary for you to come, judge. If you’re asking for an autopsy, that’s what we need to clarify," the marshal told her, per Guevara. She goes on: "As part of my investigation, one of the things I did ask the sheriff and the US Marshal: 'Were there any signs of foul play?' And they said, ‘Absolutely not.’ At that time, I still wanted to be careful, and asked them if [Scalia’s] physician would call me." Scalia's doctor did call her Saturday night, saying Scalia had a shoulder injury and several chronic health issues. Guevara decided the death was natural and no autopsy would be needed, ABC News reports. Meanwhile, Scalia's body was transported overnight by van—with a procession of US Marshals Service vehicles and Texas Dept. of Public Safety troopers—to Sunset Funeral Home in El Paso. The funeral home manager says Scalia's remains were embalmed, a legal requirement before moving a body out of the state. The leading conspiracy theory was that President Obama himself had Scalia murdered, a notion the New Republic puts down to "some paranoid people on Twitter."
TreeSum_summary: – Antonin Scalia's personal doctor has confirmed that the Supreme Court justice died of a heart attack, Presidio County Judge Cinderela Guevara tells ABC News. The 79-year-old Presidio County resident had a history of heart trouble, high blood pressure, and a stroke, she says. She says Scalia had also suffered from a shoulder injury over the last few years. Guevara says she asked the sheriff's office and the US Marshal's Office whether there were signs of foul play, but they said "absolutely not," WFAA reports. The judge says she will fill out the official death certificate after the funeral home collects the justice's vital information. "After I did my job, yes ... I kept playing it over and over in my mind and thought, 'Oh my God. History is being made in Presidio County,'" Guevara says. "I just feel that we have lost a great defender of the Constitution, and it's a big loss for the United States of America."

Romney backed a ban on assault weapons—including the AR-15 used in the Aurora rampage—when he was governor of Massachusetts. The weapons are legal in Colorado, where few modifications have been made to gun laws since the Columbine massacre. “I believe the people should have the right to bear arms, but I don’t believe that we have to have assault weapons as part of our personal arsenal,” Romney said on Fox News in 2004. "Our challenge is not the laws, our challenge is people who, obviously, are distracted from reality and do unthinkable, unimaginable, inexplicable things." Romney said "very stringent" gun laws already exist in Massachusetts, including bans on the online sale of ammunition and on the sale of semi-automatic weapons. "The law that we signed in Massachusetts was a combination of efforts both on the part of those that were for additional gun rights and those that opposed gun rights, and they came together and made some changes that provided, I think, a better environment for both, and that's why both sides came to celebrate the signing of the bill."

Flat_1024_summary: – Albert Einstein's theory of special relativity may be kaput. If true, the discovery would upend the theory, which posits that nothing can move faster than light. “I suspect that the bulk of the scientific community will not take this as a definitive result unless it can be reproduced by at least one and preferably several experiments,” one physicist tells ScienceNOW. CERN's press release refers to the findings as "one of the most significant scientific achievements in the past 50 years." The particles in question are called neutrinos, and scientists have detected them using a 1,300-metric-ton particle detector in Italy. Neutrinos come in a number of types, and have recently been seen to switch spontaneously from one type to another. The team measured the travel times of neutrino bunches some 16,000 times, and found that the particles sped up 60 billionths of a second earlier than they would have done if they had traveled at the rate of light. This is a tiny fractional change, just 20 parts in a million, but one that occurs consistently. "This is the first time that we have been able to show that a neutrino travels at a very high speed in a very short period of time," says a study co-author.

By Adrian Cho, ScienceNOW

reference: – It's enough to make Einstein's hair stand up: Physicists at CERN think they've spotted neutrinos traveling faster than light, reports AP. According to Einstein's special theory of relativity—his E=MC2 equation—nothing should be able to go that fast. At Wired, Adrian Cho doesn't mince words: "If it’s true, it will mark the biggest discovery in physics in the past half-century." It's so jarring in the world of science—the BBC explains that modern physics depends on the notion that the "the speed of light is the universe's ultimate speed limit"—that the researchers themselves are asking other scientists to try to duplicate the findings before proclaiming them to be true. "The feeling that most people have is this can't be right, this can't be real," says a CERN spokesman. Chicago's Fermilab says it will begin its own experiments immediately.
TreeSum_summary: – Albert Einstein's theory of special relativity says that nothing can move faster than light. If CERN's new findings are true, it would wreck the theory. "I suspect that the bulk of the scientific community will not take this as a definitive result unless it can be reproduced by at least one and preferably several experiments," one physicist tells ScienceNOW. But, he adds, "I'd be delighted if it were true." Researchers found that subatomic particles called neutrinos made an average trip of 2.43 million miles, 60 nanoseconds faster than expected if they were traveling at light speed. "We measure the distance and we measure the time, and we take the ratio to get the velocity, just as you learned to do in high school," says a physicist at the University of Bern, who is also a spokesperson for the 160-member OPERA project. Scientists are now looking to the United States and Japan to confirm the results. A similar neutrino experiment at Fermilab near Chicago would be capable of running the tests, says the deputy director of France's National Institute for Nuclear and Particle Physics Research.

Flat_1024_summary: – A federal judge has declared that the copyright to the lyrics to "Happy Birthday to You" is invalid and Warner/Chappell, which owns the rights to the song's melody and piano arrangements, is likely to appeal, Rolling Stone reports. US District Judge George King in San Francisco ruled that sisters Mildred Hill and Patty Hill, who wrote the song in 1893, gave their rights to it and other songs to Clayton Summy in 1935, when he copyrighted and published them in a book called Song Stories for the Kindergarten. The first reference to the full lyrics appeared in a 1901 article in the Inland Educator and Indiana School Journal, King said, adding that there's no evidence the Hill sisters ever transferred the copyright on the lyrics, which are based on an earlier children's song called "Good Morning to All." "Defendants ask us to find that the Hill Sisters eventually gave Summy Co. the rights in the Lyrics to exploit and protect, but this assertion has no support in the record," King wrote, per the Hollywood Reporter. The Hill sisters struck three deals with the Summy Company in the 1940s, one of which gave the younger sister of Patty and Mildred Hill 50% of profits from the performance of the song worldwide, reports Rolling Stone. But the second deal gave the company only rights to movies and dramatic performances, and the third agreement, which is now in the court record, "contains no references to the transfer of the 'Happy Birthday' lyrics." It's not clear whether Hill even wrote the lyrics.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – A federal judge has declared the copyright on the lyrics to "Happy Birthday to You" invalid, ending Warner/Chappell's licensing business around the song, the Los Angeles Times reports. Ruypa Marya, one of the plaintiffs in the case, says she plans to appeal. "I hope we can start reimagining copyright law to do what it's supposed to do—protect the creations of people who make stuff so that we can continue to make more stuff," she says. The Hill sisters, Mildred and Patty, wrote the song in 1893 and sold the rights to it and other songs to the Clayton F. Summy Co. in 1935, Rolling Stone reports. Patty Hill claimed credit in 1935 when she was deposed in a copyright lawsuit, but she never publicly claimed to have written the song. In his 43-page ruling, US District Judge George King said the copyright to the lyrics, which are "dedicated to public use and in the public domain," was never owned by Summy. "Defendants ask us to find that the Hill sisters eventually gave [Summy] Co. the rights in the Lyrics to exploit and protect, but this assertion has no support in the record," King wrote. The basic tune of the song has long been in the Public Domain.

The AP tweeted its replacement tweet Thursday: "AP review: Many of the discretionary meetings Clinton had at State were with people who gave to Clinton foundation." According to the AP's review, 85 of 154 people who had in-person or phone meetings with Clinton while she was secretary of state were also donors to her family's foundation. The original tweet "omitted the important distinction between discretionary meetings and official meetings," John Daniszewski, the vice president for standards for the AP, wrote in a memo explaining the deletion. The tweet "gave the impression that a far higher percentage of Clinton’s total meetings while secretary were with donors than was concluded by the story's analysis, given that the 154 people included in the review did not encompass the many government officials she was interacting with during her time at the State Department. The AP "cherry-picked a limited subset of [Clinton's] schedule to give a distorted" report, according to the memo.

Flat_1024_summary: – Mitch McConnell is taking a lot of the blame for the government shutdown, but the Senate minority leader swears he's not dropping out of his re-election race. "When the country's in crisis and when a bipartisan agreement is needed, I've demonstrated on no fewer than four occasions that I can step into the breach and get an outcome that's good for the country," he tells the Washington Post. "I'm not running for reelection. I'm still a member of the United States Senate, and I will continue to be." His primary challenger, Matt Bevin, accuses him of selling out conservative principles and says McConnell is part of the "disease of dysfunction" in Washington. But McConnell swears his role as the "indispensable Washington Republican" won't be tarnished by the shutdown, and he plans to make it the hallmark of both his primary and general election campaigns next year. He convinced John Boehner to hold a vote on a bill that would defund ObamaCare—but only if McConnell first agreed to hold talks with President Obama and Harry Reid. That didn't happen, and McConnell's call for no such talks proved too much for Boehner. John Boehner vs. Nancy Pelosi: The former House minority leader was the one to tell Obama and Reid to stand firm, and she told them privately.

Flat_1024_summary: – Netflix knew it would face a flood of angry customer calls when it announced a price hike this week, and told employees to prepare for them, according to CNET. Some reps told customers that they had added extra employees to handle the calls, many of which were emotional, the employees said. "We knew what the reaction would be," a spokesman said. Netflix is splitting its streaming and DVD services into two subscription plans, each costing $7.99 per month. Starting in September, the company will no longer offer users the ability to access both streaming video and by-mail DVDs for $9.99 a month. The announcement saw the company's blog fill up with 4,000 responses, most of them negative. Over the past couple days, there was speculation that Netflix didn't anticipate how the price increase would anger some customers. Netflix spokesman Steve Swasey confirmed that Netflix had indeed prepared employees to receive a certain amount of calls from those unhappy with the hike. Netflix employee said that he was instructed not to rush anybody off the phone and to hear people out-pedal their complaints or suggestions—and to process cancellations if that was what they wanted.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Amtrak train that derailed in Washington state on Monday, killing three people, was going 78mph in a 30mph zone when the engineer told the crew to slow down, the New York Times reports. According to the National Transportation Safety Board, the event data recorder in the lead locomotive recorded the engineer talking about "an over speed condition" just six seconds before the train derailed, sending several cars off a bridge and onto a highway. The recording ended with the train tilting and the crew bracing for impact. The NTSB says the train was not equipped with positive train control, which can prevent derailments caused by excessive speed. The full investigation of the crash is expected to take up to two years.

Flat_1024_summary: – A new report from the Council of the Great City Schools finds that many US students are falling behind and aren't getting challenged in school. The survey of students in elementary and high schools found that 37% of fourth-graders say their math work is too easy, and 72% of eighth-grade science students say they're not being taught engineering and technology, the Washington Post reports. "If students are going to succeed in the competitive global economy, they need to be exposed to a rigorous curriculum," the report's authors write. "Many students are not engaged in rigorous learning activities. That’s below what many experts recommend for students in middle school." The report looked at national student surveys administered every two years by the National Center for Education Statistics. Among its findings: Many schools are not challenging students. Eighth-grade students report reading fewer than five pages a day either in school or for homework. Approximately one-third of students write long answers to reading questions on tests. High school-level students, for example, say they hardly ever or only once or twice a year write about what they read in class.

reference: – If your kid's favorite pastime seems to be whining to you about the rigors of school, it might be time to call his bluff. A study of questionnaires completed as part of America's largest regular student assessment finds that a huge segment of our nation's kids say school is far too simple. Some stats backing up the "too easy" refrain, per the Center for American Progress: 37% of 4th-graders find their math work too easy 29% of 8th-graders find that subject too easy as well, as do 51% of civics students and 57% of history students And the trend doesn't stop at middle school. In terms of civics and history, 56% and 55% of 12th-graders said the same thing, respectively; 21% said ditto about math And some of the intel gathered on the amount of work kids do seems to back this up: Nearly a third of 8th-graders say they read less than five pages a day ... in school or as homework. A third also say they write lengthy answers on reading tests two times a year—or less. USA Today notes that a fellow at the center says that the results chip away at the "school-as-pressure-cooker" portrait of our kids presented in movies like Race to Nowhere. Click for one take on why we have too many teachers.
TreeSum_summary: – The US education system is falling behind, according to a new report from the Council of the Great City Schools. The report, based on a federal survey of students in elementary and high schools around the country, also finds that 37% of fourth-graders find their math work too easy, 33% of high-school seniors don't write about what they read in class, and 72% of eighth-grade science students say they aren't being taught engineering and tech, the New York Times reports. "It's not that we're slackers," says the co-author of the report. "We're just falling behind." The report calls for more rigorous testing and for schools to do a better job preparing students for the jobs of the future.

Here's what fact-checkers are saying: The citizenship question has been included in every decennial census since 1950, but it's being removed from the long-form portion of the census from 1970 to 2000 and from the American Community Survey since 2000. The Census Bureau says the question wasn't asked in four of the 14 censuses that took place between 1820 and 1950.

Grief counseling was offered to the 150-plus employees at the moving freight company, which has been its client since October, the Detroit Free Press reports. "We were asked not to say anything, until the investigation is over," says the director, who wouldn't comment on whether the woman had given birth alive. Police are investigating whether homicide was involved.

reference: – The USS Independence has remained submerged a half-mile deep off the coast of California for 65 years, out of human sight since it was purposely relegated to the bottom of the ocean by the US Navy in 1951, reportedly with a bunch of 50-gallon barrels containing radioactive waste, per the Mercury News. This week, however, thousands of viewers watched as the first photos other than sonar scans of the 623-foot aircraft carrier were shown live online, courtesy of the same ocean explorer who discovered the Titanic, among other famous shipwrecks—and those pics show the Independence is in remarkably good shape in its watery grave. "There's very little change from when the Navy scuttled it," Robert Ballard says of his team's documentation, in conjunction with the Navy and the NOAA, adding the Titanic was similarly well-kept. What the deep-sea dive didn't find: any evidence of the atomic waste rumored to have been sunk with the ship, per USA Today, though a UC Berkeley nuclear engineering expert tells the Mercury News any danger posed by such waste would've long since dissipated. The 74-year-old Ballard says he treated his newest subject with the same respect he does all his shipwrecks, leaving artifacts intact. "Taking things off would be like bringing a shovel to Gettysburg," he says. (Sonar images of the Independence were first seen last year.)

Flat_1024_summary: – The rare condition known as acute flaccid myelitis, or AFM, has now claimed the life of a 6-year-old boy in Washington state. Daniel Ramirez of Bellingham had been hospitalized for more than two weeks with sudden weakness and paralysis in one or more arms and legs, and he died Sunday night, reports KOMO News. Daniel is one of eight children in Washington who have been hospitalized with the illness, which affects the nervous system and has now been confirmed in eight of them, reports KATU. There have been no cases of AFM in the state last year, but in 2014, there were two cases. "We thought that Hayden's case was the most severe it could get—paralyzed from the neck down," says Heather Werdal, mother of one of the kids. "That is scary for us because we didn't think it could (cause death)." Hayden, 15, is now in a wheelchair, but he recently returned to school for the first time in two years and is taking three classes, including French, math, and English. There's no treatment for AFM, which is not contagious, and the CDC is investigating a spike in the illness that has hit at least 50 people in 24 states so far this year.

reference: – Most of the national attention in Tuesday's election is focused on GOP gains in the Senate, but Roll Call points out that Republicans also are poised to hand President Obama a milestone he'd rather avoid in the House. Consider that Democrats lost 63 seats in the 2010 midterms are expected to lose five to 12 (or maybe more) seats on Tuesday. No president has lost as many in back-to-back midterms since Harry Truman lost 83 in 1946 and 1950, writes Stuart Rothenberg. Dwight Eisenhower managed to lose a total of 66, but Obama seems on track to top him. More typical is the pattern of Bill Clinton, who lost 54 in 1994 but bounced back with a gain of five in 1998. Still, if Tuesday is shaping up to be a night of celebration for the GOP, Politico offers a reality check, at least in the Senate: Several first-term Republicans in vulnerable states will be up for re-election in 2016. So even if Republicans win a small majority this year, they might have to give it right back two years later.

Republicans are expected to pick up seats in Arkansas, Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Montana, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, while Democrats are likely to lose seats in Alaska, Nevada, New Hampshire, and Virginia. Most recent presidents have had one disastrous midterm and another midterm that was not terrible. The GOP lost 30 House seats ... but gained 8 seats in George W. Bush's second midterm ... and a net loss of 31 seats. Democrats got shellacked in 1994, losing 54 seats in Bill Clinton’s first midterm ... but the party gained 5 House seats that year, for a net Clinton loss of 49 House seats. TreeSum_summary: – A 90-year-old California man was arrested last week for allegedly killing his stepdaughter, ABC News reports. Karen Navarra, 67, was found dead in her San Jose home Sept. 13 with a gaping wound to her neck, a deep laceration on her head, and a kitchen knife in her hand. A medical examiner determined she couldn't have caused all the wounds herself, and detectives believed the scene was staged to appear as a suicide. Police initially thought it was a suicide, but an autopsy revealed "multiple deep and intrusive wounds" to her head and facial area that were likely caused by a small hatchet or ax. After consulting with Fitbit, police say they were able to determine that Navarra's heart rate spiked from 3:20pm to 3:28pm on Sept. 8—the time her stepfather, Tony Aiello, says he dropped her off to bring her pizza—and then rapidly slowed. Aiello told police he was outside his own home a few hours later and saw Navarra drive by and honk with someone else in the passenger seat of her car. But surveillance footage from Aiello's home between 3:12pm and 3:33pm didn't show her car ever leaving in the direction Aiello said it did. Navarra was wearing a Fitbit, which can collect data like number of steps walked and heart rate, when she walked to her job as a pharmacy technician. Police say Aiello then returned to his ex's house to retrieve her phone, which he used to call her before allegedly shooting her. He was charged Friday with first-degree murder.

The poll ties Turner’s success to anti-Obama sentiment in the area, but the race is also taking a turn for the nasty: ThinkProgress reports that the GOP blanketed the district with a flier portraying a mosque rising from the ashes of Ground Zero, alongside images of Weprin and Obama, with Weprin quoted as saying, "I support the right of the mosque to build." Meanwhile, Politico leaked details of a nasty 1986 custody battle between Weprin and his ex-wife, in which Weprin is described as "heedless" of his toddler's son's welfare. It is an interim ruling in a case that was, later, resolved in Weprin’s favor, with the main judge handling the case later casting serious doubt on allegations made by the politician’s ex-wife. “The sad thing is that David is fighting you instead of thinking of the baby's welfare,” she told his sister-in-law, according to the ruling. In the ruling, Justice Bruce Wright described relations between Weprin and his ex as “warlike,” calling both parents “arrogant” and “egocentric.” Weprin, the judge wrote, “rushed into the toilet with the child and refused to allow in or to come out, and was compelled to call the police before would exit, although the bathroom was said to be cold.” Click for more on the case.

Nearly 12,000 people have required hospitalization so far, and flu activity was said to be high or even "extreme" in 39 states, as well as New York City and Puerto Rico. Health officials say the final pediatric death toll might exceed the 148 deaths recorded in the 2014-15 season. Although NBC adds that influenza usually isn't cause for too much alarm with prompt and proper treatment, it cites the cases of two children who died this month after experiencing "typical" cold or flu symptoms. The best way to keep your own kids safe, says Williams: Get them vaccinated. Fox 8 Cleveland lists child-specific symptoms parents should look for that might warrant a trip to the doctor, including labored breathing, finding it hard to keep from dozing off, and an unrelenting fever (or one that vanishes, only to reemerge). Flat_1024_summary: – The Supreme Court kicks off its new term today, and there's no shortage of cases on its docket. Here's a look at some of the bigger ones, via the AP, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, SCOTUSblog, and the Washington Post: Abortion: The court could rule as soon as next month on whether states can regulate abortion clinics. A lower court had already struck down a key part of California's law, but a ruling in favor of the state could open the door to similar laws in other states. Unions: If the court rules against them, public sector unions could be in big trouble. Lawyers for the unions argue that they should have to get permission before collecting dues for political purposes. The court has previously ruled that government workers can't be forced to join unions, but this case asks it to overturn a 38-year-old precedent that allowed all workers covered by union negotiations to be charged for representation. Texas affirmative action: Justice Elena Kagan has recused herself from this case, which involves a woman who says she was rejected because of her race at the University of Texas at Austin.

reference: – Hikers on the Pacific Crest Trail can expect to encounter harsh-but-beautiful landscapes, extreme fatigue, and—these days, at least—traffic. "You can’t talk about the Pacific Crest Trail without mentioning the crowds," Pete Brook writes for Outside. He should know: Brook currently is trekking the 2,650-mile PCT, which runs from the Mexican border through California, Oregon, and Washington to the border with Canada. But don't take his word for it: The Pacific Crest Trail Association so far this year has issued more than 4,000 permits to people planning on tackling at least 500 miles of the trail. To put things in perspective: 300 people attempted to complete the entire PCT in 2006, according to the AP, with about 120 of those making it. In 2014, 1,000 people set off and about half completed the trail. More traffic means more stress on the land, more improperly disposed of poop, and more inexperienced hikers requiring rescue. So what's with the increase in traffic over the past few years? You can thank Cheryl Strayed and her enormously popular memoir-turned-major-motion-picture Wild. After the book came out in 2012, there was a small increase in interest in the trail, the PCTA's Jack Haskel told the AP in 2015. But after the movie, starring Reese Witherspoon, was released in 2014, interest in the PCT exploded. "Millions are hearing about it now and are being inspired," Haskel said. Strayed, more or less unprepared for the journey, hiked 1,100 miles of the trail as a form of therapy as she grappled with personal demons. "However for others that follow her strategy of deliberate ineptitude, things might not turn out so well," writes DontHikeLikeWild.org. "Our advice to would-be hikers: Grow a spine first. Then get out there and hike the PCT." (This female hiker is the "biggest badass you've never heard of.")
TreeSum_summary: – When Cheryl Strayed set out to hike the 2,650-mile Pacific Crest Trail in her memoir Wild, she didn't think she'd make it that far. But she did—and now she's raising money to help other would-be hikers get there, the San Francisco Chronicle reports. The trail is open to all, but "those that choose to arrive unprepared can quickly find themselves in situations on the trail that begin to negatively affect others, as well as the trail environment," writes Kelly Servick at Outside. "An influx of inexperienced, and often careless wanderers may invariably add strain to the fragile natural and human resources on which hikers rely. Likewise even some experienced hikers are often responsible for inappropriate behavior and the resulting often sour reputation of hiker trash." So far, donations are mostly in the form of food, water, and gear for those hoping to make it to the end of the trail in June. (The movie Wild, starring Reese Witherspoon and Laura Dern, tells the story of Strayed's 1,100-mile trek as she recovered from drug abuse, divorce, and her mother's death.)

Flat_1024_summary: – Egyptian security forces and protesters clashed for a second day today, leaving at least five dead and more than 1,000 injured in the worst violence between the two sides in months, the Los Angeles Times reports. The military and police used tear gas and birdshot to try to disperse demonstrators in Cairo’s Tahrir Square, where protesters have been camped out since yesterday. “We are on the brink of danger. Those asking for the government to fall are requesting for the state to fall,” the army’s chief of staff said in a TV interview. Protesters numbered as many as 20,000 before midnight, yelling epithets against the military as darkness fell. “I should be at work,” one protester said. “But I suffered from life under Mubarak and I refuse to continue suffering and keep watching injustices being done to our revolution.” The clashes were sparked by the military’s proposed constitution, which would have given the military an expanded role in writing the new document. The Muslim Brotherhood and ultraconservative Islamists were among those supporting the protests, but the group condemned the violence and said it was “not a suitable time” to take to the streets, the Washington Post reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Federal Communications Commission is set to vote Dec. 14 on whether to gut net neutrality, meaning internet service providers like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T would be free to experiment with "fast lanes," prioritize their own traffic, or block or speed up certain apps and services. Here's what you need to know about the proposal, which the FCC is calling a "misguided and legally flawed approach" that would "facilitate critical broadband investment and innovation." The proposal states that the 2015 order that established net neutrality was "incorrect" and came to "erroneous conclusions," reports the Verge. It also states that because the FTC will now have oversight of ISPs, "the transparency requirement we adopt, together with antitrust and consumer protection laws, ensures that consumers have means to take remedial action if an ISP engages in behavior inconsistent with an open internet." But while blocking, throttling, and paid prioritization may be OK with the FCC, the commission says ISPs will still have to answer to the FTC, which may or may not be okay with those things.
