Flat_1024_summary: – It's the first day of the new year, which means it's time for the editors of the Wall Street Journal to reflect on the state of the US economy in 2012. Here's what they're saying: "Happy days, in other words, will be here again," writes James Surowiecki in the New York Times. "What we’re talking about is a spurt of rapid employment growth from a low base, not a tight labor market and rapidly rising wages like we had in the late ’90s." "The housing bust, meanwhile, has been followed by an epic construction slump that’s actually left us with a shortage of homes," he writes. "Every downward tick in the unemployment rate is another twentysomething moving out of his parents’ basement, stimulating a return to a more normal level of construction. Multifamily housing starts are already up 80% over the past year to accommodate the likely coming flood of renters, and there’ll be more to come once people have more cash in their pockets. This increase in economic activity will boost state and local tax revenue and end the already slowing cycle of public sector layoffs." "We’ll remember 2012 as a magnificent boom," writes Michael J. Casey in Slate. "The important thing to note, however, is that each month of recovery closes the gap between the natural rate and the rate the Federal Reserve is willing to set." Click for Casey's full column.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The good news: The unemployment rate dropped to 8.6% last month, the lowest it’s been since April 2009. The bad news: It’s only going to get worse, writes Paul Krugman in the New York Times. “The downward creep of unemployment from 10.1 percent in October 2009 to 9.7 percent a year later to 9% in October 2011 and then down to 8.6 indicates a rising natural rate of interest,” he writes. “And while the Fed has refused to resort to exotic moves to push rates down further, they’ve committed to holding nominal rates where they are until the economy recovers.” “What will this recovery look like in concrete terms?” he asks. “Total bank credit, which collapsed during the crisis, is growing again and will keep growing. That will make it easier for Americans to buy new cars and reverse the four years of growth in the average age of America’s passenger vehicles.” Click for his full column.

Flat_1024_summary: – "Politics was not playing a part in that room today," says Sebastian Coe, president of the International Association of Athletics Federations, after the group voted unanimously Friday to ban Russia's track and field athletes from the Rio Olympics, the New York Times reports. "It was unambiguous." According to USA Today, the ban is the first of its kind in Olympic history and comes after a report from the World Anti-Doping Agency found Russia was running a "state-sponsored" doping program in its sports. The Russian government oversaw the doping program, which involved switching out urine samples from supposedly tamper-proof bottles. "The head coach of the Russian athletic team and many of the athletes on that team appear unwilling to acknowledge the nature and extent of the doping problem in Russian athletics, and certain athletes and coaches appear willing to ignore the doping rules," says Rune Andersen, chair of the IAAF's task force monitoring the verification process. "A strong and effective anti-doping infrastructure capable of detecting and doping has still not been created." The Russian Olympic Committee says it will appeal the ban.

Flat_1024_summary: – Japanese researchers have taken a "step towards a radical new treatment" for heart attacks, the Guardian reports. In a study published in Nature, researchers injected heart cells from a donor monkey into five macaques who had suffered a heart attack. The heart cells, created in the lab from skin cells, were quickly incorporated into damaged areas of the heart and helped the organ to pump more vigorously. But all of the monkeys developed unusual heart rhythms after the treatment, leading researchers to say more work is needed before the treatment can be considered safe enough for human trials. "Currently, the only long term option for these patients is heart transplantation, but there are not enough donors to meet the current demand," a heart researcher says. "Ideally, immune rejection would be eliminated if the cells could be derived from the same patient, but this is costly and time consuming at a time when the patient requires immediate treatment. Another concern is that the incomplete integration of the transplanted cells could result in irregular heart beats which can be deadly."

Flat_1024_summary: – When fantasy novelist Zhang Wei paid $10,000 for a bottle of Scotch whisky at a bar in Switzerland last month, he thought it was the world's most expensive bottle of whisky. reference: – To say that it was an indulgent purchase would be an understatement: A Chinese millionaire paid a record $10,050 for a shot of 1878 Macallan single malt scotch in July—except it turns out the alcohol was all of 40 years old. Eyebrows were raised about the veracity of Zhang Wei's purchase after photos were posted online of Zhang posing with the bottle and the manager of the Waldhaus Am See hotel; the Swiss hotel's Devil's Place whisky bar has a 2,500-bottle collection. The prime condition of the vintage bottle, and the wording on the label didn't add up, said doubters. They were right. The BBC reports a series of lab tests were performed and returned all-around negative results. University of Oxford researchers carbon dated the sample and say there's a 95% probability it was produced between 1970 and 1972. And it's not even a single malt, as testing by alcohol analysts Tatlock and Thomson found it was a blend of 60% malt and 40% grain. Manager Sandro Bernasconi tells the Scotsman, "The result has been a big shock to the system, and we are delighted to have repaid our customer in full as a gesture of goodwill." The repayment was done in what's likely the most expensive way possible: SwissInfo.ch reports Bernasconi flew to Beijing to apologize and reimburse Zhang. The Daily Meal suspects the bottle is one of a batch of fakes that were so convincing Macallan actually purchased 100 such bottles in 2002. As for the story behind the man who felt comfortable paying so much for a nip of Scotch, he's a 36-year-old writer of online fantasy novels who reportedly made $16.8 million in 2015. "To answer you all, it had a good taste. It's not just the taste, but also history," Zhang, who writes martial arts fantasy novels under the pen name Tang Jia San Shao, said on social media when he bought the bottle at the Devil's Place whisky bar in Switzerland's St. Moritz. The hotel's owner, Sandro Bernasconi, says he was "petrified" when Zhang opened the bottle he had just purchased, but the .67-ounce drink "tasted good" and he was happy with his purchase. When Zhang drank some of it, he realized it was a fake, and the hotel has now rescinded the purchase. "The result has been a big shock to the system, we delighted to have repaid our customer full as a gesture of goodwill," says RW Waldhaus, which owns the bar. Tests conducted by the University of Oxford's Research Laboratory for Archaeology and The History of Art found that there is a "95% probability that the liquid was created between 1970 and 1972," per the Telegraph.

reference: – The 20th anniversary of JonBenet Ramsey's murder has led to all kinds of renewed speculation about the case, but now comes an actual development in the criminal investigation: The state plans to conduct new DNA tests on the panties and long johns the 6-year-old was wearing when she was killed on or after Christmas night 1996, reports the Daily Camera and 9News. A previous investigation by the two news outlets suggested that former District Attorney Mary Lacy erred when she exonerated members of the Ramsey family in 2008 based on her interpretation of earlier DNA tests. Lacy concluded that those tests revealed that an intruder killed the girl, but outside forensic experts have since disputed that, asserting that the DNA was a mishmash of multiple people and not that of the single person referred to as "Unknown Male 1." "If you're looking for someone that doesn't exist, because actually it's several people, it's a problem," explained a former US attorney for Colorado. The new, more sophisticated tests could provide an answer to which view is right. They could also reveal the DNA is worthless in terms of tracking down the killer, and merely the result of "inconsequential contact with other people," per the Camera. One of the most high-profile anniversary stories about the case came via CBS, whose expert panel concluded that JonBenet's brother, Burke, killed his sister. Burke has since sued, but the forensic pathologist he's going after argued in court documents this month that his view on the case was mere "speculation" about "one of the major unsolved crimes" of the 20th century and thus should be protected speech, reports People. No word on when the new DNA tests will be conducted. (Burke also talked to Dr. Phil.)
TreeSum_summary: – Colorado police and prosecutors are planning a new round of DNA testing in the JonBenet Ramsey murder case after a joint investigation by 9NEWS and the Boulder Daily Camera found flaws in previous testing. The new testing will involve new, more sensitive "kits" required of crime labs by the FBI's Combined DNA Index System, the database that includes genetic profiles from more than 15.1 million known offenders and arrestees and more than 738,000 unsolved cases. "We should be doing all reasonable testing that we can do, and we will be," says Boulder County District Attorney Stan Garnett, who says he has met with the Colorado Bureau of Investigation. "Over time, the results will be more individualizing to a specific male versus a family," the Daily Camera reports. Former public defender Michael McKee, who has taught an advanced course on forensic science at the University of Colorado, tells the Denver Post that he believes there is more to be tested and that the new kits will help "shed some light on what it." The 2008 testing of DNA found in her underwear and in two spots on her long johns didn't jibe with findings by forensic experts hired by the district attorney's office at the time. The experts disagreed with former DA Mary Lacy's conclusion that the DNA matched that found on the girl's clothing, that there was. The Bode Cellmark Forensics lab determined that DNA found at the scene of the 6-year-old's murder wasn't from one person but from "potentially accumulated DNA," which could have come from people in the Ramsey family. "Reproducibility and repeatability is a hallmark of science," says one scientist. "To me, that does raise concern."

reference: – The owner of a gun store in Florida who declared his shop to be a "Muslim-free zone" is now the target of a lawsuit. The Council on American-Islamic Relations filed a federal lawsuit calling the policy at Florida Gun Supply discriminatory, reports Reuters. The move comes after owner Andrew Hallinan, 28, posted a video to Facebook announcing his new policy in the wake of the Chattanooga rampage. "I have a moral and legal responsibility to ensure the safety of all patriots in my community," Hallinan says in the video, as quoted by NBC Miami. "So effective immediately, I'm declaring Florida Gun Supply as a Muslim-free zone. I will not arm and train those who wish to do harm to my fellow patriots." But the chief executive of CAIR calls it blatant "Islamophobia" that must be challenged. "Unfortunately, he caved in to a lot of the anti-Muslim pressure and anti-Muslim base that he's pandering to," Hassan Shibly tells USA Today. "When he refused to reconsider his position, when he refused to reconsider to be educated, refused to engage this community, refused to respect American law, we had no choice but to bring forward this lawsuit." Meanwhile, Chris Martin, a US military veteran who converted to Islam, has traveled to Inverness, Florida, from California so he can try to enroll in a training course at the shop to challenge the ban, reports WFTS-TV. Federal agents are reportedly keeping a close eye on the situation.

Flat_1024_summary: – South Korea says it won't allow North Korea to attend a reunion for families separated by the Korean War next month despite Pyongyang's demand for the return of 22 restaurant workers who defected to the South earlier this year. South Korea's Unification Ministry said Friday that the reunion will go ahead as planned on Aug. 3, but it will "not be possible" for the North to attend if the restaurant defectors aren't returned immediately, Yonhap News reports. According to South Korean media, the 22 women worked at a restaurant in the North Korean border town of Panmunjom and say they were pressured into defecting by superiors at the restaurant who threatened to kill them if they tried to return to the North. The North has demanded the women's return.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – North Korea is ratcheting up its rhetoric against the South ahead of a reunion of families separated by the Korean War next month, Yonhap News reports. According to the North's official Korean Central News Agency, the South "kidnapped" two restaurant workers from the North and is trying to force them back across the border. "We will closely watch what action the South Korean government will take," says one North Korean propaganda website. "It could serve as an obstacle not just to the planned reunions of separated families between the two Koreas but also to the overall inter-Korean relations." The workers are believed to have defected to the South via a restaurant manager who says South Korea's spy agency was involved in the process. The North has demanded the women be returned immediately.

Seoul, South Korea (CNN) The leaders of North and South Korea will hold a summit in Pyongyang in September, both countries announced Monday. 
 
 It will be the third in-person meeting between South Korean President Moon Jae-in and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The two first met in April, pledging to forge closer relations and work to formally end the Korean War in an agreement called the Panmunjom Declaration 
 
 They then held an impromptu meeting in May at the demilitarized zone that divide...
reference: – What was unprecedented in April is now becoming ... routine? The leaders of North and South Korea will meet again sometime in September, their third such meeting in five months, reports CNN. This time, however, the South's Moon Jae-in will travel to Pyongyang to meet with Kim Jong Un. High-level officials from the two nations announced the meeting after talks in the Demilitarized Zone on Monday. No agenda has been released, but the two sides have been discussing everything from a possible peace declaration to economic projects, notes Reuters. One potential sore spot: The plight of 12 North Korean women now in South Korea as restaurant workers. The North claims they were kidnapped—or perhaps tricked into defecting—and must be returned, while the South maintains they defected of their own accord in 2016 through China, per Yonhap News. "If our female citizens' repatriation issue is not resolved as quickly as possible, it could serve as an obstacle not just to the planned reunions of separated families between the two Koreas but also to the overall inter-Korean relations," said Uriminzokkiri, a propaganda website for the North, last month. South Korean officials declined to say if the issue came up in Monday's talks.
TreeSum_summary: – The leaders of North and South Korea will meet in Pyongyang in September for the third time this year, CNN reports. The announcement came after high-level talks between officials from the two Koreas at the DMZ Monday. "What's very important is that both governments do all they ought to do regarding progressing all the issues on the agenda," Ri Son Gwon, North Korea's point man for inter-Korean relations, told reporters. "If the issues that were raised in the inter-Korea talks and individual meetings are not resolved, then unexpected problems could arise and all the items on the Agenda could meet obstacles." Ri didn't say exactly when the September summit would be held, but Cho Myoung-gyon, Cho's South Korean counterpart, said "it needs to be discussed further." A spokesperson for Moon said holding the summit before Sept. 10 would be difficult due to logistics.

Flat_1024_summary: – Texas is bracing itself for more flooding after days of heavy rain, with the remnants of Hurricane Patricia expected to soak the state over the next few days. The storm system already moving through Texas dumped nearly two feet of rain on parts of the state since Friday, causing flooding that blocked several major roadways, the AP reports. Galveston County Judge Mark Henry on Saturday issued a voluntary evacuation for Bolivar Peninsula, just northeast of Galveston Island, after forecasters predicted that the area would get 8 to 12 inches of rain and tides that are 4 to 5 feet high. "Elderly residents and people with medical conditions should make plans to leave the area before dark," Henry said. County spokeswoman Brittany Rainville said there were buses waiting to evacuate people, but no one had yet shown up to leave. She said about 4,000 people live on the peninsula. In San Antonio, a man walking his dog before dawn early Saturday was swept into a flooded drainage ditch and disappeared, fire officials said. Firefighters searched for two hours but had to stop due to bad weather. The dog is safe.

The water partially submerged one locomotive and several rail cars, but both crew members "swam to high ground" and were pulled out by a high-water rescue team. reference: – Two crew members had to be rescued when flooding in Texas overturned a 64-car Union Pacific freight train on its way to Houston early Saturday morning, NBC News reports. Navarro County, where the train was derailed around 3:30am local time, had received nearly 2 feet of rain in 24 hours, and more was expected with what's left of Hurricane Patricia heading into the area. According to the AP, a creek overflowed and washed away the train tracks. "[The crew] escaped the train after it stopped and swam to high ground," a Union Pacific spokesperson tells the AP. "A Navarro County rescue team was able to get in and pull them to safety. They are back safe on dry ground." Despite several rail cars and a locomotive ending up partially underwater, no injuries were reported in the train crash, NBC reports. The train—which is carrying cement or gravel—was still on its side hours later, with crews waiting until water levels drop before they attempt to remove it. After three days of heavy rains, Navarro County has carried out five dozen water rescues. According to the AP, only one person is missing so far in the recent Texas flooding. A man walking his dog in San Antonio fell into a flooded draining ditch and was swept away. His dog was later found safe.
TreeSum_summary: – Hurricane Patricia has been downgraded to a tropical depression, but Texas isn't out of the woods yet. The state is under a flash-flood watch, and Houston, Corpus Christi, and other parts of southeast Texas are under a tornado watch until 10pm Saturday, NBC News reports. In Navarro County south of Dallas, two train crew members were rescued early Saturday after a 64-car Union Pacific train derailed in floodwaters, partially submerged one locomotive and several rail cars, but no one was injured. The 64-car train was traveling from Midlothian to Houston when it got caught in floodwaters that had closed major highways throughout North Texas. The county has received 20 to 21 inches of rainfall in the past 24 hours, and emergency management coordinator Eric Myers tells NBC that 72 swift-water rescues have been performed. The heaviest of the rain should be done by Saturday night, he adds, "but they're going to have flooding problems in South and East Texas at least through tomorrow." Hundreds of flights were canceled or delayed on Thursday and Friday at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The airport got 3.24 inches of rain on Friday alone—a daily record. The storm system already moving through Texas dumped nearly two feet of rain since Friday, causing flooding that blocked several major roadways. Galveston County Judge Mark Henry on Saturday issued a voluntary evacuation for Bolivar Peninsula, just northeast of Galveston Island. The judge warned that residents who don't leave might find themselves cut off from emergency services as the heaviest winds and tides are 4 to 5 feet high.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Australian couple at the center of a surrogacy scandal in Thailand say they would have aborted their pregnancy had they known that their surrogate had a baby boy with Down syndrome. "No parent wants a son with a disability," biological father David Farnell told Australia's 60 Minutes. "It was late into the pregnancy that we learned the boy had Down's. They sent us the reports, but they didn't do the checks early enough." But surrogate mother Pattaramon Chanbua told the program that "if we try to take our little boy, she's going to get the police and she'll come and take ourlittle girl," the Sydney Morning Herald reports. The Farnells returned to Australia with baby Gammy, who has a hole in his heart, and his healthy sister, Pipah. "We wanted to bring him with us," Farnell said. "There is no reason to be concerned. I'm not going to harm my little daughter." Farnell has 22 convictions for sexually abusing girls as young as 5, but he says he won't harm his 4-year-old daughter. "I have no inclination of doing anything like this. I don't have any thoughts about this at all. That is the 100% truth. I cannot do this again."

Sharron Angle retreats a bit, but mostly stands ground Republican candidate for Senate gives first interview to mainstream medium 
 
 Lisa J. Tolda / Special to the Sun 
 
 WHERE SHE CHANGED Angle softened her rhetoric on phasing out Social Security and retreated from statements about people exercising “Second Amendment remedies” if conservatives don’t prevail this year. 
 
 WHERE SHE DIDN'T Angle held firm in opposing extension of unemployment benefits. She also restated her opposition to abort...
reference: – A little thing like rape isn't a good enough excuse for an abortion, as far as Sharron Angle's concerned. Harry Reid's conservative, Tea Party-backed opponent gave an interview in January, in which she told conservative host Bill Manders that rape victims need to trust in God's plan. “Is there any reason at all for an abortion?” Manders asks in the clip, which was dug up by Think Progress. “Not in my book,” Angle replies. Not even, Manders presses, in the case of rape or incest? “Well, you know, I'm a Christian,” Angle says, “and I believe that God has a plan and a purpose for each one of our lives and that he can intercede in all kinds of situations and we need to have a little faith.” Angle got pressed on the issue yesterday in her first interview with the mainstream press since winning the GOP nomination. (More details from it at the Las Vegas Sun.) “You want government to go and tell a 13-year-old child who’s been raped by her father she has to have that baby?” asked her interviewer. “I didn’t say that," she responded. "I always say that I value life.”
TreeSum_summary: – Tea Party favorite Sharron Angle says she values life even in cases of rape or incest. “You want government to go and tell a 13-year-old child who’s been raped by her father she has to have that baby?” a conservative radio host asked. “I didn’t say that,” Angle replied. She added that she believes government should stay out of the issue of abortion, but “the government decided to get involved in this, not me. I’m just defending my position.” Angle has been making the rounds on conservative talk shows, but has so far avoided the mainstream media, Talking Points Memo reports. “It’s shocking to hear her say that the separation of church and state isn’t part of the Constitution, when it is laid out in the First Amendment,” said a spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

Flat_1024_summary: – As Hurricane Irene bears down on the East Coast, states of emergency have been declared in Virginia, Maryland, and Washington, DC, where Sunday’s dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial has been postponed. “I’m disappointed and hurt, really,” the project’s chief tells the Washington Post. “But the memorial is going to be there forever.” Irene has weakened slightly to a Category 2 storm, but is still expected to be a dangerous Category 3 hurricane when it hits North Carolina tonight. The worst of the storm is expected to hit Virginia and Maryland tomorrow night and hit New Jersey Sunday morning. In Virginia, Gov. Bob McDonnell has declared a state of emergency and ordered evacuations from low-lying coastal areas. “This is not a time to get out the camera and sit on the beach and take pictures of the waves,” he said. “We just thought better safe than sorry.” Tens of thousands of people along the North Carolina coast have been ordered to evacuate. "This is a very, very serious situation," said a public information officer for Dare County. "We have not seen anything like this in the lifetimes of most our residents." Some 2 million people have been told to evacuate coastal areas in North Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland. "I've lived through hurricanes all my life, and I've only run from one," said one man. "Unless it's a (category) 4 or 5 coming straight at me, I'm not leaving." Click for more on Irene.

Flat_1024_summary: – The New York Times is out with a list of the 10 things Donald Trump won't be doing in his first 100 days as president, and it includes a doozy: not deporting 11 million undocumented immigrants. The list includes not just Trump, but Jeb Bush, Marco Rubio, and Chris Christie, as well as Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders, Martin O'Malley, Sarah Palin, and Paul Ryan. Trump's plan to build a border wall and make Mexico pay for it appears to be the most controversial part of the list, but it also includes immigrants who came to the US illegally as children and people who have relatives here. The Times calls it "a potent symbol of the president's hardline position on immigration." In other Donald Trump news: In an interview with the Washington Post, Trump predicts that the "silent majority" of Americans will soon come out to vote for him. "Something is happening in America. You may not want to see it, but something big is happening. People are sick and tired of politicians, and I’m here for them," he says. "I’m ready to go right at the Mexican government. I'm going to charge them $25,000 per illegal immigrant and, oh, I’ll make them pay." In a break from the immigration rhetoric that has garnered him condemnation and praise, Trump said he would have more positive results in dealing with China and Russia if he were president. Asked by an audience member in Las Vegas about US-Russia relations, he said the problem is that President Obama doesn's not respect Obama. " I think we would get along very well. Click for Obama.

The story focuses on his surge in the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC/Marist poll, which puts him at 11%, well ahead of the rest of the GOP pack. The big question, however, is whether his popularity will continue to climb, and whether he'll be able to energize his base without alienating the more mainstream Republicans running for the nomination. "I don't think he's going to do very well in this poll," a GOP strategist tells the Times. "When there's so many candidates, you can appeal to a very small segment of the population and get news and get elevated. But look around, man. It's people here reading and." The Times story includes this line from GOP Sen. Jeff Flake: "He's not polling well enough to have an impact on the race, and I think that's a real problem for him." Politico has more.

Flat_1024_summary: – Scientists have long wondered how much water existed on Mars when it was young, and a new study in Science sheds new light on the planet's past. The findings suggest that the Red Planet once had a massive ocean that covered nearly half of its surface, more than a mile deep in some places, the Guardian reports. According to a NASA press release, that ocean may have been the beginnings of lakes, streams, and rivers, which would have been a good place for alien life to begin. "Ultimately we can conclude this idea of an ocean covering Mars, which opens the idea of Martian habitability and the possibility of alien life," says one of the scientists from NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. The study, which looked at water molecules in Mars' atmosphere using three of the most powerful telescopes in the world, found that the amount of water lost over time must have been six times greater than previously thought. The higher the concentration of deuterium, the heavier form of water left behind, the more water there used to be on Mars.

Flat_1024_summary: – Hunter, Jackson, and Kaden Howard were just 11 weeks old when they underwent the first-ever surgery for triplets born with a rare birth defect. If that happens too early, "the brain can be put under pressure. ... That can be detrimental to the brain, the vision, the life of the child. The condition is extremely rare—only two of the triplets are identical—because they are not all identical. "When you look from the top he—'It's awesome, I wouldn't change it for the world, but [it's] crazy.'" For the next six to nine months, the Howard boys will wear custom-made helmets, 23 hours a day, and will need to wear braces for the rest of their lives. Flat_1024_summary: – Wells Fargo says its employees—5,300 of whom were fired in a scam to meet quotas—opened 2 million phony deposit and credit card accounts in a bid to reach sales targets and get bonuses. But the Los Angeles Times reports that Wells Fargo also allegedly opened accounts for Latino immigrants—those who came to the US illegally—at no charge to help them send money back and forth between the US and Mexico. The Latino immigrants were supposed to have at least $25,000 on deposit at Wells Fargo within three months or pay a $30 monthly charge. The Times spoke to two former Wells Fargo employees, one of whom was fired two weeks ago. Siham El-Dahan says she sought help from the bank's human-relations department beginning in September. She says her managers played favorites, denied employees' breaks that are required by law, and regularly threatened employees about meeting sales quotas. Employees responded by opening bogus accounts for customers who didn't want them on a "daily" basis, she says. An emailed letter of complaint to bank directors and a signed letter to Wells Fargo's chief executive, John Stumpf, drew no response. She believes she was fired in retaliation for speaking out.

Flat_1024_summary: – "If you don't believe me, though, behold this video of Hadid literally staring into a camera for four consecutive minutes," writes Emily Yahr at Jezebel. "It'll shake your fourth grade self to the core." Hadid is Glamour's 2017 Women of the Year, and to mark the occasion, the magazine released a video of the 21-year-old model staring at the camera for a mere three minutes. The video has since gone viral, with many commenters marveling at Hadid's lack of apparent interest in what's going on. Here's what they're saying: The video "is probably the result of some enterprising video editor pulling the footage out from a photo shoot and turning it into an inside joke among staffers, but it's just as fun to imagine that the editors at Glamour were so devoid of ideas that they asked Hadid to sit there and do nothing for a while on camera," writes Willa Paskin at Slate. It's a good representation of how clueless many magazines are about how to produce good videos for the web and how equally baffled they are by nontraditional stars like Hadid, who, though a model, has become stratospherically famous for 'doing nothing,' and therefore need not—and perhaps cannot—entertain audiences with more conventional talents and charms. This is how backward our world is, now: A video of a Hadid doing nothing makes a weird sort of sense."

"The predictable counterpoint to all of this is that the dearth of women’s milestones and tradition is a result of our relatively recent entry into competitive sports—we’ve been sending large numbers of women through the college sports system only for about 45 years," Sally Bergesen, CEO of apparel company Oiselle, writes in a New York Times op-ed. Flat_Overlap_summary: – When it comes to marathon running, women are way ahead of their male counterparts, according to new research out of the University of British Columbia. "There's no battle at all," assistant professor Brian Dalton says. "Maybe more of a balance of the sexes." In the study published in Applied Physiology, Nutrition, and Metabolism, Dalton recruited eight men and nine women at a similar level of physical fitness and had them flex their feet against a set of sensors as quickly as they could 200 times. "We chose to measure foot movements because it makes use of calf muscles on the back of the leg, which are essential for practical, everyday tasks like standing and walking," Dalton says in a press release. "What we found is that males were faster and more powerful at first but became more fatigued much faster than females." Dalton says his results are consistent with previous research that shows males complete events like ultra-trail running faster but females are considerably less tired by the end. "If ever an ultra-ultra-marathon is developed, women may well dominate in that arena," he says. In a New York Times op-ed, the founder of apparel company Oiselle argues that women should be able to run the equivalent of a sub-two-hour marathon. Only 71 American women have ever run the sub-4:30 mile, and Bergesen wants to change that.

reference: – Guys might be good at carrying heavy furniture but they tire faster than their female counterparts, new research out of the University of British Columbia shows. "We've known for some time that women are less fatigable than men during isometric muscle tests—static exercises where joints don't move, such as holding a weight—but we wanted to find out if that's true during more dynamic and practical everyday movements," says UBC researcher Brian Dalton in a press release. "And the answer is pretty definitive: women can outlast men by a wide margin." Collaborating with the University of Guelph and University of Oregon, the researchers report in the journal Applied Physiology, Nutrition, and Metabolism that a handful of men and women were asked to flex their foot against sensors as fast as they could 200 times. Those sensors captured several metrics, including speed, power, torque, and even electrical activity in their muscles. The men were both faster and more powerful, but they also became more fatigued "much faster" than the women. Dalton notes that in ultra-trail running, men tend to be faster, but women tend to be far less tired; in fact in Outside, one runner calls for separate goals for women. "If ever an ultra-ultra-marathon is developed, women may likely dominate," Dalton says. But as for the Mars-vs.-Venus battle, Dalton jokes, "there's no battle at all. Maybe more of a balance of the sexes." More seriously: "Both sexes have valuable physical abilities and it only makes sense that we study and develop the tools to afford them the best advantage." (Sex gets better with age for women.)
TreeSum_summary: – When Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge ran the men's four-minute mile at last year's Boston Marathon, he became the first man to run it in under 4 minutes. But where was the women's equivalent? "Was it never even considered because, like the Four-minute Mile, we lack a goal with numeric roundness?" asks Sally Bergesen, CEO of apparel company Oiselle, in a New York Times op-ed. "Or was it because the company—and the industry itself—lacks the necessary interest and creativity to define what the equivalent mark would be for women?" The answer is yes, and it's an important one. Only 71 American women have ever run the four- minute mile, while almost 500 American men have. "We will shout it from the rooftops, drop it into casual conversations, and speak of the women who break it with reverence," Bergesen writes. "Because as it turns out, if we want someone to be a household name, we might have to build the houses." The Bring Back the Mile website and community aims to restore the mile as the " preeminent distance in the United States." Meanwhile, a new study in Applied Physiology, Nutrition, and Metabolism finds that women can outlast men by a wide margin when it comes to muscle endurance. "The answer is pretty definitive," says lead researcher Brian Dalton of the University of British Columbia, per Runner's Daily. "If ever an ultra-ultramarathon is developed, women may well dominate."

reference: – Saddam Hussain's name is making it difficult for him to get a job. "People are scared to hire me," the 25-year-old Indian marine engineer tells the Hindustan Times. Hussain was, yes, named for that Saddam Hussein; the name was given to him by his grandfather. It turned out to be a poor choice, as the young man has been unable to find a job since graduating university two years ago, despite having done very well in school. And he's applied for dozens of positions. He says he's spoken with some of the HR departments of companies he's applied with, and they told him his name was the problem, because it could cause "suspicion." One recruitment expert points out that this would be a problem especially if a job requires travel abroad, during which he might get stopped by airport or border authorities: "He might just keep getting stuck or the company has to pull him out of the sticky situation, making the hire cumbersome," the expert says. Hussain got his first name legally changed to Sajid, but though he got all his official documents changed to reflect his new name, his original name still poses a problem because it's listed on educational certificates, which prospective employers want to see. He's working on getting those certificates changed as well, but the process is moving slowly, the BBC reports. (Meanwhile, in America, a guy is trying to change his name to Hitler.)
TreeSum_summary: – Saddam Hussein may be dead, but his name lives on in one man's life in India. The BBC reports on the plight of Sajid Saddam, a 25-year-old marine engineer who was given the name Hussain by his grandfather, who apparently thought it was a good idea to name his own son after the Iraqi dictator. After graduating from college two years ago, Saddam got a job with a shipping company, but it refused to hire him. "People are scared to hire me," he says. "I am an innocent victim of somebody else's crimes." So Saddam went to court to change his name, and a judge gave him the go-ahead to do so on May 5, though it's not clear whether he'll be able to get a new passport, driving license, or school certificate under his new name. "It is not only us who hate you, the entire country hates you," a friend tells the Times of India of Saddam, who says he's known by many names, including Saddam Hussein, during his childhood in Baghdad. (The former dictator was hanged in 2006.)

Flat_1024_summary: – Denise and Micheline Lévy were just 10 and 9 years old when a French police officer yanked them from their school and heaved them to the ground as they were about to be deported to Auschwitz. On Sunday, the girls' long-lost dolls were presented to the Holocaust museum in Paris, the New York Times reports. The officer left the pink and blue dolls lying in the street, and a shopkeeper found them and gave them to Denise's grandmother. For the next three generations, the girl's parents, grandparents, an aunt and uncle, a cousin, and other relatives took care of the dolls, keeping them safe in their home in the French village of Gemeaux, the Telegraph reports. Sunday's presentation was the result of years of research by Frédérique Gilles, a teacher from Gemeaux. He tells the Times that his grandmother's "strong will" to keep the dolls alive allowed her to pass them on to his father and his mother, both of whom died before he was old enough to receive them. "It's a great honor to have them here," he says.

reference: – The FBI hopes new surveillance footage released today will aid in the recovery of 13 priceless artworks stolen 25 years ago and help put to rest one of Boston's greatest mysteries. In the early hours of March 18, 1990, two men dressed as cops were let into the Gardner Museum, where they tied up two security guards and absconded with the artwork and the museum's security footage, the Boston Globe reports. But the thieves, who have never been identified, may have missed one key thing. According to the FBI, surveillance footage from the day before the robbery shows a security guard letting a man into the museum—against protocol—through the same door later used in the robbery. The Globe reports it's unclear why this footage wasn't viewed by law enforcement earlier, but it could show a "dry run" of the heist. The newspaper identifies Richard Abath as the security guard in the footage, and the FBI is hoping the public can help identify the mystery man he lets in. Abath, a rock musician at the time who now lives in Vermont, has claimed he had no part in the robbery, but this new footage appears to contradict a number of his statements. No one has ever been charged with stealing the art—for which there is a $5 million reward—and no one ever will, as the statute of limitations has expired. Someone in possession of the paintings, however, could face charges. Their total value exceeds $500 million, reports AP.

Now the FBI is asking for the public's help in identifying a visitor who entered the museum the night before the theft and may have seen one of the works, the Boston Globe reports. "With the public’s help, we may be able to develop new information that could lead to the recovery of these invaluable works," US Attorney Carmen Ortiz says in a press release. The low-resolution video shows a security guard appearing to hit an intercom button, then to grant access to a man who can be seen in the museum's reception area at 12:49am on March 17, 1990. The man is also seen getting out of a car matching the general description of one. Authorities say the video "is compelling in that perhaps the identity of this person ... will shed new light on exactly what happened March 18 who else may be involved," the New York Times reports.

reference: – Pope Francis hit a wide-ranging number of topics in his address to Congress today. Here are five getting attention: Death penalty: He implored Congress to abolish it, reports ThinkProgress. “Every life is sacred, every human person is endowed with an inalienable dignity, and society can only benefit from the rehabilitation of those convicted of crimes." Immigrants: He invoked MLK's "I Have a Dream" speech in asking the US to be more welcoming not only to refugees from Europe but from Mexico as well, reports the Hill. "On this continent, too, thousands of persons are led to travel north in search of a better life for themselves and for their loved ones, in search of greater opportunities. Is this not what we want for our own children?" Marriage: In what Slate says is "almost certainly an allusion" to gay marriage, Francis lamented the state of the modern family. It is "threatened, perhaps as never before, from within and without," he said. "Fundamental relationships are being called into question, as is the very basis of marriage and the family. I can only reiterate the importance and, above all, the richness and the beauty of family life." Climate change: He said the US has an "important role to play" in reversing the "environmental deterioration caused by human activity," reports CNBC. "Now is the time for courageous actions and strategies." Arms trade: He told lawmakers from the world's largest exporter of weapons that the arms trade must end, reports the AP. Why do weapons get sold to war mongers? he asked. "Sadly, the answer as we all know, is simply for money: money that is drenched in blood, often innocent blood. ... It is our duty to confront the problem."
TreeSum_summary: – Pope Francis got a standing ovation when he entered the House chamber this morning, making him the first pontiff to address a joint session of Congress. "Mr. Speaker, the pope of the Holy See!" he said, per the AP. John Boehner told the crowd that the pope's visit was "a big deal for me as a Catholic," reports CNN. Other highlights from the address, as per NBC News, the New York Times, and the AP: On climate change: "The future of our planet is at stake because it is threatened, perhaps as never before, from within and without." He called for a "courageous and responsible effort" to tackle the "environmental deterioration caused by human activity." On abortion and euthanasia: "Not only do I support them, but I also offer encouragement to all those who are convinced that a just and necessary punishment must never exclude the dimension of hope and the goal of rehabilitation. The yardstick we use for others will be the yardstick which time will use for us. The Golden Rule also reminds us of our responsibility to protect and defend human life at every stage of its development." On immigration: "Let us treat others with the same passion and compassion with which we want to be treated."

Flat_1024_summary: – A new virus has been found in the blood of at least three people who'd received blood transfusions, but researchers say there's no need to be alarmed, Scientific American reports. "I'm not really worried about this particular virus," one infectious disease expert tells NBC News. "This is not SARS. This is not MERS. this is not HIV. We just don't know how many viruses are transmitted through the blood supply. There are so many viruses out there, and they have to be characterized in order to ensure transfusions are safe." The virus, which researchers are calling HHpgV-1, looks a little like the hepatitis C virus and the harmless human pegivirus, but it appears to be harmless, the New York Times reports. The virus was found in two of 46 people collected before and after they received a blood transfusion between 1974 and 1980. Both of them "cleared" the virus, and researchers later found it in two more people. One had been infected for as long as five years, but both cleared it, too. It's too early to know for sure whether the virus is responsible for any disease.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Researchers say they've found a new virus in the blood of at least two dozen people who've received blood transfusions, the New York Times reports. The virus, dubbed HHpgV-1, is believed to be related to hepatitis C and HIV, according to a study published in the journal mBio. But researchers say it's too early to take action against the blood because the virus doesn't appear to cause disease. "Does it cause trouble that would justify any response with blood safety? I don't think we're at that level," says an experimental pathologist who co-directs the Blood Systems Research Institute in San Francisco, an arm of nonprofit blood banks. "Anelloviruses are probably the most common human virus. They're very understudied." Still, "as this elegant and valuable work serves to emphasize the power of modern deep sequencing technology in identifying new viruses, the role of this newvirus in liver and other diseases remains to be elucidated." Flat_1024_summary: – When a Pennsylvania man died of a heart attack last month, he left behind a $7 million estate that will be subject to state inheritance tax starting next year, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reports. That's because under state law, a spouse or a child under the age of 21 can inherit up to 15% of a deceased person's estate, while siblings can only transfer up to 12% of that estate. The estate is also subject to federal inheritance tax, as well as sales and use taxes. The man, who was in his mid-50s, left behind three children, one of whom will receive $7 million from the estate, the paper notes. The other two children will receive $3 million and $1 million, respectively, from a trust the man set up for them.

 Inheritance tax is imposed as a percentage of the value of a decedent's estate transferred to beneficiaries by will, heirs by intestacy and transferees by operation of law. The tax rate varies depending on the relationship of the heir to the decedent.

reference: – Roland Bosee Jr., 68, and Nino Esposito, 78, have been inseparable since they first met in 1970. "You meet someone and it just clicks," Esposito told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette last month. So with the SCOTUS decision over the summer to legalize gay marriage, the men looked forward to finally tying the knot. But one issue is holding them back: Esposito is technically Bosee's father, because he adopted him in 2012. "We thought never in our lifetime—or in 20 lifetimes—...same-sex marriage [would] happen," Bosee said, adding to CNN that the adoption "gave us the most legitimate thing available to us" at the time. Even though they petitioned to have the adoption annulled, Allegheny County Judge Lawrence O'Toole —known for being progressive on LGBT issues—rejected that plea, noting that adoptions are typically only dissolved when fraud is involved and that nixing theirs "would place in jeopardy and imperil adoption decrees generally." Adoptions of this sort are often sought to cement legal status for financial and other reasons, as well as to strengthen emotional ties. The men said it was both: Esposito told the Post-Gazette "we felt we lacked a family of our own," but they also discovered that any money they inherited from each other would be subject to a much greater inheritance tax if they weren't considered relatives. One person on the couple's side: Pennsylvania Sen. Bob Casey, who tells the Post-Gazette, "I wasn't aware that LGBT couples were turning to this method. I can't even imagine having to get an adoption petition approved … to visit a loved one in the hospital." Casey has written a letter of support to AG Loretta Lynch, asking her office to "consider issuing guidance" in cases like this; her office is reviewing it, a rep tells CNN. (The gay marriage decision held up a heterosexual couple's divorce.)
TreeSum_summary: – When a Pennsylvania man died of a heart attack last month, he left behind an estimated $11 million in estate tax liabilities, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reports. That's because under state law, the executor of a person's estate can't pass the estate along to any of his or her children without paying the state's inheritance tax. The estate tax is levied on any assets above $11 million, even if those assets are in the form of real estate, according to the state tax department. The executor is required by law to pay the tax within three months of the death of the person, the paper notes. The man, who was in his 80s, left behind three sons, one of whom is a senior at West Chester Area High School. If the executor doesn't pay the inheritance tax by Sept. 30, the estate will be considered late payment.

reference: – US District Court Judge Ann Donnelly issued an injunction barring the government from deporting anyone during an emergency hearing Saturday night in Brooklyn, and her court was not the only one to do so. Reuters reports that judges in three additional states—Massachusetts, Virginia, and Washington state—have since followed suit. Reuters points out that these legal moves are curbs that do not eradicate President Trump's executive order that severely limits immigration, but observes "the growing number ... could complicate the administration's effort to enforce it." The former is exactly what an unnamed senior White House official pointed out, reportedly telling NBC's Kelly O'Donnell such rulings do "not undercut the President's executive order." The official continues, "All stopped visas will remain stopped. All halted admissions will remain halted. All restricted travel will remain prohibited. ... The order remains in place." But the pressure shows no sign of easing: The AP reports that the attorneys general of 15 states and the District of Columbia will issue a joint statement branding Trump's ban as unconstitutional and at odds with "a bedrock principle" of the US: religious liberty. The states: Washington, California, New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Hawaii, Virginia, Oregon, Connecticut, Vermont, Illinois, New Mexico, Iowa, Maine, and Maryland. What Trump had to say Sunday morning on Twitter: "Our country needs strong borders and extreme vetting, NOW. Look what is happening all over Europe and, indeed, the world - a horrible mess!"

A lawyer for the ACLU, which filed the lawsuit on behalf of two Iraqi men being, said at least seven detainees were released Saturday morning, with more people expected to be freed in the afternoon. Some people who were initially told they would be deported were allowed to enter the US.

CNN reports round two could see the US slap tariffs on another $16 billion in goods as soon as this week, but it's a much bigger figure that's attracting attention Wednesday. Bloomberg cites sources who say the White House is thinking about upping the ante and imposing not an additional 10% tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods but an additional 25%. CNN echoes that news via its source. Bloomberg frames the move, which would be revealed in the next couple of weeks, as intended to "force officials back to the negotiating table through threats of even higher tariffs"; the last high-level negotiations took place nearly two months ago. A Chinese foreign ministry rep responded to the news thusly, per the AP: "If the United States takes further measures that escalate the situation, China will definitely fight back. We are determined to safeguard our legitimate and lawful rights and interests."
TreeSum_summary: – China says it will "definitely fight back" if the US goes ahead with new tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports, the AP reports. A foreign ministry spokesman, Geng Shuang, said Wednesday that Beijing is ready for "dialogue and consultation" to defuse an escalating trade dispute between the two countries. "If the United States takes further measures that escalate the situation, China will definitely fight back," said Geng. He gave no details of possible measures but said, "we are determined to safeguard our legitimate and lawful rights and interests." The US imposed additional 25% tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods July 6 in response to complaints Beijing steals or pressures companies to hand over technology. Beijing responded by imposing the same penalties on the same amount of US imports. A second round of tariffs on products worth $16 billion could take effect as soon as this week. "I need to stress that dialogues must be conducted on the basis of mutual respect and equality," says Geng, a spokesman for China's Ministry of Commerce, per CNN. "Unilateral threats and pressure will only be counterproductive." Sources tell Bloomberg that President Trump has instructed US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to consider slapping another 200 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, bringing the total up to $500 billion from the current $34 billion. The tariffs would take effect if China retaliates for the new ones. Bloomberg's sources say Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He are trying to restart talks aimed at averting a full-blown trade war.

reference: – Dr. Sheik Umar Khan, one of the leading doctors fighting Sierra Leone's Ebola outbreak, died today of the virus in yet another high-profile casualty, reports the BBC. The death of the man hailed by the government as a "national hero" comes as Nigeria, the continent's most populous country, recorded its first case of the infectious disease, reports Reuters. The death was that of a Liberian consultant who collapsed in the Lagos airport on July 20, and health authorities have quarantined the hospital that cared for him. Meanwhile, American doctor Kent Brantly has a "grave" prognosis in Liberia as his family in Texas asks for prayers, reports the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. The 33-year-old tested positive last week. Liberia has closed its border crossings; Nigeria’s airports, seaports, and borders have been on "red alert"; and West African airports are screening passengers for signs of illness. Since February, 1,200 people have been infected with Ebola, and 672 people in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone have died; the fatality rate in this outbreak is 60%. Here’s what you need to know about Ebola: It's possible that Ebola can jump from animals to humans through "bush meat" such as apes, monkeys, antelope, and porcupines, reports NBC News. Once an outbreak starts, it moves from person to person. The fatality rate is 50% to 90%. Early treatment is vital. The virus spreads through bodily fluids such as vomit and diarrhea; it’s infectious when the victim shows symptoms and remains so after the patient's death. Many have contracted Ebola by preparing a corpse for burial. Up to 60% of patients will bleed from the eyes and skin. There is no cure, and antivirals aren’t effective. The only way to get a diagnosis is with a blood test, adds the Wall Street Journal.

The highest number of cases is in Guinea, with 319, followed by Sierra Leone with 224, and Liberia with 129. "The scale of this outbreak is beyond the capacity of each of the affected countries," said WHO chief Margaret Chan. She called on governments to "mobilize and involve all sectors, including civil society and communities, in the response." Among the developments: A major airline in Nigeria has followed the lead of Arik Air and stopped flying to Liberia and Sierra Leone. Asky said it made the decision to keep "its passengers and staff safe during this unsettling time," reports the BBC. In an effort to stop the outbreak, Liberia has suspended all football activities. "Football being a contact sport—people are sweating—they do contact each other, and that could result in contracting the disease," the president of its football association says. "It also has to do with the fans because whenever there is a game, a lot of people come together and we want to discourage gathering at this point." Two American health workers who contracted Ebola in Liberia are in stable condition at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, reports USA Today.

The Ediacaran critters were an odd bunch—from ringed discs and patterned blobs to lumpy ropes and wavy fronds. Taking to the warm shallow seas as early as 570 million years ago, these soft and squishy misfits were Earth's earliest complex life.

reference: – A researcher calls it "a decades-old mystery that has been the Holy Grail of paleontology": What, exactly, Dickinsonia was. It's one of a group of lifeforms called the Ediacaran biota, which the BBC describes as the "first complex multi-cellular organisms to appear on Earth." But for decades they've defied definitive classification, with scientists suggesting they could be everything from lichen to giant single-celled amoeba to "evolutionary dead-ends." Now, an answer: Dickinsonia is an animal that dates back 558 million years, making it the earliest confirmed one in the geological record. That conclusion comes thanks to fat, reports Phys.org. Ilya Bobrovskiy of Australian National University discovered a Dickinsonia fossil in 300-foot-high cliffs along the White Sea in northwest Russia, in a place so remote she reached it via helicopter. The fossil was superbly preserved, so much so that its tissue had cholesterol molecules present in it. "The fossil fat molecules that we've found prove that animals were large and abundant 558 million years ago, millions of years earlier than previously thought," says ANU professor Jochen Brocks, co-author of the paper on the discovery, which was published in Science. The Cambrian explosion that gave rise to modern animal groups didn't happen for another 20 million years or so. As for the oval Dickinsonia's appearance, the BBC describes it as possibly bearing "a superficial resemblance to a segmented jellyfish." National Geographic delves into the difficulty of studying Ediacarans, who had no shells or bones to leave behind and whose "squishy bodies have long since decayed." Read more on how the team overcame that here.

"The fossil fat molecules that we've found prove that animals were large and abundant 558 millions years ago," says lead researcher Associate Professor Jochen Brocks. "Scientists have been fighting for more than 75 years over what Dickinsonia and other bizarre fossils of the Edicaran Biota were: giant single-celled amoeba, lichen, failed experiments of evolution, or the earliest animals on Earth," he says in a press release. The team found Dickinsonia fossils with organic matter still intact in rocks in a remote part of Russia, where they "had to hang over the edge of a cliff on ropes and dig out huge blocks of sandstone, throw them down, wash the sandstone, and repeat this process until I found the fossils I was after," researcher Ilya Bobrovskiy tells the Washington Post. "I took a helicopter to reach the sandstone." The team believes Dickinsonia produced cholesterol, which is unique in ancient life because all organics break down, leaving only the "original skeleton of the cholesterol" preserved in molecular fossils. Researchers believe the cholesterol is responsible for the hair's color and for its ability to grow long, Newsweek. "What you get is an average composition of the ecosystem that was found in Siberia.

Flat_1024_summary: – Women who eat a lot of potatoes while pregnant have a higher risk of giving birth to a child with type 2 diabetes, according to a new study. reference: – The world's least shocking quote: A British man's admission that his fairly miraculous swim across the Hoover Dam reservoir was "drink fueled," per the Guardian. Arron Hughes speaks to the Daily Post about his Aug. 10 experience, which came after what he says was a 37-hour bachelor-party bender with friends in Las Vegas. Flat_1024_summary: – We've experienced five mass extinctions: The Ordovician-Silurian mass extinction of 443 million years ago saw 83% of sea life wiped out, the Late Devonian mass extinction which followed 90 million years later, the Permian mass extinction, and the last one, the Great Dying, which marked the end of the dinosaurs. But while those five extinctions usually saw two species of mammals die out every 10,000 years, the current rate is 114 times that, according to a study published Friday in Science Advances. "We were very surprised to see how bad it is," study co-author Gerardo Ceballos of the National Autonomous University of Mexico tells the Guardian. "This is very depressing because we used the most conservative rates, and even then they are much higher than the normal extinction rate, really indicating we are having a massive loss of the species." The rate of extinction for species in the 20th century was up to 100 times higher than it would have been without man, reports the New York Times. "There are examples of species all over the world that are essentially the walking dead," says Paul Ehrlich of Stanford University, one of the study's co-authors. "Avoiding a true sixth extinction will require rapid, greatly intensified efforts to conserve already threatened species, and to alleviate pressures on their populations—exploitation for economic gain and climate change."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Our species is on the brink of having its sixth mass extinction since the dinosaurs went extinct 66 million years ago, according to a study published Friday in Science Advances. "We were very surprised to see how bad it is," study co-author Gerardo Ceballos of the National Autonomous University of Mexico tells the Guardian. "This is very depressing because we used the most conservative rates, and even then they are much higher than the normal extinction rate, really indicating we are having a massive loss of the species." Researchers looked at 617 vertebrate species—including 69 mammal species, 80 bird species, 24 amphibians, 146 reptiles, and 158 fish—from 1500 to the present and found that the "background rate" of species extinction has been somewhere between 0.1 and 1 species extinction per 10,000 species per 100 years. That's a lot lower than the "more dramatic" modern extinction rates of 0.2 to 1 per million species per year, or 1.8 E/MSY, researchers say. "On human time scales, this loss would be effectively permanent because in the aftermath of past mass extinctions, the living world took hundreds of thousands to millions of years to rediversify," one of the study's co-authors says in a Stanford University news release, per NBC. The Los Angeles Times reports that if current trends continue, 1,508 vertebrate species could go extinct in the next 100 years—the equivalent of .2% of the world's vertebrate population.

reference: – Feeling upbeat? Enough of that: Planet Earth is undergoing a sixth mass extinction that will likely annihilate the human race unless we can curb the trend, scientists say. According to a new paper, the current rate of species extinction outpaces the natural rate far more than anyone knew, NBC News reports. The analysis "employed better knowledge" of Earth's natural extinction rate, the Guardian reports, upping the number from one extinction per million species annually to two extinctions. It then compared that to a current extinction rate that study authors consider conservative. Presto, they got a rate since 1900 that's eight to 100 times worse than the natural one. "We were very surprised to see how bad it is," says study leader Gerardo Ceballos. "This is very depressing." "If it is allowed to continue, life would take millions of years to recover, and our species itself would disappear early on," says Ceballos. But nations can reverse the crisis—which has been linked to deforestation, industrialization, and other human factors—by conserving threatened species and lowering pressures on their populations, the paper says. So far critics seem to buy the paper's basic math but doubt that species extinction will continue at this high rate for centuries. "It is likely the problem will decline rapidly because most countries will be rich and care much for the natural world," writes one environmentalist. Earth has seen five other mass extinctions, including one 443 million years ago that killed off 83% of sea life, and the most recent, which wiped out the dinosaurs 66 million years ago, the Telegraph notes.
TreeSum_summary: – "We're on track for a sixth mass extinction in the next 100 years. If we don't act now, we will be leaving behind a trail of dead animals and plants that will be unrecognizable to future generations." So says George Takei, a co-author of a study published Friday in Science Advances that found the rate of extinction for species in the 20th century was up to 114 times higher than it would have been without man's impact. "This is very depressing because we used the most conservative rates, and even then they are much higher than the normal extinction rate, really indicating we are having a massive loss of the species," Dr. Gerardo Ceballos of the National Autonomous University of Mexico tells the Guardian. vertebrates—including mammals, birds, and fish— comprise more than half of all species on the planet and have suffered a 52% decline over the past 40 years. The normal rate is two species dying out every 10,000 years; the current rate is 114 times that. Humans are largely to blame for the extinctions of at least 77 mammals, 140 types of bird, amphibians, and 34 since 1500, including the dodo. "The evidence is incontrovertible that recent extinction rates are unprecedented in human history and highly unusual in Earth's history," the study's lead author says in a press release. "If the currently elevated extinction pace is allowed to continue, humans will soon."

By Kwon Ji-youn 
 
 The world's longest filibuster went into the books Wednesday evening, leaving behind a host of records. 
 
 During the session, which began at 7.07 p.m. last Tuesday, 39 opposition lawmakers spoke for 192 hours and 25 minutes to block the vote on a disputed anti-terrorism bill that they claim will threaten personal freedom and privacy if passed into law.

reference: – Think Wendy Davis' 10-hour filibuster was impressive? That was nothing compared to what dozens of lawmakers in South Korea just accomplished in the country's first filibuster in 47 years. For 192 hours and 25 minutes—or almost nine days—beginning Feb. 23, opposition Members of Parliament rambled on in an attempt to block an anti-terror bill proposed by a member of the governing party, report the BBC and Korea Times. The goal was to get to the end of the parliamentary session on March 10, but the filibuster came to a close Wednesday after attacks by the country's leaders. The bill passed hours later. At least the lawmakers still have something to show for their efforts: They smashed the world record for filibustering set in 2011 when Canadian lawmakers delayed proceedings for 57 hours. The last speaker alone spoke for 12 hours and 31 minutes to claim the record for longest individual filibuster in South Korea. Speakers wore running shoes, thumbed through huge stacks of documents, read academic articles and online comments on privacy infringement in their entirety, and recited sections of George Orwell's 1984, per Yonhap News. It was unsurprising, then, that the parliament chair was caught sleeping. The lawmakers argued the anti-terror bill—allowing for the collection of data, including phone records, on people considered security risks—would violate privacy rights, but President Park Geun-hye said the filibuster was "nothing more than a dereliction of duty." The public was also peeved that the stunt held up bills regarding North Korean human rights and an upcoming election.
TreeSum_summary: – South Korea's opposition Minjoo Party broke a world record Wednesday night after speaking for 12 hours and 31 minutes to block a vote on an anti-terrorism bill—the longest filibuster in the country's history, the Korea Herald reports. The record-breaking speech came after 39 opposition lawmakers spoke for 192 hours and 25 minutes over nine days to block the vote on the bill, which would give the nation's intelligence service the authority to collect information on private communications, travel, and financial transactions of potential terrorists. The bill was put to a vote last week, but the opposition used the filibuster to delay it and prevent it from passing. The ruling Saenuri Party controls 157 seats in the 293-member National Assembly, meaning the bill is very likely to be passed. "Everyone participated with enthusiasm," Lee Jong-kul, the party's floor leader, said, reiterating that the bill infringes upon the privacy rights of the citizens. A total of 49 lawmakers took turns speaking around the clock in opposition to the bills, claiming it would give too much power to the intelligence agency. The legislators took their time reading related bills or academic papers on privacy infringement. Thousands of South Koreans have traveled to Seoul to watch the opposition lawmakers speak, with the most-mentioned book, the BBC reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – At least 14 people were injured—five of them critically—when a massive hail storm hit the Cheyenne Mountain Zoo in Colorado Springs on Monday, the Denver Post reports. "It was hail the size I've never seen before," the zoo's marketing director tells the Post. "Basically chunks of ice ... It's frightening." According to CBS Denver, the hail shattered windows on as many as 400 vehicles in the parking lot and sent animals and humans running for cover. A 13-year-old caped vulture and a 4-year- old Muscovy duck were killed in the storm. A third animal was initially reported dead, but later turned out to be severely injured.

Flat_1024_summary: – Hackers broke into Neiman Marcus' computer system as far back as July, and the breach wasn't fully contained until Sunday, sources briefed on the investigation tell the New York Times. The revelation comes as a 17-page report from computer firm iSight has been filed to the Secret Service, which notes that while some of the components of the breach were "technically sophisticated," "the operational sophistication of the compromise activity makes this case stand out." The report doesn't say who is behind the Target breach, but investigators are looking into whether the two attacks are related. The iSight report notes that "memory scraping capabilities has been available in the Russian-language underground for some time" and that "cyber criminals in Brazil have used the technique since at least 2009." Neiman Marcus, meanwhile, says that "some of our customers' payment cards were used fraudulently after making purchases at our stores. We have taken steps to notify those affected customers for whom we have contact information."

Flat_1024_summary: – Iran plans to beef up its naval presence in the Persian Gulf to protect three islands it says are its own, Reuters reports. The islands—the Greater and Lesser Tunb and Abu Musa—are located near oil shipping routes at the mouth of the strategic Strait of Hormuz, and the United Arab Emirates says they are its territory. The 41-year-old dispute between Iran and the Sunni UAE has nationalist and ethnic overtones, and was inflamed when President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad visited Abu Musa in April. Last month Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman Ramin Mehmanparast said Tehran would consider downgrading ties with the UAE over the dispute, although the foreign ministry later denied the report, according to state television. Meanwhile, Iran says it has produced a domestically-made drone capable of hovering in midair.

Flat_1024_summary: – The SEC today suspended trading in Cynk Technology Corp. over "concerns regarding the accuracy and adequacy of information in the marketplace and potentially manipulative transactions in CYNK's common stock," it said on its website. Cynk's stock had soared nearly 5,000% in less than a week, from 6 cents to $21.95 yesterday, Business Insider reports. The company appears to have no members, no revenue, no assets, and only a single employee. "Real companies get hurt when the entire space gets tagged as bad because of really bad incidents such as this," says a former SEC official. He later told Business Insider that he works for CYNK but doesn't actually work for the company.

"Kevin does this thing which was play fights with them in order to touch them." The actress says she saw Spacey approach "multiple people" on set to "say hello, greet them, shake their hand and pull their hand down to his crotch and touch their crotch." "I have friends say he reached up their shorts on set," she says. Meanwhile, a former student of Spacey's tells the Times the actor had a sexual relationship with him when the two were students at Shakespeare in the Park in 1983. The former student, now 48 and living on the East Coast with a long-term partner, says he went to a weekend acting class Spacey taught in Westchester County, NY, in 1981 when he was 12 and Spacey was 22 and working in the New York theater scene. Eight people who worked on the show or worked on it in the past tell CNN that Spacey made the set "into a toxic work environment" with a pattern of nonconsensual touching and crude comments. One former employee says Spacey sexually assaulted him during one of the show's early seasons. The crew member says he was working on the series' first season in 2012 when Spacey "would come in and massage my shoulders from behind or put his hands around me or touch my stomach sometimes in weird ways that in normal everyday conversation would not be appropriate." He says he didn't feel comfortable telling Spacey to stop.

The production assistant says when he and Spacey arrived at the set, the actor put his hands down the production assistant's pants. A crew member who worked on the show for all six seasons tells the Los Angeles Times that "this type of predatory behavior was routine for him and that my experience was one of many and that Kevin had few if any qualms about exploiting his status and position."

Flat_1024_summary: – Chris Christie gave what the Washington Post calls an "uncharacteristically low-key speech" at the Conservative Political Action Conference last night. He used notes instead of a teleprompter, and spoke off the cuff—"You know I'm shy and retiring, and I don't like to speak my mind," he joked—but he still managed to court conservatives with his pro-market and pro-life bona fides, his record on taking on public-sector unions, and his advice for the GOP: "We have to stop letting the media define who we are and what we stand for." He also went after the Koch brothers: "Mr. President, what the hell are we paying you for?" The speech was "poignant," and Christie "made the case that Republicans must 'talk about what we are for, not what we're against," writes Peggy Noonan in the Wall Street Journal. "There is the message for every governor running against every senator for the Republican presidential nomination. Instead, he argued that conservatives must be confident that 'our ideas are better than their ideas.'" At the National Review, Michael Tomasky writes that Christie "used the media-feeding frenzy at home to boost his conservative street cred." He used the speech to remind conservatives that he's "pro-market" and "anti-abortion," and he used it to shore up his conservative "street cred." Click for Tomasky's full column.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Chris Christie gave what the Washington Post calls an "uncharacteristically low-key speech" at the Conservative Political Action Conference last night. He spoke off the cuff, using notes instead of a teleprompter, and received a polite reception. "You know I'm shy and retiring, and I don't like to speak my mind," he joked, according to the New York Times. He praised the work of Republican governors across the country, including Wisconsin's Scott Walker, Ohio's John Kasich, and Michigan's Rick Snyder. "Republican governors in this country have stood up and done things, not just talked about them," he said. He concluded by suggesting that the GOP has lost its way by nominating candidates that are too conservative. "We don’t get to govern if we aren’t win. Let’s come out of this conference resolved to win elections."

They'll still be required to learn about Clinton's impeachment and Keller's efforts to provide education for deaf children, per the Houston Chronicle.
