Flat_1024_summary: – The family of a University of Richmond football player found dead in his car in a snowstorm last week plans to donate his brain to the Concussion Legacy Foundation to study the long-term effects of contact sports. "I just wonder if something happened," mother Phyllis Lee tells the Washington Post. "Because what he did was so out of character for him. It's like, OK, wow, something has taken over this sweet kid that I never would imagine would do something like this. And that just led me to think if something had taken over him, maybe it's his own brain that's working against him." The cause of death was suicide by asphyxiation, and the Virginia Office of the Chief Medical Examiner reported that CTE, or chronic traumatic encephalopathy, was found in his brain. The co-founder of the foundation says Lee's brain will be one of more than 650 in the VA-Boston University-Concussion Legacy Foundation. Redshirt freshman Augustus "Gus" Lee, 20, played football, lacrosse, and track at Paul VI Catholic High School in Fairfax, Va., and was a member of the Spiders' special teams units. He was found dead just off the Richmond campus at 1:35am on Dec. 11. His mother says her son's final two exams were scheduled for Dec. 10, but he hadn't been seen by his roommate. He called her when he went to check on her son. Richmond coach Russ Huesman says Lee "was a terrific young man and a great member of our Richmond family. His loss is a true tragedy."

Flat_1024_summary: – A Pennsylvania woman died last week after apparently overdosing herself while cleaning up drug paraphernalia in her son's bathroom, PennLive reports. Cambria County Coroner Jeff Lees says Theresa Plummer, 69, found her son, Ronald Plummer, 45, unresponsive in the bathroom Nov. 5. He was taken to Conemaugh Memorial Medical Center in Johnstown for a suspected overdose and died the next day. Plummer stayed at his bedside in intensive care as doctors treated him for a possible overdose, WJAC reports. The coroner says Plummer likely absorbed a substance through her skin or had a reaction to drug paraphernalia after handling it. "This is a caution for safety for anyone coming into contact with any type of powder substance," Lees tells WJAC. "You should use extreme caution and notify the proper authorities." Autopsies have been performed, but toxicology results won't be back for another six to eight weeks.

Flat_1024_summary: – Scientists say they've discovered a way to boost the heart's ability to pump blood, a finding that could have big implications for people suffering from heart failure. Currently, there's no treatment for right heart failure, which occurs when the left side of the heart fails, and the only treatment for left heart failure is a transplant. The new study, published in Cell Research, shows that a protein called Cardiotrophin 1 causes heart muscle cells to grow in a healthy way and stimulates blood vessel growth, "just like what you would see with exercise and pregnancy," says Dr. Lynn Megeney, senior author of the study and a professor at the University of Ottawa. When heart cells are treated with CT-1, they become longer, healthier fibers, while those treated with a drug called phenylephrine (PE) just grow wider. When CT-1 treatment stops, the heart goes back to its original condition, just like it does when exercise or pregnancy end. "An intriguing aspect of this research was how human CT1 was able to promote a healthy growth response in multiple animal models," says a co-author. "This suggests the action of CT1 is universally conserved and puts us much closer to therapy." The researchers say that two weeks of treatment with a pump-like device called a mini-pump improved blood flow in mice and rats for about two months, and they say it could be ready for clinical trials in two or three years. Heart failure is the leading cause of death and disability in high-income countries.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Good news if you've ever had a heart attack: Scientists say they've found a way to boost the body's ability to repair itself. In a study published in Cell Research, researchers from the University of Ottawa's Sprott Center for Stem Cell Research and the Ottawa Hospital's Heart and Stroke Institute found that a type of white blood cell called a cardiotrophin was found in the coronary arteries of people with a history of heart attacks and strokes. Cardiotrophin acts as a "relaxation agent" for the heart, helping it to pump blood more easily and to repair damaged tissue, the researchers say in a press release. It also appears to be an effective treatment for heart failure, which is the second leading cause of death in the US, according to the American Heart Association. The study's lead author, Dr. Lynn Megeney, tells the CBC that it's the first time a heart disease-related stem cell has been shown to be effective in repairing the damage done to the heart by an attack. He says the next step will be to test it on people who have had heart attacks or strokes to see if it works the same way in them. (Click to read about another potentially life-saving discovery.)

From labyrinthine security checkpoints to cramped seats and scant overhead storage space, air travel ranks among the most grueling experiences out there (unless you're one of the rarefied few who spring for first class). With its A350 XWB jet, Airbus integrates the latest design and engineering tricks to quell many of the headaches for flyers, carriers, and pilots. Chief among them? Jet lag. 
 
 "The design process was about optimization, pushing the constraints, and opening up the box of soluti...
reference: – If it works, it could be an air-traveling perk to trump all others: no more jet lag. Airbus is making the bold claim that it can at least reduce the malady for those aboard its new A350 XWB line of jets. The main tool is a set of LED lights within the cabin that mimics natural shifts in sunlight and theoretically keeps people's natural circadian rhythms in sync, reports Fast Company. Another factor: Because of the planes' relatively light frames, they can be pressurized to 6,000 feet, which the airline says allows for more humidity and makes the air pressure inside the aircraft closer to the pressure on the ground than is the case with most jets, per Quartz. A third factor is the jet's filtration system, which replaces the air in the cabin in its entirety every two to three minutes. The idea there is that, if nothing else, the improved air quality should help people sleep better on long flights. And the big question: Has it worked? It's a little too early to tell. The first such jet landed in the US only earlier this month via Qatar Airways, though other airlines plan to add the jet to their fleets, notes a post at Science Alert. (This protein might provide another way to fight jet lag.)
TreeSum_summary: – The first Airbus A350 XWB jet to land in the US arrived at New York's LaGuardia Airport last week, but don't hold your breath waiting for it to arrive on your next long-distance flight. The jet, which is scheduled to fly for the first time from Doha, Qatar, to Los Angeles later this month, is designed to make the trip across time zones easier and more comfortable for passengers, Business Insider reports. Among other things, the A350 is 20% bigger than its predecessors, 10% wider, 50% carbon fiber-reinforced plastic, and features LED lights that change color to reflect the sun's natural glow. It's also pressurized to 6,000 feet, so passengers have more room to move around. The plane's flaps follow the flight path, which reduces drag and noise and makes the ride smoother. It also features a filter that changes the air every two to three minutes to keep stale air from entering the cabin. The A350's interior is also designed to be adaptable so that carriers can swap out seats and configuration much more easily than in the past. "There's an open architecture that can evolve to welcome new functions and can cope with the evolution of technology," an Airbus engineer tells Popular Mechanics.

"Our aircraft landed safely, was fully examined by our engineers and it was cleared to operate its next flight," the rep says. No arrests have been made (it's unclear whose drone it may have been), and the aviation security arm of the Metropolitan Police is looking into the matter. Police note that flying a drone too close to a plane is illegal, NBC News reports, with punishment including up to five years in prison. Specifically, drones over 15 pounds can't fly higher than 400 feet and aren't permitted to fly "beyond the direct unaided line of sight" of its operator or near crowds or buildings. Not that the incident came as a total surprise: The head of the International Air Transport Association had previously noted the "real and growing threat" of a drone-plane hit, while a British Airline Pilots Association rep says it was "only a matter of time." A recent study by Bard College's Center for the Study of the Drone underscores the danger in US airspace, with 327 "close encounters" of drones flying within 500 feet of manned aircraft between December 2013 and September 2015, and at least 28 pilots "[maneuvering] to avoid a collision with a drone." Frighteningly, aviation experts say they don't really know what would happen if a drone got sucked into a plane's engine, a Civil Aviation Authority rep tells NBC. (A drone recently came within 200 feet of a plane at LAX.)
TreeSum_summary: – "This is dangerous, it is also a crime. Please be aware of the rules before you start flying a drone," London's Metropolitan Police tweeted Sunday after a British Airways plane was hit by a drone while landing at Heathrow Airport. The pilot reported the incident, which landed safely, to police after the drone came within 500 feet of the plane as it was coming in to land from Geneva, NBC News reports. Five crew members and 132 passengers were aboard the Airbus A320 at the time. British Airways said in a statement that the plane was inspected and cleared for the next flight. "Safety and security are always our first priority and we will give the police every assistance with their investigation," the airline said. The UK's Air Proximity Board says it has logged more than 100 near-misses involving drones over the past two years, the BBC reports. The board says drones "just have no place to be" at the country's airports, with incidents including a drone "flying over the top of a B737 aircraft while at 4,000 feet, missing it by about 5m, shortly after it left" Manchester Airport in August, and a drone that came within 50 feet of a plane in September.

Flat_1024_summary: – The death toll from Typhoon Haiyan's devastation in the Philippines now stands at 2,357, according to the country's government, but that figure is expected to continue rising as relief workers reach the hard-hit city of Tacloban. Tens of thousands of people are still trapped in the city, and there are reports of murder, rape, looting, and ambushes, the Guardian reports. The city has been turned into a "war zone," with tanks rolling through the center and soldiers crouching behind walls with automatic rifles. Many aid workers have been pulled out for security reasons, and some are fleeing the city for the safety. "There are many people who had chronic illnesses before this disaster struck who need to be taken to the medical treatment center that area still working," says a European Commission spokesman. "You have the elderly, small children, babies who are being born, there are many things." The US military says it is also preparing to send the USS Carl Vinson, which will be the first US warship to deliver aid. The British warship HMS Illustrious will relieve the USS Daring, which is already in the Gulf. More than 11 million people have been affected by the storm.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – As the scope of Typhoon Haiyan's devastation becomes clear, the Philippines is turning to the international community for help. More than 100 US troops are en route to the country, the New York Times reports, and the State Department has promised an additional $100 million in humanitarian aid. The US is also sending two cargo planes with supplies including food, water, looting, and tarps to Tacloban, the Philippine city at the center of the storm. "There's a lot of dead bodies outside. There's no water, no food," a doctor at the city's airport clinic tells USA Today. "Patients had to endure the pain." The death toll is expected to be "significantly lower" than the 10,000 earlier estimated, the country's health minister tells the BBC, adding that international criticism of the government's relief efforts is "unkind." But the situation remains desperate in some areas, where bodies are still lying in the open and people are digging through water pipes to extract fuel from petrol stations. The Philippines has sent troops to keep law and order, but there is a "growing sense of panic" in TacloBAN, where some survivors have resorted to digging up water pipes and extracting fuel from reservoirs at gas.

Flat_1024_summary: – The superintendent of a small Kansas school district resigned Tuesday after two high school journalists published an investigative piece that led to his ouster. The Booster Redux, a student-run newspaper, printed a front-page story on the resignation of Russell Robertson, the superintendent of the Hoisington school district. In the piece, the students revealed that Robertson had been accused of sexual misconduct in the past, including an alleged affair with a female student, but that he had continued to lead the district as superintendent. After Robertson's resignation, national journalists—including David Fahrenthold of the Washington Post—tweeted the students' story, congratulating them for their work. "To know that the administration saw that and respected that, it was a really great moment for us," the Booster Redux's editor-in-chief tells the Topeka Capital-Journal.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – When Pittsburg High School in Kansas hired Amy Robertson as its new principal last month, the school board called her "the best fit," saying she had "decades of experience in education." Problem is, Robertson doesn't have any of those decades of experience, the Kansas City Star reports. Robertson, who'd lived in Dubai for 19 years, isn't licensed in Kansas, and her master's and doctorate degrees from a private college in the United Arab Emirates, where she's lived for the last decade, don't appear to be legit. Corllins University, where Robertson got her degrees, hasn't responded to emails from the Star about its status. The school's newspaper, the Booster Redux, published a story Friday questioning the legitimacy of the college, which the Department of Education couldn't find. "We stumbled on some things that most might not consider legitimate credentials," says student newspaper editor Trina Paul. "The kids had never gone through someone like this before. I want our kids to have real-life experiences, whether it's welding or journalism." Superintendent Destry Brown said Tuesday night that Robertson "felt it was in the best interest of the district to resign her position." The school board plans to reopen the principal.

Flat_1024_summary: – Vitamin B12 helps the brain, nerves, and blood work properly, and it's found in meat, fish, eggs, dairy products, and Marmite. But some people take the vitamin, which is also found in vitamins A, C, and D, and end up with acne, reports LiveScience. So researchers set out to find out why. Their findings, published today in Science Translational Medicine, could eventually lead to better treatments for acne. "It has been reported several times that people who take B12 develop acne," says Huiying Li, a molecular pharmacologist at the University of California-Los Angeles and a co-author of the study. "So it’s exciting that we found that the potential link between B12 and acne is through the skin bacteria." Li's team found that people taking B12 have high levels of Propionibacterium acnes, the bacteria that causes acne. The vitamin lowers the bacteria's production of B12, which causes it to produce more porphyrins, which are also linked to inflammation. "The main message is that skin bacteria are important," says Li. "They're contributing members of our skin's society, and they like to do things in a certain way."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – If you take vitamin B12, you may want to steer clear of acne-prone skin. UCLA researchers say they've found a link between vitamin B12 and Propionibacterium acnes, the skin bacteria most associated with acne, LiveScience reports. "I think there's a link," says a co-author of the study. "There's still a lot to be studied in order to really understand if B12 causes acne." The researchers looked at the gene expression of the skin microbe in people with acne and people without acne. They found that the pathway that produces vitamin B 12 was altered, and this changed the bacteria's gene expression, which could have led to acne-promoting inflammation. They then studied the skin of people who received a B12 injection, and found that one of the 10 participants broke out in pimples a week after receiving the injection. That person's P. acnes gene-expression pattern also changed, the researchers found. "This study does present some compelling evidence suggesting that supplementation with B12 can cause or exacerbate acne in a subset of individuals," says one dermatology professor. But, he adds, "Proof of a causative effect of B12 supplements on acne development will require randomized control trials with enough."

Click for the full story. – "In Ireland, the day may have written checks the night can't cash, but out here in Doolin, on this night at least, the credit's still good." So writes Andrew McCarthy in a lengthy piece for National Geographic about life in the land of shamrocks and craic. "The Irish may have stopped going to church in large numbers, but it’s impossible to get the church out of the people," he writes. "Outside, a light rain's begun. I make my way over the stone bridge and past McGann's Pub. The band inside is slashing into a reel, and I stand under the glow of the lone streetlamp, listening. The music burns to a crescendo and then breaks hard. There's a moment of absolute silence in the countryside, and then it's shattered as the crowd inside erupts." Click for McCarthy's full column.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – In the wake of Ireland’s economic crisis, Andrew McCarthy set out to explore the rural West of the country—and returned with a decidedly different impression. “It’s worst we’ve seen our lifetime,” he writes in the New Yorker. “And there’s absolutely hope for the future.” McCarthy discovered traditional Irish music in the village of Doolin, which “has long been the epicenter of the success renaissance” of the genre. “You can practically hear them singing ‘How How’d you like?’—except you’re more likely to catch the sounds of searing fiddles, rising flutes, and bodhrn.” The music, he writes, “may not be worth $20 a night, but it’s kept the place buzzing.” To see McCarthy’s full piece, click here.

reference: – It is one of the most unusual, and rarest, jobs in the country: Larry Villarin is a certified male sex surrogate, one of only 10 in the US sanctioned by the International Professional Surrogates Association. But as a profile at Broadly makes clear, the 62-year-old Villarin is not to be confused with a male gigolo. His role is to help clients "cope with their fears and anxieties about physical intimacy," writes Natalie O'Neill, and sex is just one component of that. The story uses the example of a 35-year-old woman who had shied away from intimacy her entire adult life because a car accident as a teenager left her blind in one eye. She'd never even been kissed until her sessions with Villarin. "She needed to believe I wouldn't laugh at her or run away," he says. "It was beautiful to see her open up." On its website, IPSA says "it is committed to promoting healthy attitudes toward sexuality and intimacy in our clients and in the community," and the story explains that it gets around prostitution laws "because it doesn't acknowledge intercourse is part of the practice." Villarin says his clients range in age from 22 to 75, with milestone birthdays seemingly one of the big triggers. Most are referred to him from a psychologist, with survivors of abuse and women with disabilities among those reaching out. One of the tricky parts is setting boundaries so the clients don't confuse the physical intimacy with romantic feelings for Villarin. "It's just growth—what humans are capable of," he says. "Gosh, it's intimate stuff." Click for the full story. (This study has concluded how often happy couples have sex.)
TreeSum_summary: – Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie are expecting their second child, and if you're wondering what it's like to be a dad, the answer is "surrogate partner therapy." Surrogate partners, as they're called, are people who are willing to act as a surrogate for a man or a woman who is unable to have children of their own. There's even a term for them: "sex surrogates." The Pitt-Jolie news comes via a report in the New York Daily News by Jolie's rep, who says the actress has "struggled with her sexuality for a long time." The rep adds that Pitt and Jolie have been dating for about a year and a half. Pitt, 52, and Jolie, 39, have a 6-year-old daughter and a son, both born through in-vitro fertilization, respectively. Flat_1024_summary: – If you're black, you may be more likely to be stopped by a white police officer than a white driver, according to a study published Wednesday in Social Psychological and Personality Science. The New York Times reports researchers asked 414 people who'd been stopped by police to rate the level of "respect," "impartial," "friendly," "formal," and "professional" language used by the officers during the stop. The subjects rated officers' language based on how respectful they were toward the person they were stopped by, as well as the officers' level of formality (e.g., "ma'am" or "sir"). The study looked at body camera footage from officers in Oakland, Calif., who stopped 1,440 drivers, 68.1% of whom were black and the rest white, from April 2014 to April 2015. Participants rating officers' words on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the most respectful, per a press release. Officers' words toward black drivers were rated as “less respectful,” “polite,” “friendly,” “impartial,” “formal,” and “respectful,” while white drivers received 57% more respect than black drivers. "This work demonstrates the power of body-cam footage as an important source of data, not just as evidence," the researchers say, per the Los Angeles Times.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – A new study finds police officers speak less respectfully to black drivers even when controlling for race, severity of infraction, stop location, and stop outcome, the Los Angeles Times reports. "Such disparities in common, everyday interactions between police and the communities they serve have important implications for procedural justice and the building of police–community trust," researchers write in the study, published in PLOS One. The study looked at 414 interactions between black drivers and police officers in five US cities over a two-year period. The subjects rated officers' level of respect based on five categories: respectful, impartial, friendly, polite, and formal. White drivers were rated the same as black drivers when it came to respectful—they were more likely to be called "ma'am" or "sir," and they were more often to hear the words "please" and "thank you," reports the BBC. Black drivers, on the other hand, were called by their first names (including "my man") and were less likely to use "disfluencies" and informal titles like "My Man" than when they speak to white drivers.

reference: – The discovery of 12 Thai boys and their coach still alive after 10 days trapped in a flooded cave has brought massive relief to their families and an anxious nation—but the military warns that their ordeal could be only just beginning. The group, discovered by two British divers late Monday, are on a dry rock ledge around 2.5 miles from the mouth of the cave, and the Thai military says it could be months before it can get them out, unless the boys learn to dive, the BBC reports. The cave in northern Thailand often remains flooded until the end of the rainy season in September or October, meaning the youth soccer team and their coach may need to have food and other supplies sent in for the next four months. Experts warn that it could be very difficult to get the boys, ages 11 to 16, to safety through miles of dark, narrow, flooded tunnels. "Trying to take non-divers through a cave is one of the most dangerous situations possible, even if the dives are relatively easy," US National Cave Rescue Commission coordinator Anmar Mirza tells the AP. Thai officials say they're committed to "100% safety" and will continue to explore their options, including draining water from the cave system and searching for shafts that could provide an alternative escape route. Officials say the boys are hungry and weak but in stable medical condition with only minor injuries. They have been provided with high-protein liquid food and will be given more supplies and visited by doctors in the days to come.
TreeSum_summary: – The 12 boys and their soccer coach found alive in a cave in Thailand on Monday have had their first taste of freedom in 10 days. "We will not rush to take the lads out of the cave," the governor of Chiang Rai province, Narongsak Ousted, told reporters Tuesday, per the BBC. "Whoever has zero risk first can leave the cave first." Seven divers have now joined the group, including a doctor and a nurse. The boys have been given easy-to-digest food, "high-energy food with vitamins and minerals," under the supervision of a doctor, said Rear Admiral Apagorn Youkonggaew, head of the Thai navy's special forces. The military earlier said the boys would need to learn to dive—or wait up to four months for flooding to recede. More heavy rain could see water levels rise and threaten the air pocket where the group has taken refuge. Interior Minister Anupong Paojinda later stressed the urgency of the evacuation, adding that rain was forecast "in the next few days." Attempts are being made to reduce the risk of further flooding of the caves by pumping water from the underground system, Mr. Anupong said. A phone line is also being installed so the boys can talk to their families.

Flat_1024_summary: – The water crisis in Flint, Mich., isn't just affecting people, it's affecting pets as well. The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development says there have been at least four cases of lead poisoning in animals since the city's water switch-over in 2014, the Detroit Free Press reports. State officials say most tests for lead in dogs have come back negative, but owners are being advised to see a veterinarian if their pets show symptoms such as dullness, arthritis, or general malaise. "My dog, when I get up in the morning, the first thing he wants to do is get up and go to the bathroom," a vet tells USA Today. "(Pet owners) know their animals. And when they're not their normal selves, tell them to seek veterinary care." Officials have not disclosed whether the dogs were drinking Flint water, how much lead was in their systems, what symptoms they were showing, their weight, or how old they are.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Two dogs in Flint, Mich., have tested positive for lead poisoning, the first such cases in the state in five years, the Detroit Free Press reports. One was a pet, and the other was a family animal. "One was last fall and one was here in January," state veterinarian Dr. James Averill tells CBS Detroit. The dogs are still alive, but Averill says there's no regular testing for lead. "Dogs are at a higher risk amongst mammals for finding high lead levels, but it's not that common," he says. "Typically for us when we deal with lead toxicity we're usually dealing with cattle. So, really this was a new instance for us." Officials have not disclosed whether the dogs were drinking Flint water, how much lead was in their systems, what symptoms they were showing, their weight, or how old they are.

Flat_1024_summary: – In what one space expert calls a "diplomatic Post-it note," NASA has suspended all "bilateral contacts" with Russia in the wake of the country's annexation of Crimea, the Christian Science Monitor reports. "This suspension includes NASA travel to Russia and visits by Russian Government representatives to NASA facilities, bilateral meetings, email, and teleconferences or videoconferences," NASA's associate administrator for international and interagency relations wrote in a memo sent to staff yesterday. The memo exempts the International Space Station, which is operated by Russia, as well as meetings with other partners, such as Canada, Europe, and Japan. But the move highlights an important fact: For the next few years, NASA can't send astronauts into space without Russia, which has served as America's taxi service for delivering and retrieving US crew members from the space station. "If the United States wants to avoid looking extremely hypocritical, this was going to be coming," a professor at the US Naval War College tells the Monitor. The director of the Space Policy Institute tells RIA Novosti that the move will have a "rather significant" impact on the international space program, though he doesn't think Russia will give up its space program entirely. The researchers tested the hand-grip's ability on 14 cadavers, all of whom were able to lift with their arms straight. They found that the arm's abductor muscles became less active in the straight-grip group.

reference: – When journalist Al Letson saw a suspected alt-right protester being beaten by "antifa" supporters in Berkeley, Calif., on Sunday, he didn't stop to consider what the fallen man might think of him. Letson, who is black, simply wanted to save him. Running into the crowd, Letson jumped on top of the man in order to protect him. A series of videos posted to Twitter show Letson, in a red shirt, shielding the man's body and attempting to push the assailants away. "What came to me was that he was a human being, and I didn't want to see anybody die," Letson, host of podcast Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting, tells NPR. "In retrospect, it doesn't matter if he doesn't see my humanity, what matters to me is that I see his." Letson tells Slate that the unidentified protester had been with Joey Gibson of right-wing group Patriot Prayer during the mostly peaceful rally. But after Gibson began "antagonizing the black bloc," 20 to 30 others began chasing them. Gibson fled but his apparent companion "stumbled—or someone tripped him—and then four or five people surrounded him and began to kick and hit him," Letson says. When he noticed "a whole mass of people coming," Letson says he intervened in fear for the man's life. Though he was struck a few times, he'd do it all again, per Reveal. "I remember seeing the pictures of a young man being brutally beaten by these guys with poles [in Charlottesville], and when I saw that I thought, "Why didn't anybody step in?" he says.

Flat_1024_summary: – One of the world's leading investigators into the illegal trade in ivory and rhino horn was found stabbed to death in his home in Nairobi, Kenya, on Sunday. Police are investigating the circumstances but suspect it was a botched robbery. Martin, an American geographer, had spent decades risking his life to secretly photograph and document illegal sales of ivory and rhinoceros horn, traveling to China, Vietnam, and Laos to pose as a buyer and establish the details of black market prices. He first went to Kenya from the US in the 1970s when there was a surge in the number of elephants being killed for their ivory. His last report, Decline in the Legal Ivory Trade in China in Anticipation of a Ban, was published by conservation group Save the Elephants last year. His wife, who reported the death, said she found her husband's lifeless body after coming from a painstaking nature walk at around 4pm. "We have already questioned a gardener and a cook who are employed at the home," Nairobi DCI boss Ireri Kamwende said. (An anti-smuggling expert was recently murdered.)

reference: – WikiLeaks' founder has a "thermonuclear device" of unreleased files that he says he'll detonate if he's killed or brought to trial. Julian Assange has widely distributed an encrypted 1.3-gigabyte file containing the full versions of all the US documents the site has received, and his lawyer says the encryption key will be released if Assange is forced to appear before Swedish authorities on sexual assault charges or American authorities on treason charges, the Globe and Mail reports. WikiLeaks has "been subject to cyberattacks and censorship around the world and they need to protect themselves," lawyer Mark Stephens tells the Globe and Mail. Stephens says that if Assange is arrested or forced to appear before authorities, the release of the encryption key would give the tens of thousands of people who have downloaded the file access to the names, addresses, and details of the files. The US is looking into charges against Assange under the Espionage Act, but Assange would likely be protected under the Constitution's free-speech provisions because he didn't steal the documents or distribute them, notes the Christian Science Monitor.

Flat_1024_summary: – Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker put the National Guard on alert for Milwaukee today after a second night of violence following the police shooting of a black man. The unrest began Saturday night after the police officer who shot 23-year-old Sylville Smith didn't release his name from his body camera, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reports. The officer has been on paid administrative leave since the shooting, and Milwaukee's police chief says he is concerned for the officer's safety. "He has been staying with relatives out of town," the chief says. Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett says he has asked the Department of Justice to open an investigation into the shooting. "This is a very difficult time for the city of Milwaukee," Barrett says. "There's a lot of work that needs to be done to make sure that this does not spread to other parts of the city." "We'll be sharing information with the community so they are aware of what's going on and understand that things will be moving forward," says Milwaukee County Sheriff David A. Clarke Jr., who requested the Guard. "I'm not going to get caught like Ferguson and Baltimore." The police union called the violence a "terrorist-like" act and said the people who set fire to buildings and fired weapons "thugs" and "terrorists." reference: – One person was shot and a police officer was injured as unrest gripped Milwaukee on Sunday for a second night after the fatal shooting of a black suspect. Milwaukee Police Chief Edward Flynn says the officer who shot 23-year-old Sylville K. Smith is also black, and that officer is now staying with relatives out of town amid concerns for his safety, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reports. Flynn says Smith had a lengthy criminal record and was shot after fleeing a traffic stop on foot Saturday afternoon. The chief says Smith had a gun that he didn't drop when he was ordered to and, per body camera footage, "the individual did turn toward the officer with the firearm in his hand. You can't tell when the officer discharges his firearm." Flynn says the officer "certainly appeared to be within lawful bounds." Officials earlier said Smith was carrying a stolen handgun with 23 rounds of ammunition, Reuters reports. Before protests turned violent Sunday night, several of his sisters addressed a peaceful vigil. "My brother was no felon," said Kimberly Neal. "My brother was running for his life. He was shot in his back." Sherelle Smith, another sister, condemned the Saturday night violence that left businesses burned and four police officers injured, CNN reports. The National Guard was activated but not deployed during Sunday night's protest. Police say the person shot during Sunday's unrest is an 18-year-old man who was rushed to a hospital with serious injuries. His connection to the protests is unclear.
TreeSum_summary: – Wisconsin's National Guard has been activated in Milwaukee after a second night of violence following the police shooting of a black man. The unrest began Saturday night after the officer who shot 23-year-old Sylville Smith shot him multiple times while he was fleeing a traffic stop, and it continued Sunday night after a crowd threw rocks, bricks, and glass bottles at police and one man was shot in the arm and taken to a hospital in an armored vehicle, the AP reports. Milwaukee Police Chief Edward Flynn says the officer, who is not being identified, is "concerned for his safety" and has been "staying with relatives out of town" since the shooting. He says body camera footage from the officer will be released soon, but "you can't tell when the officer discharges his firearm." The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel identifies Smith as black and reports that he was shot as he allegedly turned toward the officer with a gun in his hand. "I'm not going to get caught like Ferguson and Baltimore," says Milwaukee County Sheriff David A. Clarke Jr. "It is who we have been led to believe." At least 17 people were arrested Saturday night and four police officers were injured in the violence.

Flat_1024_summary: – The movie version of Sara Gruen’s best-selling book Water for Elephants is getting mostly decent reviews: Betsy Sharkey, Los Angeles Times: It’s “good sound family entertainment, a safe PG-13 but not a dumb one, and it's a refreshing interlude before we hurtle into the summer blockbuster season.” Kyle Smith, New York Post: “The film's climax involves a series of dire events I will not describe ... but the fact that she does saves the film from dissolving entirely into melodrama.” Roger Ebert, Chicago Sun-Times: The film is “so bland that it made me long for The Greatest Show on Earth.”
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The movie version of Sara Gruen's best-seller, Water for Elephants, based on the true story of a traveling circus in the 1930s, stars Reese Witherspoon, Robert Pattinson, and Christoph Waltz, but critics aren't exactly enamored. Here's what they're saying: "Water for Elephants could have used some spritzes of 'National Velvet' or 'Lassie Come Home' sentimentality," writes Manohla Dargis in the New York Times. "The monotonous tone is established early on with Jacob’s plodding narration, which takes over after an introduction by a rheumy-eyed Hal Holbrook (wonderful, as always), playing the aged Jacob. Mr. Pattinson’s simplistic narration, unfortunately, affects the gee-whiz language of a grade-school reading book." "The movie displays its most disastrous choice when it makes the book’s climatic rampage seem perfunctory," writes Roger Ebert in the Chicago Sun-Times. "This sloppily directed scene, which ends almost as soon as it begins, leaves you feeling cheated out of a necessary cathartic release." The film's "romance" between Pattinson's Jacob and Witherspoon's Marlena "is nil. When they finally make love in a scene that is so ... it’s an old-fashioned movie, says Betsy Sharkey in the Los Angeles Times, "in an age of prefabricated special effects and obviously phony spectacle." But it's also "good sound family entertainment, a safe PG-13 but not a dumb one, and it is a refreshing interlude before we hurtle into the summer blockbuster season."

"Recently, Kanye let us in on his personal struggle. He is 53 million dollars in debt and it doesn't look like he's going to get Mark Zuckerberg's help that he desperately needs," Piatt writes. As for Zuckerberg—West specifically asked him, as well as Larry Page, to donate money to the Kanye cause when he went on his Twitter rant, and then went on to imply that he knows other tech giants who should help him. "All you dudes in San Fran play rap music in your homes but never help the real artists…," he tweeted, followed by, "All you guys had meetings with me and no one lifted a finger to help…." The Guardian did a little investigation into how many "tech guys" Kanye actually knows, and found that he really does have something of an ongoing relationship with Facebook and Apple; has had meetings with investors in Silicon Valley and even had some of them at one of his parties; has had interactions with an Instagram co-founder, the Dropbox chief executive, a co-founder of Rap Genius, and Elon Musk; and is good friends with venture capitalist Ben Horowitz. Flat_1024_summary: – A gunman opened fire at Los Angeles International Airport today, killing a TSA officer and wounding at least two other people, reports NBC News and the Los Angeles Times. The shooter was shot multiple times by airport police and is in critical condition, says LA Mayor Eric Garcetti. Authorities haven't speculated about a motive. The gunman walked into Terminal 3 about 9:20am local time and opened fire with a .223-caliber semiautomatic assault-style rifle, says a law enforcement official. He fired at least eight times. "We were just standing there in line, and somebody started shooting," says a witness. "Everyone dropped to the floor and started crawling along the ground." Tearful radio hosts say sorry to nurse's family in UK 
 
 SYDNEY — The Australian radio hosts who made a prank call to a London hospital treating Prince William's wife Kate tearfully told of their heartbreak Monday at hearing that a nurse had been found dead. 
 
 Mel Greig and Michael Christian from Sydney station 2Day FM have been in hiding and undergoing counselling since their hoax sparked global outrage following the apparent suicide of Jacintha Saldanha.

reference: – Australian DJs Michael Christian and Mel Greig have broken their silence on their royal prank call gone horribly wrong, reports the Guardian, tearfully telling an interviewer that they're "shattered, gutted, heartbroken" over the death of nurse Jacintha Saldanha. "No one could've imagined this to happen," Christian said. "Naturally, we're shattered. We're people, too." "There's not a minute that goes by that I don't think about what (Saldanha's) family is going through, and the thought that we may have contributed to it is gut-wrenching," says Greig. The DJs meant no harm, adds Christian: "At every single point it was innocent on our behalf." Innocent or not, Greig and Christian "will not return to the airwaves until further notice," says parent company Southern Cross Austereo, which has also axed their show, halted all prank calls, and nixed ads amid an internal review, CNN reports. But the station is doubling down on its decision to air the prank, saying that it had tried to contact King Edward VII's Hospital no fewer than five times to talk about the recording before airing it. "It is absolutely true to say that we actually did attempt to contact those people on multiple occasions," says Southern Cross' CEO. It's not clear if the hospital responded, notes the AFP, but it has mounted a withering assault against the station in the aftermath of Saldanha's death.
TreeSum_summary: – The Australian radio hosts behind last week's royal prank call have broken their silence for the first time since the apparent suicide of the nurse they tricked. "Unfortunately I remember that moment very well because I haven't stopped thinking about it since it happened," Mel Greig told Australia's Seven Network, according to the AFP. "And I remember my first question was, was she a mother?" In a separate interview with the Nine Network, Michael Christian added: "It came into my head that I just wanted to reach out to them (the family), give them a big hug and say sorry. I hope they're OK, I really do." The two also gave interviews to the Seven and Nine networks. The CEO of 2Day FM's parent company tells the Guardian that the station tried to contact King Edward VII Hospital on the phone before the call went to air. "We rang them to discuss what we had recorded. We attempted to contact them on no fewer than five times. We wanted to speak to them about it." The death of Jacintha Saldanha, the nurse who took the prank call, has been ruled a suicide.

Flat_1024_summary: – The mystery author behind O: A Presidential Novel, due out later this month, has “been in the room with Barack Obama” and has “spent years observing politics,” publisher Simon & Schuster says. The author “has a solid grasp of Obamaland, with the obvious characters like David Axelrod (Avi Samuelson) sketched clearly, and another character, who seems to be a composite of people I can guess at, in the role of a spurned but loyal Chicago Obama protege,” writes Michael Wolff in the Washington Post. But “its real calling card is the author's anonymity, and there's some fun to be had on those terms,” Wolff continues. “For one thing, the author has a real grasp of campaigns—but mostly as far as campaigns' relations with the press go, which suggests the author’s either a political reporter or a press staffer of some sort. The only other event to come close to a 7 was a 1957 accident at a fuel-processing plant (where spent nuclear fuel is recycled into new fuel) in Russia, in which an off-site release of radiation prompted preventive evacuations. “The INES rating itself is not an indicator of a daily phenomena but the assessment after careful consideration and calculation on the event that happened in the past,” says a spokesman for Japan’s Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency. The government also expanded the evacuation zone around Fukushima to include several towns within a 19-mile radius where residents had been told they could remain at home but were recommended to stay indoors. Flat_Overlap_summary: – A substance found in plastic bags could someday help treat everything from allergies to Parkinson's disease, according to a new study. Until now, a high-fibre diet was thought to help keep weight down by stimulating the release of appetite-suppressing hormones in the gut, but humans do not seem to show the same increase in these hormones that mice do. So Bell and his colleagues decided: If fiber-rich foods like cereal bars and chicory coffee make you feel full, it's because you've got an anti-appetite molecule in your gut that tells you to stop eating. The molecule, called acetate, is released when fiber is digested in thegut and is taken to the brain, where it triggers a series of chemical events that suppress hunger. As Live Science explains, previous research suggested the reason was that it takes longer to digest, keeping us satisfied for longer after we've stopped eating. But this new research shows for the first times that fiber actually triggers the release, which signals we're full.

 Not very long after James Watson finished his Nobel Prizewinning work on the structure of DNA in 1953, he started firing off some eyebrow-raising comments about his fellow man: that fat people don't get hired because they lack ambition; how sunlight (and darker skin) is the source of the "Latin lover" libido; what he found distasteful in the appearance of his female research collaborator, Rosalind Franklin.

reference: – One of the scientists who helped unfold the structure of DNA is putting his Nobel Prize on the auction block, and James Watson says it's because he's broke after being ostracized by the academic community over racist remarks he made seven years ago, the Atlantic reports. "No one really wants to admit I exist," he tells the Financial Times, labeling himself an "unperson." The remarks were made in a 2007 Sunday Times article, in which he admitted to feeling "inherently gloomy about the prospect of Africa [because] all our social policies are based on the fact that their intelligence is the same as ours—whereas all the testing says not really." He tacked on that even though some would say black people were as intelligent as whites, "people who have to deal with black employees find this not true." Those weren't the first incendiary statements he's made: As Laura Blue pointed out in a 2007 Time article, Watson has also said fat people don't get jobs because they lack ambition, that sun and dark skin creates a "Latin lover" libido, and that a female colleague widely credited with expediting the DNA discovery didn't dress well. But while Blue writes that it's "hard not to feel a little bit sorry" for Watson, whom she calls "less an arrogant bigot than an enthusiastic if misguided old man," Adam Rutherford says in the Guardian that "no one is interested in his racist, sexist views" and that "it turns out that just like DNA, people are messy, complex, and sometimes full of hideous errors." Meanwhile, his Nobel is expected to net between $2.5 million and $3.5 million when it's up for auction on Thursday, according to a Christie's statement. reference: – Donald Trump woke everyone from their pre-Christmas slumber Thursday with a tweet calling for a strengthened and expanded US nuclear arsenal. His tweet followed remarks made earlier by Vladimir Putin in which he called for his country's "need to strengthen the military potential of strategic nuclear forces," per Yahoo. On Friday, Trump doubled down on his previous remarks during what Politico calls an "off-air conversation" on MSNBC's Morning Joe. "Let it be an arms race … we will outmatch them at every pass and outlast them all," he said. (Politico notes some flip-flopping on nuclear issues, citing a March New York Times interview in which he said, "It's a very scary nuclear world. Biggest problem, to me, in the world, is nuclear, and proliferation.") Not in on his latest stance, apparently: his own team. Per a transcript posted by NBC's Katy Tur on Twitter, Trump's new White House counselor Kellyanne Conway told Rachel Maddow Thursday night "we're getting ahead of ourselves" when Maddow mentioned a "new nuclear arms race." And, per a tweet by CNN's David Wright, incoming White House press secretary Sean Spicer insisted on Today Friday that "there is not going to be" an arms race and that "we will all be just fine." A short time later on CNN's New Day, Spicer said the remarks Trump made to Morning Joes' Mika Brzezinski "was a private conversation. I was not privy to that," per Mediaite. Daniel Dale of the Toronto Star wonders: "Is there any point of quoting clarifications from Trump spokespeople? They've proven to be unreliable interpreters of him." One person shrugging off arms race chatter: Putin, who said Friday Trump's tweet was "nothing new," per Politico.

"Look, you should at least wait until you're president," he says. "But this is why—this kind of view that he—"Let it be an arms race. We will outmatch them at every pass. And outlast them all." Flat_1024_summary: – Yawn, you say? It's not because you're stressed or tired, but because your brain is cooling, according to a new study. Austrian researchers found that people yawn more in summer than winter when the temperature is around 20 degrees Fahrenheit, Science Daily reports. Yawning is believed to deliver a fresh supply of oxygen to the brain, but previous studies haven't been able to show an increase in blood oxygen levels after yawning. The new study compared the results of a similar study in Arizona, which is arid, to Vienna, Austria, where the air is a lot cooler. Researchers found that contagious yawning—in which people yawn while others do the same—dropped when temperatures were around 37 degrees Fahrenheit in Arizona's summer and around freezing in Vienna's winter. "While most research on contagious yawning emphasizes the influence of interpersonal and emotional-cognitive variables on its expression, this report adds to accumulating research suggesting that the underlying mechanism for yawning, both spontaneous and contagious forms, is involved in regulating brain temperature," the researchers write. "In turn, the cooling of the brain functions to improve arousal and mental efficiency. The spreading of this behavior via contagious yawning could therefore function to enhance overall group vigilance."

reference: – The drama of 2016's final moments continues to spill into 2017 in the form of an ongoing battle over just went wrong with Mariah Carey's New Year's Eve performance. Carey herself tweeted "S--- happens" to fans, alongside a GIF of her shaking her head, after an appearance on ABC's New Year's Rockin' Eve that included bungled renditions of "Emotion" and "We Belong Together" in which the Carey sang only small portions of the songs as a pre-recorded track played in the background. Carey's rep tells Billboard that the singer took the performance "very seriously," so much so that she rehearsed for three hours on the 30th and again at 3pm on the big night, with no sound issues surfacing on either occasion. "A shame that production set her up to fail," rep Nicole Perna concludes. Carey's manager Stella Bulochnikov tells Billboard stage managers were alerted that the "in-ears" weren't working four minutes before showtime; reassurances the ear pieces would function once live were bogus so Carey "pulled them out but could not hear the music over the crowd." Bulochnikov suggests production "just want[ed] eyeballs at any expense." Dick Clark Productions swung back in a statement released to the AP Sunday night: "To suggest that dcp (Dick Clark Productions) ... would ever intentionally compromise the success of any artist is defamatory, outrageous, and frankly absurd." It said its initial investigation found no evidence of technical errors. An unnamed production source counters Perna's rehearsal claims, saying Carey used a body double during Saturday's rehearsal. (Josh Groban tweeted, then deleted, a diss about Carey.)
TreeSum_summary: – Mariah Carey's Times Square performance on New Year's Eve was supposed to be a triumphant start to 2017. Instead, the singer flubbed two of her biggest hits—"Emotions" and "We Belong Together," which she couldn't hear through her in-ear monitors—and the audience audibly groaned as she tried to sing along. Afterward, she tweeted, "Shit happens. Have a happy and healthy new year everybody! Here's to making more headlines in 2017"—but that wasn't good enough for Dick Clark Productions, which issued a statement to Billboard saying, "As the premier producer of live television events for nearly 50 years, we pride ourselves on our reputation and long-standing relationships with artists. To suggest that dcp, as producer of music shows ... would ever intentionally compromise the success of any artist is defamatory, outrageous and frankly absurd." A production source tells Billboard that Carey "had ample time to rehearse and chose not to," but a rep for the singer says she was set up by producers. "They told her it would be fine once she was on stage," the rep says. "However, that was not the case and they were again told that her ear piece was not working. Instead of endeavoring to fix the issue so that Mariah could perform, they went live." A recording producer tells the New York Times, "Every monitor and in- ear device worked perfectly. I can't comment beyond that and don't know what her non-technical issue may be." Meanwhile, fellow singer Josh Groban has deleted his thoughts: "Deleted "because it's a joke about the fact that it was a joke.

Flat_1024_summary: – The brutal cold snaps that have been plaguing much of the northern hemisphere this winter are the result of a distinct lack of Arctic air, experts tell the AP. "We basically have seen just a big outbreak of arctic air" over populated areas of the Northern Hemisphere. "The Arctic air has really turned itself loose on us." The zigzag pattern that has kept Arctic air confined to the north and south is beginning to weaken, but experts expect more typical winter weather across North America early next week. In fact, Beijing had its coldest morning in almost 40 years and its biggest snowfall since 1951. Britain is suffering through its longest cold snap since 1981, and freezing weather is gripping the Deep South, including Florida's orange groves and beaches. "Whatever happened to global warming? Such weather doesn't seem to fit with warnings from scientists that the Earth is warming because of greenhouse gases," writes Andrew Revkin in the Telegraph. "It seems to be far less about genuine scientific scepticism and more about confirmation bias of a politicised world view."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Just when you thought climate change skeptics couldn't get any sillier, a pair of British columnists have jumped on the bandwagon. In Sunday's Telegraph and Daily Mail, Christopher Booker and Richard North wrote that Britain's official weather forecasting service, the Met Office, has been "hijacked" by climate change deniers. "If this story were true, it would be huge," writes Andrew Revkin in the Guardian. "It would also be fantastically stupid, as forecasts can always be checked against delivery. It is as predictable a feature of the British winter as log fires and roasting chestnuts: a national outpouring of idiocy every time some snow falls." In the Express today, Martyn Brown wrote that "climate experts are still trying to claim the world is growing warmer. ... Other areas including Alaska, Canada and the Mediterranean were warmer than usual." Revkin notes that the Express "would have us return to the days in which the future course of human affairs could be predicted by solar eclipses and the appearance of comets."

reference: – A 21-year-old Baltimore County man died in the hospital three days after being repeatedly punched by officers responding to his 911 call, the Guardian reports. According to the Baltimore Sun, Tawon Boyd called 911 early last Sunday. He told officers his girlfriend, Deona Styron, had "got him intoxicated and is secretly recording him." Boyd's grandmother, Linda Burch, says Boyd "was acting...like he was on something." Police noted he seemed "confused and paranoid," and it was clear he "needed to be taken to the hospital." But Boyd started trying to get into police cars and resisted attempts to restrain him, resulting in minor injuries to three officers. Based on the police report, it doesn't appear Boyd was trying to hurt the officers. He was holding onto one of the officer's shirts when the officer punched him twice in the face. At that point, the family's lawyer, Latoya Francis-Williams, says Boyd was "literally attacked" by officers. She says they got on top of him and "really started wailing." “I kept telling them stop before they hurt him,” Burch tells the Sun. “They told me to go across the street before they lock me up.” WBAL reports a medic gave Boyd haloperidol, an antipsychotic drug, to calm him down. An autopsy is now looking into whether the drug played a role in Boyd's death Wednesday from heart and kidney failure. Boyd's family is accusing the police of using too much force. “Mr. Boyd was in need of medical attention, and the police responded with violence,” Francis-Williams tells the Sun.
TreeSum_summary: – The family of a homeless man who died after a "disturbing" encounter with Baltimore police is suing the city, the police department, and two officers, the Baltimore Sun reports. Tawon Boyd, 21, called 911 himself Friday because he was feeling "confused and paranoid" and needed an ambulance. According to the police report, Boyd was "under the influence of a narcotic and/or suffering" and "needed to be taken to the hospital for emergency evaluation." But Boyd's lawyer, Latoya Francis-Williams, says police were actually there to get him to a health facility. The incident report states officers arrived to find Boyd trying to get into two police cars and running to a neighbor's house, where he banged on the door and said, "Help! Call the police!" Francis- Williams says Boyd was not threatening officers at the time. He was "literally attacked," she says. "And by attacked, I mean the witness is describing that he struck many times and struck to the ground." The report states an officer "really started wailing on Mr. Boyd, meaning Mr Boyd was on the ground in a prone position and Bowman sat on him, almost straddled his back, and put his left arm under Boyd’s neck and pulled his head up in a choking fashion." Boyd went limp after one officer hit him in the face and another choked him, his grandmother says. He died Wednesday, three days after the incident. An autopsy hasn't been released.

Flat_1024_summary: – Bill Maher has a request for America: "Please Stop Apologizing." In a New York Times op-ed, the HBO politico-celebrity calls for an end to politicians' demands for apologies from those who have supposedly offended them—and to the equally insincere apologies they so often elicit. Exhibit A, according to Maher, is the recent flap over actor Robert De Niro's quip: "Callista Gingrich. Karen Santorum. Ann Romney. Now do you really think our country is ready for a white first lady?" The first lady's press secretary declared the joke "inappropriate," and De Niro said his remarks were "not meant to offend." So, as these things go, even if the terrible damage can never be undone, at least the healing can begin. And we can move on to the next time we choose sides and pretend to be outraged about nothing. When did we get it in our heads that we have the right to never hear anything we don’t like? In the last year, we’ve been shocked and appalled by the unbelievable insensitivity of Nike shoes, the Fighting Sioux, Hank Williams Jr., Cee Lo Green, Ashton Kutcher, Tracy Morgan, Don Imus, Kirk Cameron, Gilbert Gottfried, and more.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Bill Maher is in hot water again, this time over a joke he made on his HBO show about President Obama's birth certificate. On last night's Real Time With Bill Maher, Maher noted that the president's signature on the document is a "labyrinth," and then added, "I don't know if it's a forgery, but it is a birth certificate." The reaction has been swift, with the New York Times publishing an open letter to Maher in which it notes that "incivility, like any other issue, is subject to partisan manipulation" and calls for "higher standards, even from those who straddle the divide between politics and entertainment." The Times also notes that Maher recently donated $1 million to a pro-Obama super PAC. But Maher isn't buying it. "When did we get it in our heads that we have the right to never hear anything we don’t like?" he asks in a New York Post op-ed. "In the last year, we’ve been shocked and appalled by the unbelievable insensitivity of Nike shoes, the Fighting Sioux, Hank Williams Jr., Cee Lo Green, Ashton Kutcher, Tracy Morgan, Don Imus, Kirk Cameron, Gilbert Gottfried, etc.?"

The regime's claim that rebels used chlorine gas is "highly unlikely," as it would have destroyed evidence of the attack and killed hundreds of people. Meanwhile, John Kerry today called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a "moral obscenity" that "cannot go unanswered," but he stopped short of directly accusing Assad's government of carrying out the attack. "We know that the Syrian regime maintains custody of these chemical weapons," Kerry said, but the regime "has the capacity to do this with rockets." He added that the US has "high confidence" that chemical weapons were used in Moadamiyet al-Sham, but it is "determined to clear the opposition from those very places where the attacks took place." The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting today to address Syria's civil war, the AP reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – The UPS cargo plane that crashed in Alabama earlier this week, killing both pilots, was descending at an unusually high rate 16 seconds before impact, according to a flight recorder. The first of two warnings was made to the cockpit, either from trees or the ground, the AP reports. Investigators haven't determined the cause of the crash, but they're looking into whether the captain should have tried to land on the shorter of the two runways at Birmingham Shuttlesworth International Airport, the Wall Street Journal reports. With a large hill and trees at one end, the runway lacks the electronics for a full instrument landing. That forces pilots to make key judgments about altitude while aiming a descending aircraft at a runway that's 5,000 feet shorter than the airport's main runway, which was closed for maintenance work at the time of the accident. "When I heard they were using Runway 18 it caught my attention because of that hill," says a retired United Airlines captain. "It's sad, but it didn't surprise me."

reference: – The pilots killed in this week's crash of a UPS plane in Birmingham got two automated warnings that they were coming in too low, says the NTSB. But they didn't have much time to process them—the first came 7 seconds before impact, reports the Wall Street Journal. Three seconds after the first "sink rate" alarm sounded in the cockpit, one of the two pilots said the runway was in sight, but the plane soon clipped power wires and slammed into a hill. A veteran pilot was at the controls: Cerea Beal had 8,600 flying hours with UPS—3,000 alone in A300 cargo planes, the type that went down—and before that served as a Maine helicopter pilot. But it's unclear whether he had ever landed at this particular runway before at Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International Airport. Authorities say it's tricky because it's not equipped with the electronics for a full instrument landing and thus requires a visual approach. The crash occurred in the pre-dawn dark, while it was raining. "When I heard they were using Runway 18, it caught my attention because of that hill," a commercial pilot tells AP. "It's sad, but it didn't surprise me." A longer runway at the airport with a more modern landing system had been closed for maintenance. The co-pilot was previously identified as 37-year-old Shanda Fanning.
TreeSum_summary: – The pilot of a UPS plane that crashed in Alabama last week, killing three, tried to land on the airport's longer main runway but failed, according to the National Transportation Safety Board. The NTSB says the pilot, who was landing on a runway that is 5,000 feet shorter than the main runway, reported that he couldn't reach his destination because of bad weather. The board says it has found no evidence of engine failure before the crash, and the runway was closed for maintenance at the time of the crash. The UPS pilot told air traffic controllers that he was going to try to reach Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International Airport from Louisville, Ky., but he "realized he wasn't going to be able to," says the NTSB's Robert Sumwalt. He said the plane hit a tree and sucked in wood before crashing into a hill less than a mile from the end of the shorter runway. A former commercial pilot tells the AP that some pilots avoid landing on that runway when possible. "When I heard they were using Runway 18 it caught my attention because of that hill," he says. "It's sad, but it didn't surprise me." Click for more on the UPS crash.

Flat_1024_summary: – A British businessman has spent the past 27 years in a Florida prison for a double murder he says he didn't commit. Krishna "Kris" Maharaj, 75, says Pablo Escobar ordered the 1986 killings of his business partner, Derrick Moo Young, and Young's 23-year-old son, Duane, in a Miami hotel, CNN reports. Maharaj says he was framed because the Moo Youngs had cheated him out of more than $400,000, and because police framed him to cover up the Medellin drug cartel's involvement in the killings. At an evidentiary hearing next week, Maharaj's lawyers plan to call 53 witnesses—including six who say Maharaj was 30 miles away at the time of the murders—and 498 documents to prove his innocence. "Kris Maharaj is so patently innocent that it is unimaginable to me that the state of Florida does not let him go," the author of a book on the case tells the Guardian. "It is a very sad day when the government desperately wants to keep the wrong person in prison, such that they will not even investigate who the real killers are." Maharaj was sentenced to life in prison in 2002 after his lawyers successfully argued that new witnesses could testify that the killings were ordered by Escobar, and that Maharaj was framed. But Florida state attorneys say there's no evidence to back up the claims. "None have any first hand knowledge, provide no admissible testimony or evidence, and only attempt to further the nonsensical and wholly speculative theories of the defense," wrote prosecutors in a court filing.

reference: – Paul Ryan evoked boos and jeers from an audience of retirees in New Orleans today when he promised to repeal ObamaCare—but he continued his argument apparently unfazed, Raw Story reports. "The first step to a stronger Medicare is to repeal ObamaCare," said Ryan at a meeting of the American Association of Retired Persons, where people reacted by booing and shouting, "No!" Ryan said he "had a feeling there would be mixed reaction,” and went on to claim that ObamaCare would drain Medicare of $716 billion and put seniors at risk. But that only elicited more boos and cries. On a happier note, he earned applause when he talked about his family and mentioned that his 78-year-old mother, Betty Douglas, was in attendance, the Washington Post reports. Ryan's speech was round two of a debate that began earlier in the day when President Obama addressed the crowd by video, reports CNN. "Contrary to what you've heard and what you may hear from subsequent speakers, ObamaCare actually strengthened Medicare," said Obama, who called the $716-billion-cut claim "simply untrue."

The majority of his income came from investments, according to a blog post from the trustee of Romney's blind trust. The Romneys gave just over $4 million to charity. In addition, the Romney campaign said his tax filings from 1990 to 2009 show that he and his wife paid 100% of the federal and state income taxes they owed and that their overall average annual effective federal tax rate was 20.2%. Obama deputy campaign manager Stephanie Cutter said in a statement the disclosure "continues to mask Romney’s true wealth" and income from the private equity firm he once led, leaving the American people in the dark about critical details of his finances.

The silt is a "remnant of the verdant tundra that covered Greenland before it was entombed in ice," according to a study published today in Science. The discovery was made 20 years ago, during a deep-drilling project to reach the bedrock beneath Summit. The 10-foot-long drill hole was archived at the National Ice Core Laboratory in Denver, Colo., but until now, no one had examined the dirt at the bottom of the drill hole. "I was asking a really different question than people who look at ice cores," says lead study author Paul Bierman. "There was a really stable landscape on Greenland before the icesheet came. This landscape has been preserved from beyond the dawn of humankind." Pollen and plant DNA buried in the seafloor offshore of Greenland also suggest the island once had tundra and forest, similar to today's high Arctic. "Now we know that it’s unlikely the ice sheet has disappeared for significant periods of time in the last 3 million years, at least at—'A refrigerator that’s preserved this antique landscape.'"

reference: – The family of one of four missing young men in Pennsylvania got the news they were dreading Wednesday night when authorities announced that the body of 19-year-old Dean Finocchiaro had been found in a deep grave on a suburban Philadelphia farm. District Attorney Matthew Weintraub said the body was found in a "common grave" more than 12 feet deep, though he didn't say whether the other remains found belong to the three other men who vanished last week, the Washington Post reports. The farm belongs to the family of Cosmo DiNardo, a "person of interest" in the case who was arrested Wednesday for stealing a car belonging to one of the missing men, the New York Times reports. DiNardo, 20, was bailed out by his father late Tuesday after being arrested on a weapons charge from earlier this year. Bail on the new charges has been set at $5 million. "We bought ourselves a little bit of time" with the stolen car charge, Weintraub told reporters early Thursday, adding that homicide charges are being seriously looked at. Flat_1024_summary: – If you've ever dreamed of competing in a triathlon, you're out of luck. Researchers looked at the mortality records of nearly 10,000 athletes who competed in the Olympic Games between 1896 and 1936, and found that those who engaged in cycling and rowing (high cardiovascular intensity) "had no added survival benefit compared with playing golf or cricket" (low cardiovascular intensity), the Wall Street Journal reports. "During high intensive exercise the human body has to deal with all kinds of micro traumata," says one of the study authors. "Over time, this will result in an accumulation of damage, which can be explained as a form of aging." The study doesn't prove that triathlons are bad for you, just that they don't offer the same longevity benefits as playing golf, the Journal notes. "The results of this study should not be interpreted to mean that Olympic athletes should give up exercise altogether," the study's lead author tells the New York Times. "Rather, they should consider increasing their intensity if they want to reduce their mortality risk." The researchers theorize that the lower mortality risk may be due to "specific social and psychometric characteristics," such as a person's risk of injury. But it's also possible that "high intensity exercise brings a survival benefit or an increased mortality risk for athletes remains to be elucidated," the researchers write. The study also excluded 2,162 athletes who weren't in the study and 7534 athletes born after 1910.

Flat_1024_summary: – If you've ever wondered who your mom's favorite is, Purdue University researchers have some bad news: You may be more likely to suffer from depression, Medical News Today reports. "Adult children who reported that they were most emotionally close to their mothers also reported higher depressive symptoms," the researchers write in the Journal of Gerontology: Social Sciences. "Depressive symptoms were also higher when respondents identified themselves as being the children with whom their mothers had the greatest conflict, and in whom the mothers were most disappointed." The researchers looked at data from 725 adult children in 309 families in which mothers were between the ages of 65 and 75 when the study began in 2001. They found the highest reports of depressive symptoms came from children who believed they were emotionally closer to their mother than their siblings and those who thought they were the sibling their mother was most disappointed in. "What we found suggests that the black offspring were particularly distressed when they, as opposed to their siblings, were the children in whom mothers weremost disappointed," says one of the researchers. The researchers plan to investigate whether similar results arise from studying adult children's perceptions of favoritism and disfavoritism from fathers.

reference: – Dodgers third-baseman Juan Uribe might want to remember a baseball fundamental: Keep your eye on the ball. Yesterday's game against the Tampa Bay Rays brings us a seemingly innocuous play, notes USA Today, in which Uribe made it to third base on a sac fly. TreeSum_summary: – President Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital "is a victory for the people of Israel," Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Friday. Flat_1024_summary: – Longtime Alcoholics Anonymous members may have an "innate ability to use the AA experience—prayer in this case—to minimize the effect of alcohol triggers in producing craving," says senior author Marc Galanter of NYU Langone Medical Center. In a study published in the American Journal of Drug and Alcohol Abuse, researchers recruited 20 long-term AA members who reported no cravings for alcohol during the week preceding testing. The participants were placed in an MRI scanner and then shown either pictures of alcoholic drinks or people drinking to simulate drinking behavior in a laboratory setting. The pictures were presented twice: first after asking the participant to read neutral material from a newspaper, and again after the participant recited an AA prayer promoting abstinence from alcohol to represent the impact of AA. All research subjects reported some degree of craving for alcohol after viewing the images, and less craving after reciting anAA prayer. MRI data revealed that there were changes in parts of the prefrontal cortex, the region of the brain that controls attention, and in brain sites responsible for control of emotion and the semantic reappraisal of emotion, which represents the different ways a people understand situations based on their perspectives. "This finding suggests that there appears to be an emotional" response, says Galanter.

Peter Travers, Rolling Stone: "A director's true gift is to animate these figures, bring them to life. This engrossing, nearly enthralling movie straddles multiple worlds as well: Susie's bright innocence, Mr. Harvey's meticulous depravity and Jack's ferocious determination to sleuth his daughter's fate."

Flat_1024_summary: – About half of Earth's water is older than the sun—and that's a good thing, because it suggests we're not alone. In a study published Thursday in Science, researchers found that heavy hydrogen levels on Earth are higher than they would have been in the protoplanetary disk, the same band of space dust around which the sun was formed, the Washington Post reports. That means some of our water must have predate the sun, when heavy hydrogen was in abundance. So, if water can survive a star's birthing process, and if other solar systems in the universe formed much like ours did, that means that water might be a common ingredient in the making of other planets far from our own. "By identifying the ancient heritage of Earth’s water, we can see that the way in which our solar system was formed will not be unique, and that exoplanets will form in environments with abundant water," a researcher says in a statement. "Consequently," he adds, "it raises the possibility that some exoplanets could house the right conditions, and water resources, for life to evolve." Last spring, scientists announced that there could be up to 11 billion exoplanets—planets outside or solar system—that are capable of supporting life.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Vatican is home to about 800 people—and they drink a lot of wine, the Independent reports. According to the latest statistics from the Wine Institute, the Vatican's residents consume an average of 105 bottles of wine a year, more than the average person in any other country and more than three times the amount consumed in the UK. That's around twice the amount drunk by the average French or Italian person, and around three times that of the average Catholic in the US. The National Catholic Reporter notes that Vatican residents are more likely to be old, male, highly educated, and eat in larger groups, all factors that can contribute to greater wine consumption.
