Flat_1024_summary: – Nestle may have taken more than 32 million gallons of water from a national forest in California last year—but it only had the right to do so for about 8.5 million gallons, according to a state investigation. The California State Water Resources Control Board found that the company didn't have the proper permits to withdraw the water from Mount Adams National Forest in the midst of a drought, the Los Angeles Times reports. Nestle claims it inherited rights to the water in the forest more than a century ago and uses it in its Arrowhead Mountain Spring Water. "I feel like it's a victory," Mount Adams Supervisor Cheryl Frye tells the Desert Sun. The investigation was prompted by complaints from residents who said Nestle was depleting the forest's water supply and endangering wildlife. The US Forest Service was also sued by environmental and public interest groups who alleged the company was allowed to operate its Strawberry Canyon pipeline on a permit that expired in 1988.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Nestle may have to stop taking millions of gallons of water from Southern California's San Bernardino National Forest after state regulators concluded it lacks valid permits, the AP reports. The State Water Resources Control Board notified the company on Wednesday that an investigation concluded it doesn't have proper rights to about three-quarters of the water it withdraws for bottling. "A significant portion of the Water currently diverted by Nestle appears to be diverted without a valid basis of right," the report concluded. The board left open the possibility that Nestle could make a valid claim to extract more water from the forest land. Nestle Waters North America was urged to cut back its water withdrawals unless it can show it has valid water rights to its current sources or to additional groundwater. The company, a division of the Swiss food giant, also was given 60 days to submit an interim compliance plan. Nestle said it was pleased that the report reaffirms that it holds valid rights to "a significant amount" of water. "We will continue to operate lawfully according to these existing rights and will comply fully with California law," Nestle added in a statement. The report also was applauded by activists who have fought to turn off Nestle's tap in the forest.

reference: – James Tumblin's 300,000-piece collection of Gone With the Wind memorabilia started with a single gray dress with black appliques that lay crumpled on the floor of the Western Costume Company in Los Angeles in the 1960s. "A docent told me not to bother to pick it up, because they were throwing it away," Tumblin, who once ran the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios, told the Telegraph last month. But "I had noticed there was a printed label saying Selznick International Pictures, and 'Scarlett production dress' was written in ink," he said. "I asked if he would sell it to me." He ended up paying just $20 for the costume, worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in four scenes of the 1939 film—an incredible bargain considering the dress sold at auction on Saturday for $137,000. The outfit—really a jacket and skirt ensemble—was actually pale blue during filming. But some of the 150 Gone With the Wind pieces sold by Heritage Auctions this weekend remain in pristine condition, including a gray wool suit Clark Gable wore when he kicked down Scarlett O'Hara's boudoir door as Rhett Butler, CNN reports; it sold for $55,000. A straw hat worn by Leigh fetched $52,500, while a black bonnet donned by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland's character Melanie Wilkes sold for $30,000, Reuters reports. Tumblin seems happy to have been able to offer up his pieces, many of which have toured the country. "I am really looking forward to walking through a museum and seeing something that I once owned," he said. He still maintains the largest private collection of Gone With the Wind memorabilia, which includes Leigh's Oscar. (The film almost didn't make it to the screen.)
TreeSum_summary: – A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as she played Scarlett O'Hara in Gone With the Wind fetched $137,000 at auction on Saturday, CNN reports. That's a pretty healthy profit for the collector who bought the outfit decades ago for just $20 as it was on the verge of being tossed out. James Tumblin, who used to work at Universal Studios, says he came across the dress while doing research at a costume company in the early 1960s. "I saw this dress on the floor and a docent told me not to bother to pick it up, because they were throwing it away," he says, per the Telegraph. Tumblin asked if he could sell it and was told to keep it. He bought it for $20 after noticing a label on the back that said Selznick International Pictures and "Scarlett production dress" was written in ink. Other standout items included a straw hat worn by Leigh in a number of scenes in the movie and a gray wool suit worn by Clark Gable as his character, Rhett Butler. The outfit, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett O’Hara encounters Rhett Butler and when she gets attacked in the shanty town. When Leigh wore it in the film, it was slate blue-gray. Over the years, it's faded to light gray. But that didn't deter the winning bidder at the auction. "Gone with the Wind is in my all time top 10 films I would watch if I was stranded on a desert island with a generator," Tumblin says.

Flat_1024_summary: – It's been a half-century since Vivian and Ron Joseph finished fourth in pairs figure skating at the 1964 Innsbruck Olympics, but they've always believed they were bronze medalists—until now. The Josephs had the medals to prove it, but records from the International Olympic Committee and US Figure Skating didn't show them as such, the Chicago Tribune reports. "I never talked about that Olympic medal for fear someone would say it wasn't true," Vivian, 66, says. "It's very strange, isn't it. This is typical of the politics of sport." The West German Olympic Committee was able to get the team's medals back in 1987, and some record books at the time listed the Germans as sole silver medalists. Other records listed them as co-silver medalists with Canadians Debbi Wilkes and Guy Revell. "This is great. But this is how many years later, and after how many books have been printed? How many years do you not have to cringe over this?" Vivian Joseph tells the Tribune.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – It's been a half-century since Vivian and Ron Joseph finished fourth in pairs figure skating at the 1964 Innsbruck Olympics, but they always thought they were bronze medalists—until now. The International Olympic Committee has finally confirmed that the Josephs are the new co-silver medalists, with Canada and West Germany sharing the silver, the New York Times reports. "This is great. But this is how many years later, and after how many books have been printed? How many years do you not have to cringe over this?" Vivian, 66, tells the Chicago Tribune. "I am prouder of the world silver medal and the US title we won in 1965." The Josephs, who grew up in Chicago, had the medals to prove it until a few years ago, when a friend told them at a party that IOC and US Figure Skating records didn't list them as medalists. "After that, I never talked about that Olympic medal for fear someone would say it wasn't true," Vivian says. "It's very strange, isn't it. This is typical of the politics of sport." The problem is that the West German team that finished second in the event, Marika Kilius and Hans Kilius, had signed a contract to appear in a professional ice show before the Games—a violation of Olympic rules. The West Germans returned their medals, and the IOC awarded the bronze to Canada.

Flat_1024_summary: – Morocco's Khizanat al-Qarawiyyin library, believed to be the oldest library in the world, is set to reopen after a $10 million, five-year restoration. The library, located in the old medina of Fez, was founded in 859 by a woman named Fatima al-Fihri, the daughter of a wealthy Tunisian merchant. It was also home to the world's oldest university, according to Atlas Obscura, and the oldest copy of the Qur'an, written in the Kufic script on camel skin. "The library's value is not simply to preserve it for tourists, but that it is functioning," architect Aziza Chaouni tells the Guardian. "I would like my kids to be able to see this heritage." To that end, engineers worked to determine the structural integrity of the library, restoring some of the woodwork but all the while trying to preserve as much of it as possible. They also installed a new chandelier in the reading room, a high-ceiling hall with polished wooden desks and chairs, and intricate reliefs on its columns. King Mohammad VI inspected the work in June and is expected to inaugurate the reopening before 2017.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Mediterranean diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish, nuts, olive oil, and legumes can help you live longer, according to a new study. Researchers found that middle-aged women who followed the diet had longer leukocyte telomeres, the caps on the ends of chromosomes that protect cells from damage, the New York Times reports. Shorter telomeres are associated with age-related chronic diseases. "Based on our data, a three-point change in the adherence score is equivalent to 4.5 years of aging, a difference comparable to that between smokers and nonsmokers," says the lead author of the study from Harvard Medical School. Researchers aren't sure why the diet is associated with telomere length, but they suspect it has something to do with "a potential biologic mechanism behind the well known anti-aging effects of the diet," according to the study. The diet was linked to lower all-cause mortality, reduced incidence of major cardiovascular disease, and greater health and wellbeing in people. "These results reinforce our advice that eating a balanced and healthy diet can reduce your risk of developing heart disease," says a doctor with the British Heart Foundation.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The Mediterranean diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish, nuts, olive oil, and plenty of sleep may help keep you younger than your years. So say researchers out of Boston in the British Medical Journal after tracking the health of nearly 5,000 women over more than a decade. "These results reinforce our advice that eating a balanced and healthy diet can reduce your risk of developing heart disease," says a spokesman for the British Heart Foundation, which notes that no single dietary component of the diet is associated with a longer life. The study, published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology, looked at more than 46,000 women between the ages of 30 and 55 who completed a food frequency questionnaire every four years between 1980 and 1990. Researchers found that people who ate a diet high in vegetables, fruits, Nuts, Fish, and olive oil had a 30% lower risk of dying from any cause compared to those who consumed the most calories. "This is the first study to show that the whole Mediterranean diet isassociated with a reduced risk of death from all causes," the study's lead author says in a press release.

A black man in his 30s or 40s, weighing about 250 pounds, was spotted by cameras during three of the robberies, reports NBC News. The FBI says both suspects "are considered armed and dangerous."
TreeSum_summary: – The FBI is offering a $20,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of two men suspected in a string of armed robberies of jewelry stores in the South. The agency says the men have robbed six Jared Vaults in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee, and North Carolina since April, ABC News reports. According to the FBI, one suspect is a white woman in her 20s or 30s, 5-foot-8, and 130 pounds, and the other is a black man in his 30s or 40s, 6 feet, and 250 pounds. They're believed to be responsible for at least three of the heists. In the most recent heist, a woman armed with a gun robbed a Jared Vault in Mebane, NC, on Monday morning. Police say she forced two workers into a back room at gunpoint, zip-tied their hands, and then piled jewelry from the cases into a shopping bag. "Both suspects are considered armed and dangerous," the FBI said in a statement. Authorities say the woman, who weighs about 120 pounds, may be the same one responsible for some other robberies. In those robberies, the woman showed a gun and tied up employees before stealing an undisclosed amount of jewelry. In other robberies, she forced employees into the back room before tying them up.

reference: – A nonprofit group is throwing in $10,000 to sweeten the deal for potential voters in Philadelphia for whom the joy of taking part in democracy might not be enough. Voter turnout in the city has been declining for a long time and sank to just 27% in a mayoral primary this May, according to the Philadelphia Citizen, which is offering the prize in its "2015 Philadelphia Municipal Election Voting Lottery." The group says it will randomly select one of Philadelphia's 1,686 voting divisions when the city votes in local elections on Nov. 3, and will hand a $10,000 check to the first voter who emerges at a selected time, the Philadelphia Inquirer reports. The Citizen says the funds will come from the Pamela and Ajay Raju Foundation civic group—and the giveaway is completely legal. On its website, the Citizen, which was co-founded by former Philadelphia Daily News editor Larry Platt, admits that the plan is "sorta icky"—and that a similar giveaway in a Los Angeles school district was condemned as a "superficial pseudo-solution" to civic malaise—but says "desperate times call for desperate measures," and the lottery isn't the only scheme underway to try to boost voter turnout. "It's kind of a cockamamie scheme," Platt tells the Daily News. "I want to give away money to see if we can get people to vote." (Low turnout isn't just a Philadelphia problem: The "abysmally low" turnout nationwide last year was the worst since World War II.)
TreeSum_summary: – "We could, as usual, stand back and wring our hands. Instead, we at the Citizen have decided it's time for action. That's why we launched the 2015 Philadelphia Municipal Election Voting Lottery," writes Philadelphia Citizen editor-in-chief Larry Platt. "Let me repeat that: One voter. Randomly selected. Taking home $10,000, courtesy of the Pamela and Ajay Raju Foundation. Before you ask: Yes, this is legal. And no: We are not endorsing anyone, or making any money off of this ourselves. We’re doing this for one reason alone: To bring more people to the polls, in any way that gets them there." Voting locations for all 1,686 voting divisions will be fed into a computer program that chooses one at random, and organizers will drive to that polling place on Election Day and wait for the first voter to show up, reports the Philadelphia Inquirer. "My first gut instinct was, 'Do we really need to pay to get voter participation?' It seemed a bit crass," says Ajay Raju, the law firm's chairman and CEO who is donating the money. "But if it can spark a conversation ... I always have an excuse for not voting." The Los Angeles Times calls the lottery "the most superficial pseudo-solution to a very real problem in Los Angeles, which is the pervasive civic malaise that prevents so many eligible voters from feeling truly engaged." But turnout increased from 46% to 80% among those who knew about the possibility of winning $25,000 in May.

Flat_1024_summary: – An Oklahoma woman led police on a high-speed chase this week because she wanted to be booked into a different county jail. Luz Avilla, 34, pulled over just a few miles from the county line and told an officer why she didn't pull over. "Apparently the driver did not want to go to jail in Grady County," Shannon McClain of the Chickasha Police tells News 9. "She wanted to goto jail in Caddo County was her explanation as to why she did not pull over." Dash cam video shows Avilla's car traveling between 5 and 10 miles over the speed limit before she pulls over. McClain says the officer yelled at her to get out of the car, but she refused. He pulled out his gun and called for backup. "Instead of pulling over, the driver accelerated to speeds approximately 90 to 100 miles per hour," McClain tells KFOR. "When you're doing 90 miles an hour andyou're weaving all over the road, just the slightest movements by those other vehicles could be catastrophe." Avilla has been charged with DUI and evading police.

Flat_1024_summary: – "Perhaps I am going to lose fame, but I accept it, I assume it." That's how French chef Sébastien Bras describes his request to have his restaurant, Le Suquet, stripped of its three Michelin stars, which it's held for nearly 20 years. Bras, 46, says he's tired of the pressure that comes with being one of France's most celebrated chefs and wants to "redefined what is essential" in order to "give a new meaning to my life." In a Facebook video, he says he wants to be left out of the 2018 edition of the Michelin guide without "justifying his choice by a change in (restaurant) concept or closing the business." Bras—who says his restaurant's three stars have been "spellbinding"—adds he'll continue to cook good food "without wondering whether my creations will appeal to Michelin's inspectors." The Guardian reports this is the first time a chef has asked not to have a restaurant featured in the guide, but Bras isn't the first to make such a request. In 2005, Paris restaurateur Alain Senderens—one of the pioneers of nouvelle cuisine—shocked the culinary world by giving back his three stars, claiming diners were turned.

Flat_1024_summary: – Reports of an explosion at Iran's Fordow nuclear site are "Western propaganda ahead of nuclear negotiations to influence their process and outcome," an Iranian official said last night. The 300-foot-deep bunker is immune to air strikes or bunker bombs, Reuters notes, and Tehran has repeatedly blamed Israel for explosions that have hit Iranian nuclear targets. Israeli officials, however, tell the Telegraph that penetrating a fortified facility such as Fordow would be no easy task. "Anything man-made, we can penetrate," one official says. "Israel would do anything within its power to stop the Iranian nuclear program. This includes tactics that fall just short, or substitute, a direct attack, such as the cyber war that has been raging for the past few years or acts of sabotage on Iranian's nuclear facilities." However, days after the recent failed talks with the International Atomic Energy Agency, Iranian officials announced the enrichment process will not stop "for a moment."

Nurse's aide Michele Kalina has been charged with criminal homicide in the deaths of the babies, whose remains were found in her home and in a landfill site, CNN reports. Police say DNA testing matched Kalina to four of the remains and a man Adams described as her boyfriend to three. He and her husband denied knowledge of any pregnancies. Kalina was charged earlier this month with abuse of a corpse, but was charged with homicide after a forensic pathologist determined that the deaths were violent, caused by asphyxia, poisoning, or neglect.

Flat_1024_summary: – Whale-watching is "traditionally seen as green tourism," says a US Geological Survey wildlife biologist. "The negative is the potential for disturbance. reference: – Secretive data companies are tracking almost every American's every move online—and compiling and selling disturbingly targeted lists based on that spying, a new Senate Commerce Committee report concludes. That includes lists of rape victims, people suffering from ailments including HIV, AIDS, and dementia, and people with substance abuse problems, a privacy group said in a hearing yesterday, as per CNN. Mailing addresses for police officers and domestic violence shelters—the latter of which are usually protected by law—are also for sale, as are lists based on demographics and economics, including "Ethnic Second-City Strugglers," and "Rural and Barely Making It." The World Privacy Forum urged Congress to act to "remove unsafe, unfair, and overall just deplorable lists from circulation." The Direct Marketing Association released a statement saying that while the lists are occasionally "used to disparage certain groups," they represented a "tiny minority" of marketing products. Overall the committee looked at nine companies, some of which refused to explain how they got their data or who they sold it to, Gawker reports. One company admitted it had sold social security numbers and banking information to an alleged identity theft ring.
TreeSum_summary: – Today's Senate Commerce Committee report on the data industry is "chilling," writes Matthew Yglesias at Slate. It reveals that the companies involved "own an astounding number of consumer profiles, and they're selling deeply personal information—sometimes to identity thieves—in categories like rape victims, people with cancer, and 'rural and Barely Making It.' One data broker is selling lists of addresses and names of consumers suffering from conditions including cancer, diabetes, and depression, and the medications used for those conditions; another is offering lists naming consumers, their credit scores, and specific health conditions." Of the nine companies the committee approached, "some" were forthcoming, but Acxiom, Experian, Epsilon, Reed Elsevier, Equifax, Rapleaf, TransUnion, Dataleaf, and Dataleaf refused to explain how they collected their data or who they were selling it to, citing confidentiality clauses in their contracts. Equifax told the Committee they had information as specific as: Whether a consumer purchased a particular soft drink or shampoo product in the last six months Whether they use laxatives or yeast infection products How many OB/GYN doctor visits they've had within the last 12 months How many miles they traveled in the past 4 weeks The number of whiskey drinks they consumed in—The home addresses of more than 30,000 police officers, the addresses of domestic violence shelters, and even the names of people suffering from AIDS and dementia were among "highly sensitive" consumer data lists uncovered by a privacy group, CNN reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – Elvis Presley's estate has won the right to trademark the late singer's name. The UK Intellectual Property Office ruled this week that Scottish craft brewer BrewDog was wrong to apply to register the names "Elvis Juice" and "BrewDog Elvis Juice" for a beer it released in 2015, Munchies reports. Elvis, who died in 1977, had his name and likeness trademarked by Elvis Presley Enterprises, which earns millions of dollars through a licensing program that allows the sale of Elvis merchandise worldwide. "Put simply, and notwithstanding that Mr Presley died nearly 40 years ago, he was/is such an iconic figure, that I would be very surprised if many people, including those at the younger end of the average consumer age spectrum, had not heard of him," the hearing officer said in a statement. "I consider most average consumers, on seeing the name Elvis alone, are likely to conceptualise that on the basis of Elvis Presley." BrewDog co-founders James Watt and Martin Dickie changed their names to Elvis in response to the trademark application and say Elvis Juice is one of the company's best-selling products.

Flat_1024_summary: – A soybean-laden US ship was just 25 miles from its destination when China slapped tariffs on $34 billion of American goods Friday in the first volley of a trade war between the world's two biggest economies. Bloomberg reports the Peak Pegasus was en route to the port of Dalian in northern China with soybeans from Brazil when the tariff went into effect at 12:01am local time. China had previously said it would impose a 25% levy on US agricultural produce and goods including automobiles. The soybean ship was expected to arrive in Dalian at around 5pm local time, but it appears to have lost its race. China typically imports from Brazil at this time of year before switching to the US in the fourth quarter, spurring concerns about a deficit in the final three months of the year. China is expected to cancel or re-sell at least some of the soybeans it bought from Brazil last week as a result of the new tariffs. Meanwhile, Bloomberg reports that soybean prices in the US have fallen to their lowest in almost a decade, while premiums for Brazilian soybeans have tripled over the last few months.

NPR President Vivian Schiller defended the decision, saying that Williams had violated NPR's guidelines barring its analysts from making personal or controversial statements. She also said that he should keep his feelings about Muslims between himself and "his psychiatrist or his publicist." Meanwhile, the AP reports that Williams' firing is "a reminder that we should be looking for similarities among religions and cultures rather than differences.Divisiveness only serves to fuel the downward spiral of hate and misunderstanding between the Islamic and Western worlds."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – NPR analyst Juan Williams says he was fired because he told Fox's Bill O'Reilly, "You cannot ignore what happened on 9/11 and you cannot ignore the connection to Islamic radicalism." "I said, 'I don't even get the chance to come in and we do this eyeball to eyeball, person to person?'" Williams tells the New York Times. "She said 'There's nothing you can say that will change my mind, this has been decided above me and we're terminating your contract." Williams says NPR's chief ethics officer told him he crossed the line by telling Fox that Williams' remarks were bigoted. Williams says that when he pointed out that America had "an obligation to protect the constitutional rights of everyone in the country," he was told he couldn't ignore the link between radicalism and 9/11.

reference: – Juan Williams says he didn't misspeak when he talked of getting nervous when seeing Muslims in airports, comments that got him fired from NPR. "I said what I meant to say," Williams explained on Fox News today, "which is that it is an honest experience that when I'm in an airport and I see people in Muslim garb who identify themselves first and foremost as Muslims, I do a double take. I have a moment of anxiety or fear given what happened on 9/11. That's just a reality." Williams described how an NPR executive fired him by phone after he told her just that, reports the Huffington Post. "I said, 'I don't even get the chance to come in and we do this eyeball to eyeball, person to person?'" he said. "She said, 'There's nothing you can say that will change my mind, this has been decided above me and we're terminating your contract.'" Separately today, NPR chief Vivian Schiller said Williams should keep his feelings about Muslims between him and "his psychiatrist or his publicist," reports AP. Click here for more.
TreeSum_summary: – NPR's chief has apologized for saying Juan Williams should keep his feelings about Muslims between himself and "his psychiatrist or his publicist." "I spoke hastily and I apologize to Juan and others for my thoughtless remark," Vivian Schiller said in a statement. "Despite many conversations and warnings over the years, Juan has continued to violate this principle." Williams, who was fired by NPR for telling Fox's Bill O'Reilly that he was nervous when he flew on a plane with a Muslim passenger, will also appear on Sean Hannity's show. "The point he was trying to say is, 'I get nervous,' and that's OK," said Whoopi Goldberg on the View. "Firing him for saying that I think is kind of ridiculous." Newt Gingrich called for an investigation into NPR, and Sarah Palin tweeted, "NPR should receive NO fed tax dollars if it operates as intolerant, private radio."

Flat_1024_summary: – The driver and at least one other person are in custody after at least nine people were found dead in the back of a stiflingly hot tractor-trailer parked at a Walmart in San Antonio, Texas, in what police are calling a human trafficking crime. The San Antonio Express-News reports that more than 30 people were taken to local hospitals with injuries believed to have been inflicted by the driver or others in the truck. Two of those hospitalized are 15 years old. "We have more than 100 people that we believe were in the trailer at the time, possibly more," San Antonio Police Chief William McManus says. McManus says a Walmart employee called police after getting a call from a man who said he was among the survivors and needed water. When police arrived on the scene, they found eight bodies and 31 people suffering from various injuries. "Unfortunately, some of them were severely overheated, and that was a refrigerated truck with no refrigeration," says San Antonio Fire Chief Charles Hood. "So the inside of the truck was just austere condition that nobody was going to survive in it. So we were very fortunate that they were found." The US Department of Homeland Security was involved in the investigation into what happened, he says.

Flat_1024_summary: – Two police officers in Georgia have been fired after video surfaced showing them punching and kicking a man in the head during a traffic stop, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports. Master Police Officer Robert McDonald can be seen on the video kicking 28-year-old Demetrius Hollins as he lay handcuffed on the ground. A second video shows Sgt. Michael Bongiovanni punching Hollins in the face as he stepped out of his car with his hands up, according to the Washington Post. "We acknowledge that the actions of these two officers have implications that will be felt for some time," a police department statement says. "However, we also believe that our decisive action in terminating both officers speaks volumes about what is expected of each officer that wears a Gwinnett County police badge." Hollins, who is black, tells NBC News that he was trying to record the incident on his cellphone when the officers "shoving me in my car and telling me that I was never going to have a video." He says one officer told him he would never make the call to his mother. He was charged with multiple traffic citations, obstruction of a police officer, and possession of less than an ounce of marijuana.

Flat_1024_summary: – A fifth woman has come forward to accuse Bill Cosby of sexually assaulting her, and she's a former Playboy Playmate. The woman, identified only as "Ms. Valentino," tells the Washington Post that Cosby offered her and an actress red pills after they had dinner at a restaurant in the 1970s. "He was trying to cheer me up, and he stuck a pill in my mouth. He said, 'This will make us all feel better,'" she says. "We were slurring words. I couldn't function." The next year, her 6-year-old son drowned in a swimming pool. "I was living what appeared to be a version of the Hollywood dream. But by the end of the decade, she had drifted away from those glitzy heights." Another woman has accused Cosby of drugging her and attempting to rape her 44 years ago.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – As the sexual assault allegations against Bill Cosby continue to snowball, the Washington Post interviewed five of the 16 women who've come forward to say he sexually assaulted them, including a former Playboy Playmate who has never spoken out publicly. The Post also reviewed court records that show a former director of women's basketball operations at Temple University who assembled 13 "Jane Doe" accusers in 2005 to testify on her behalf about their allegations against Cosby. A source tells the New York Daily News that before Cosby arrived on the Late Show With David Letterman last night, he'd "include as a request, before he arrived, that the young girls, interns, and assistants, all had to gather around in the green room backstage and sit down and watch him eat curry. No one would say anything, and he would sit silently eating and make us watch and want us to watch."

Flat_1024_summary: – Morning Joe co-hosts Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski say the White House threatened to run a negative tabloid story about them in order to get an apology from President Trump. In an op-ed in the Washington Post, the MSNBC hosts say they were contacted by "three people at the very top of the administration" telling them Trump was friends with David Pecker, chief executive of American Media, which publishes the National Enquirer. "And they said, if you call the president up and you apologize for your coverage, then he will pick up the phone and basically spike the story," Scarborough said Friday on Morning Joe. The hosts say Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, brokered a meeting with them. "Jared said we should end the meeting right then and there, because it was one of the only times he had heard him," the hosts said, per the New York Times. "We would take these insults seriously from anyone else. We don't from him, because, unfortunately, we believe he is in decline." Scarborough said Trump has apologized for tweeting about them as a " neurotic and not very bright mess." "It's unbelievably alarming that this president is so easily played," he said.

Donald liked being flattered, and David thought Donald was the king. Both have similar management styles, similar attitudes, starting with absolute superiority over anybody else."

Flat_1024_summary: – Celebrities have been using the #BringBackOurGirls hashtag to call for the return of Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamic extremist group Boko Haram, but one high-profile tweeter has quit the campaign after a few tweets because she fears it's becoming "one of those situations in which people feel an unjustified sense of accomplishment," she writes in the Daily Beast. "In some situations, it risks offering users of social media a false sense of achievement while obscuring underlying policy and structural issues as well as the full picture of what is taking place on the ground," she says. "I especially worry about how the # Bring BackOurGirls campaign will turn out when I think of some examples from the past: US courts are still systematically breaking down affirmative action, Joseph Kony is still free, and George Zimmerman got off. Considering these outcomes, I had to make sure I was honest with myself about the fact that a retweet or hashtag might not do much to contribute to thereturn of the girls." If readers don't suggest they are interested in doing "something else," doesn't have to mean picking up and moving to Nigeria or sleeping outside the embassy in a demand for action.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Cleveland Police Department routinely uses excessive force against citizens, including hitting and kicking people, using stun guns on the mentally ill, and shooting people in the back, according to a report released today by the Justice Department. "There is reasonable cause to believe that the Cleveland Division of Police engages in a pattern and practice of using excessive force," Eric Holder said in announcing the report, which follows a civil rights investigation into the department launched last year. The report found "a pattern of unreasonable and in some cases unnecessary force," NBC News reports. The city has agreed to a consent decree that will see an independent monitor oversee reforms, the AP reports. Among other things, the report found that officers don't receive proper training on how to de-escalate confrontations, and that men with mental illness are especially prone to use of force, Cleveland.com reports.

Carl Siciliano.

Flat_1024_summary: – An eBay seller has been ordered to pay $19,250 to cover the legal fees of another customer who took the company to court over a bad review. Med Express Inc. sued Amy Nicholls in 2013 after she posted a negative review about a microscope light she had purchased from the company, Ars Technica reports. The company claimed that Nicholls' review hurt its reputation and led to a lower overall rating for its sellers. After the lawsuit was filed, Med Express apologized and said it was withdrawing the suit. But Nicholls didn't back down. She lawyered up, getting pro bono counsel from Paul Levy at Public Citizen. "This is an important win for consumers," Levy says in a statement. "It shows that consumers have recourse when companies such as Med Express try to bully and silence consumers from telling other potential customers about their bad experiences." This week, a judge ruled that Med Express and founder Richard Radey must pay Nicholls and another customer's legal fees, ABC News reports. Radey, who has a history of such lawsuits, "had no objective reason whatsoever to question their veracity," the judge wrote.

Flat_1024_summary: – "We finally, you know, find our daughters, and we're able to put the dirt bag away for the rest of his life so he can never hurt anybody ever again." Those are the words of Kara Koptesky's mother to the Kansas City Star after a mushroom hunter in Cass County, Mo., on Monday found the remains of two young women in a field. Police haven't said whether the remains are those of 21-year-old Jessica Runions, who was last seen in Kansas City in September 2016, or Kopetsky, 17, who disappeared in May 2007. "My feeling is Kara is gone, but of course there is always that doubt in the back of your mind when you don't know 100%," Kopetsky's mom tells Fox4. "You always hold onto that hope that's what you go on. But we need a resolution to this and we need to find out what happened to our girls. Good or bad, we just want them home. We're still just waiting." Both women were friends with Kylr Yust, who has been charged with "knowingly burning" Runions' car and has never been charged in the disappearances. Yust was also involved with Kopetsky; he and Kopetsky had a restraining order against him shortly before she disappeared.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Police searching a remote area of Missouri for the remains of two women who've been missing for years say they've found a second skull, the Kansas City Star reports. The Cass County Sheriff's Office says the skull was found Monday by a mushroom hunter in the same area where remains of 17-year-old Kara Kopetsky were found last year. "Based on the remains recovered at this time, based on the age, sex, race have not been determined," the sheriff's office said in a statement. "Further examination is currently in progress." Authorities haven't yet been able to confirm the identities of the victims. Runions was last seen in September 2016, Kopetsky in May 2007. Kopetsky's mother, Rhonda Beckford, tells KMBC, "We're another day closer to getting answers, and you know, every hour, every day, every minute, we just hope and pray that those answers come in and we finally ... find our daughters, and we're able to put the dirt bag away for the rest of his life so he can never hurt anybody ever again." reference: – The families of two missing women have been notified after the discovery of a pair of skulls this week outside Kansas City, the Kansas City Star reports. Kara Kopetsky was last seen in 2007; Jessica Runions disappeared last September. Neither woman's body has ever been found. The first skull was discovered by a mushroom hunter Monday in a wooded area of Cass County. According to WDAF, authorities found the second skull Tuesday while searching the area. A number of other bones have also been found. While the families of Kopetsky and Runions were notified, neither of the skulls has been identified yet, KMBC reports. It's unclear how long it could take to get an identification. The families of the missing women are hopeful the remains will soon provide some answers. "Even if it’s not Kara, it’s someone’s loved one and someone has answers,” Kopetsky's mother tells the Star. “Good or bad, someone has answers.” Runions' family has been searching regularly since her disappearance. Searchers found two bodies in January, neither of them belonging to the missing women. Runions, 21, was last seen leaving a party with 28-year-old Kylr Yust, a friend of her boyfriend, in September. Yust has been charged with burning her car after it was later found. Yust had dated Kopetsky prior to her disappearance at the age of 17 a decade ago. Shortly before she went missing, Kopetsky filed a restraining order against him.

"Every hour, every day, every minute, we just hope and pray that those answers come in and we finally, you know, find our daughters, and we're able to put the dirt bag away for the rest of his life so he can never hurt anybody ever again." Fox News reports authorities may have found the remains of Kara Koptesky, who was last seen leaving a party with her boyfriend, Kylr Yust, in May 2014. Yust has been charged with "knowingly burning" Runions' SUV, but no charges have been filed in the disappearances. On Monday, a mushroom hunter found a human skull in a field just north of a Walmart parking lot in Belton, Mo., reports the Kansas City Star. Police haven't said how or when the women were killed, but they suspect foul play. Runions was last spotted getting into a car with Kopetsky at a gas station in May of that year. She was reported missing two months later when her boyfriend didn't pick her up from school. "I don't think I could get through this without them and my family and friends," says Runion's mother. "It's the hardest thing anybody would have to go through."

Flat_1024_summary: – If you've got a good view of the night sky Tuesday night, you'll be in for a treat. USA Today reports that the "occultation" of Aldebaran, one of the brightest stars in the sky, will be visible to most of the eastern and southern US. A lunar occultation is when the moon passes in front of a star, and Space.com explains that it's either "total" or "grazing." In the case of a total occultation, the star will disappear behind the moon before reappearing an hour or so later. Agrazing occultation happens when the star "slides right along the edge of the moon," according to Sky and Telescope. "Most of the events will be gradual rather than instantaneous, as hills and valleys on the moon's northern limb slide across the face of the giant star," the magazine says. Viewers in parts of Mexico, Central America, southeastern Canada, the eastern US, and southern Europe will be able to see the event Wednesday night. The series of occultations, which began in January 2015, will end in 2018.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Stargazers are in for a treat this weekend: The star Aldebaran, also known as the "occultation star," will appear to graze the moon's limb on Saturday night and disappear in the wee hours of Sunday morning, Space.com reports. The International Occultation Association has predicted that viewers in the eastern US and western Canada will be able to see the star as it hovers over the bright side of the moon between 1am and 2am local time. Once it's gone, it will reappear up to 75 minutes later, depending on where you are in the US. The series of occultations, which began in January 2015, will end in 2018.

Get ready for a lunar occultation Tuesday night. (Photo: GEORGI LICOVSKI, EPA) 
 
 The moon and one of the brightest stars in the sky will play hide-and-seek Tuesday night. 
 
 So grab your telescope or binoculars and get ready for a moon "occultation," which sounds like something perfect for a spooky pre-Halloween night. 
 
 Not as well known as an eclipse or a meteor shower, a lunar occultation occurs when the moon passes in front of a star. Tuesday night, the moon will occult Aldebaran, which...
reference: – Sky watchers will get a bit of a show Tuesday night: People across the Eastern US and much of the Southwest will be able to see the moon move in front of Aldebaran, one of the brightest stars in the night sky, a phenomenon known as a lunar occultation, reports USA Today. Most in the viewing zone will see a "total occultation," in which the star disappears behind the moon. But the real treat comes for residents in certain areas of LA and Denver, who will be able to witness a "grazing occultation," where the star moves along the very periphery of the moon. Those with high-powered telescopes (or perhaps a nice pair of binoculars) should be able to see the star move in and out of view as mountain ranges and craters on the moon rise and fall. In the West, Aldebaran will disappear shortly after 10pm PDT, per Space.com. In the Eastern US, it will happen between 1am and 2am EDT. Astronomy site Sky and Telescope has the nitty-gritty on when and where to look.
TreeSum_summary: – The next big show in the sky will be a lunar occultation, in which the moon passes in front of a star, USA Today reports. Viewers in parts of Mexico, Central America, southeastern Canada, the eastern US, and southern Europe will be able to see the event, which the International Occultation Timing Association calls a "total" or "grazing" occultation. Sky and Telescope says you'll likely see the star "disappear and reappear several times in the darkness just barely off the moon's dazzlingly sunlit north polar region." It adds that "most of the events will be gradual rather than instantaneous, as hills and valleys on the Moon's northern limb slide across the face of the giant star." The next Aldebaran occultation will take place early Wednesday.

Flat_1024_summary: – Scientists say Friday's devastating tsunami in Indonesia was caused by a "strike-slip fault"—a type of fault that occurs when the earth's surface moves in a "heterogeneous" way, the New York Times reports. In this case, the earth moved in such a way that it caused the tsunami. "We won't know what caused it until that's done," says Robert Patton, a seismologist at the University of California, Berkeley. He notes that the quake may have caused an undersea landslide that displaced water and created the tsunami waves. The AP reports that Indonesia was supposed to be one of the first countries to get a tsunami-warning system in place, but funding issues stalled the project. It is too late for central Sulawesi, where walls of water up to 20 feet high and a magnitude 7.5 earthquake killed at least 832 people in Palu and Donggala, tragically highlighting the weaknesses of the existing warning system and low public awareness about how to respond to warnings. "To me this is a tragedy for science, even more so a Tragedy for the Indonesian people as the residents of Sulawesi are discovering right now," says Louise Comfort, a University of Pittsburgh expert in disaster management.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The earthquake that struck the Indonesian city of Palu on Friday may have been caused by an unusual type of fault, experts say. The Guardian reports that the magnitude 7.5 quake was caused by a "strike-slip fault," in which the earth movement is largely horizontal. That kind of movement would not ordinarily create a tsunami, but under certain circumstances it can. "We won't know what caused it until that's done," says James Patton, a seismologist with the British Geological Survey. reference: – The tsunami that killed hundreds, possibly thousands of people after an earthquake in Indonesia on Friday was much bigger and more devastating than would normally be expected after that kind of quake, scientists say. "We expected it might cause a tsunami, just not one that big," geophysicist Jason Patton tells the New York Times. Tsunamis like the 18-foot monster wave that wrecked cities on Sulawesi island are usually caused by "megathrust" earthquakes that move land vertically, not "strike-slip" quakes like the 7.5-magnitude one Friday, which moved the earth horizontally, Patton says. The Sulawesi event was, however, localized, unlike the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. It may have been the case, Patton says, that massive undersea landslides created the tsunami, or that the narrow bay that Palu sits at the end of concentrated the wave's power. Indonesian authorities have been strongly criticized for apparently canceling the tsunami alert too early, though expert Adam Switzer at the Earth Observatory of Singapore tells the AP that this is unfair. "What it shows is that the tsunami models we have now are too simplistic," he says. "They don't take into account multiple events, multiple quakes within a short period of time. They don't take into account submarine landslides." The official death toll now stands at 844, though authorities, who have been preparing mass graves, have been unable to access some hard-hit areas, the Guardian reports.
TreeSum_summary: – Scientists are trying to figure out what caused Indonesia's second-largest city, Palu, to be pummeled by a tsunami Friday, and they're not sure what caused it at all. "We won't know what caused [it] until that's done," a University of California-Santa Barbara seismologist tells the New York Times. One possibility is that the tsunami was caused by an undersea landslide. Such a landslide would have displaced water and created waves, and the earthquake may have caused the rupture zone of the fault to move through an area where the seafloor rises or drops off, pushing seawater in front of it. Other possibilities are that the quake itself caused the tsunami, or that it was triggered by an earthquake-induced rupture on a strike-slip fault, reports the BBC. The death toll in Palu—which is located on the island of Java—now stands at more than 3,300, with more than 61,000 people injured, per the AP. In the wake of the 2004 earthquake and tsunami that killed more than a quarter-million people in Indonesia, the country promised to have a tsunami-detection system up and running by the end of this year. But the system has been "simply put on hold" since September, when the country's finance ministry, its geophysics agency, and a private company failed to come to an agreement on who should bear the brunt of the system's data. The project's final undersea point, off the coast of Padang, is just a few kilometers away.

 The cash was found Wednesday inside a Westborough apartment by investigators who had tailed a Brazilian man from New York. That man, Cleber Rene Rizerio Rocha, 28, was charged with conspiring to commit mone...
reference: – You'd think that much cold, hard cash would make for an uncomfortable night's sleep. The AP reports a 28-year-old Brazilian man was arrested this week in Massachusetts after authorities found about $20 million hidden in a box spring. The arrest of Cleber Rene Rizerio Rocha is connected to an investigation into TelexFree, an alleged pyramid scheme, according to Reuters. Authorities say TelexFree was originally created to swindle Brazilian immigrants but ended up taking $1.8 billion from nearly 1 million people around the world. Authorities say Rocha, acting as a courier for the nephew of TelexFree's founder, delivered a suitcase containing $2.2 million to a cooperating witness. They then followed him to an apartment where they found $20 million more under a mattress. He's been charged with conspiring to commit money laundering.
TreeSum_summary: – A Brazilian man was arrested in Massachusetts this week for allegedly laundering $20 million linked to a $1.76 billion Ponzi scheme, Reuters reports. According to the AP, 28-year-old Cleber Rene Rizerio Rocha flew from Brazil to New York on Dec. 31 and met with a cooperating witness at a restaurant in Hudson, Mass. He gave him a suitcase containing $2.2 million. Federal agents followed Rocha to an apartment in Westborough and found a "substantial amount of cash" hidden under a mattress. Rocha was charged with conspiring to commit money laundering. TelexFree was a Massachusetts-based company that sold voice-over-internet telephone service and was founded by James Merrill, a US citizen, and Carlos Wanzeler, a Brazilian. Prosecutors say the company was a massive pyramid scheme, making little to no money selling its service while taking in millions of dollars from thousands of people who paid to sign up to be "promoters" and post ads online for it. It filed for bankruptcy in April 2014 owing $5 billion to its participants, prosecutors say. WanzelER fled to his native Brazil and could not be found.

Flat_1024_summary: – President Obama today reiterated his opposition to a Senate bill that would slap sanctions on China for manipulating its currency to make its exports cheaper for the US. “I think we've got a strong case to make,” he said. “But we just have to make sure that we do it in a way that's going to be effective.” John Boehner last week called the bill “dangerous,” and Eric Cantor said he wanted to hear from the White House before deciding whether to bring it to the House floor, the Hill reports. House Democrats, meanwhile, are under increasing pressure to pass the bill, which is poised to clear the Senate soon. Democratic leaders in the Senate are expected to roundly criticize the House if it does not act on what they are calling a major jobs bill. The currency measure could become a leading issue on the campaign trail in 2012, and anxious Republican rank-and-file members have said they will buck Speaker John Boehner if necessary. One Midwest GOP lawmaker told the Hill, “I’ll sign it ... and others will sign it, if the president agrees to sign the bill.” The Senate bill has cleared two procedural hurdles and is expected to pass soon.

John Boehner has called the bill "dangerous," but 99 House Republicans voted for such a bill last year in the Democratic-controlled House. Boehner has the option of moving the bill that's different from the Senate version, putting the onus on the White House to negotiate a deal. But even if he does move the bill, it's highly unlikely he'd get it through the House, given the GOP's opposition to legislation that could hurt the economy. Flat_1024_summary: – If you've ever wondered what it's like to be tracked at Disney World, you're in luck. The Walt Disney Co. has announced that it will start using facial recognition technology to track "every move" made by guests at Disney parks, including Epcot, Disney World's Animal Kingdom, and Disney World in Florida, the Wall Street Journal reports. The technology, which will be rolled out over the next few months, will allow Disney to determine the age and gender of each guest who walks into one of the parks, as well as whether they've eaten at a Disney restaurant, ridden a Disney ride, or visited a Disney attraction. Disney says the technology will also be used to determine if a guest has changed clothes or taken off an item of clothing during the day. The company says the facial recognition system will be cheaper and easier to use than clothing recognition, which can be expensive and inaccurate if guests are wearing sunglasses or hats, the New York Daily News reports. In a blog post, Disney says that while facial recognition systems "require cameras that are visible to the person," clothing recognition will be more reliable because "many guests have similar attire, and will change their clothing throughout the day, such as putting on or taking off a jacket or sweater." Disney has been granted a patent for a system and method "using foot recognition to create a customized guest experience," WFTV reports.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Starting this summer, Disney visitors will be able to register for rides and other attractions using their shoes. In a blog post, the company explains that the technology allows Disney to " tailor certain experiences for the guest." For example, a person's shoes may vary widely in appearance and color, as well as lower leg data, tread wear, and foot size. Disney says the system can also use additional information, such as a guest's height, weight, and shoe size. The blog post notes that Disney has rejected other technologies that could be used to track guests, including retinal and fingerprint scanning, which Disney says are "invasive, obtrusive, and inaccurate if guests are wearing certain accessories such as sunglasses or hats." Disney says it has no plans to use clothing recognition, as "those systems require cameras that are visible to the person." However, WFTV reports, Disney has been granted a patent for a system and method "using foot recognition to create a customized guest experience." The patent would involve a robot or mobile scanning mechanism that would use a foot scanner to take depth information and a camera to take appearance information of aguest's foot and use that data to determine various factors like the most popular rides and common paths guests take from ride to ride. The Orlando Sentinel notes that this is just a patent and Disney files many patent that may or may not become a real.

Flat_1024_summary: – A Muslim man beaten by a mob that accused him of transporting cows for slaughter has died in western India, reports the AP, in the latest violence by Hindu vigilante groups enraged over treatment of the animal they consider sacred. Pehlu Khan died late yesterday of injuries sustained when he and 14 other men were brutally beaten three days earlier in Rajasthan state, police said. Hindus, who form 80% of India's 1.3 billion population, consider cows to be sacred and for many eating beef is taboo. In many Indian states, the slaughtering of cows and selling of beef is either restricted or banned. The men had bought the dairy cows at a cattle fair and were taking them home in neighboring Haryana state when the mob stopped the trucks, pulled out the men, and beat them, says a police officer. Indian television channels broadcast video of the men being beaten with sticks and iron rods. No arrests have been made.

Flat_1024_summary: – Scientists think they've figured out what caused the biggest eruption in Yellowstone National Park's history, a 631,000-year-old supereruption that sent vast amounts of rock, dust, and volcanic ash over parts of the US and Canada. "If something like this happened today, it would be catastrophic," Arizona State University geologist Hannah Shamloo tells National Geographic. "We want to understand what triggers these eruptions, so we can set up warning systems. That's the big-picture goal." Shamloo and her team discovered crystals of feldspar embedded in a rock formation known as the Lava Creek Tuff outside the park. These crystals, called phenocrysts, form as magma cools slowly beneath the volcano. They were too large to have formed when hot material was flung up during the eruption, but grew gradually in Yellowstone's magma chamber. As the surrounding temperature, pressure, and water content changed, trace elements surrounding the crystals also changed and became incorporated into subsequent layers. "There are multiple ways to trigger an eruption," Shamloo says, "but as of now, we're seeing evidence for a magma injection." The team presented their findings at the American Geophysical Union's Fall Meeting in San Francisco on Dec. 13.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – "It's shocking how little time is required to take a volcanic system from being quiet and sitting there to the edge of an eruption." That's Hannah Shamloo's take on the last super-eruption at Yellowstone National Park, which happened 631,000 years ago—and it's one that scientists have yet to fully understand. "We want to understand what triggers these eruptions, so we can set up warning systems," Shamloo, a geologist at Arizona State University, tells the New York Times. "That's the big-picture goal." To that end, Shamloo and a colleague presented evidence at the IAVCEI 2017 conference in Portland, Ore., this month that such eruptions only need a few decades of gestation before exploding. To study this, the researchers examined two types of crystals known as phenocrysts, which form when magma cools under a volcano. Varying between 1 and 2 millimeters each, these crystals are too large to have formed during the heat of an explosion. Instead, they grew gradually over time in Yellowstone's magma chamber, each crystal beginning with a core that slowly and steadily enlarged outward, layer upon layer. As surrounding magma conditions changed, trace elements surrounding the growing pheno crysts were recorded. The researchers believe the magma chamber had the same bulk composition as the one that erupted the Lava Creek Tuff, but the water content was much lower: 5% water by weight, 5 times that of an older eruption from the Long Valley Caldera that produced the Bishop Tuff. "There are multiple ways to trigger an eruption, but as of now, we're seeing evidence for a magma injection," says Shamloo.

Flat_1024_summary: – If you're worried about your child's ears, Consumerist has some advice: Don't buy him a pair of earbuds. The site tested a number of noise-blocking headphones and found that they don't work as well as advertised, even if they come with a built-in amplifier. It's all about volume, explains the site, which uses a technique known as "spliced water pipe." Basically, a piece of water pipe is spliced onto an end of a speaker, which reduces the amount of water that flows through it. However, you can increase the pressure going through the pipe to get it back to its original level. So what to do? Consumerist used an iPhone as its source, because "the loudest source most will encounter ... is the iPhone's" internal amplifiers. It also tested other sources, including video game consoles and home theater receivers, but found they didn't "perform with any volume limit." Still, the site notes that "most of these headphones will play louder with a headphone amp is largely irrelevant. ... In any case, such devices would likely be used by older kids with hearing loss." Wired has a list of the best kids' headphones, including the Puro IEM200, which blocks 99% of everyday household noise, including car exhaust and construction noise.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – If you've got a toddler on your hands and you want to make sure he or she doesn't get too loud while listening to the radio, the Wirecutter has some advice: Don't buy kids' headphones. The site tested a range of models and found that almost all of them exceeded the World Health Organization's 85 decibel workplace limit, which is designed to protect workers' ears from too much noise. Wired reports that the Puro Bluetooth headphones, which come with a built-in battery, were the best for kids ages 3 to 11, while the JBuddies Studio ($29.99) was the best choice for older kids. The testers also looked at the models' ability to reduce ambient noise. The Puro's cord is wired, so if it's plugged in the wrong way, "it’ll play really loud," says an audio expert who helped test all the headphones. "If they are using it in Bluetooth mode, it’s impossible to make too loud." Wired also notes that some of the models failed to meet the 85 decibel limit when plugged in via an electrical outlet.

Flat_1024_summary: – When Atlanta couple Willie and Carol Fowler had to cancel their daughter's wedding six weeks before it was to take place, they decided to make up for it in a big way—by hosting a party for the homeless. "My husband actually prayed about it," Carol Fowler tells ABC News. "The next morning he woke, I was in the process of canceling the venue, letting them know that we had no use for it, and he said, 'No, we’re going to call 'Hosea Feed the Hungry' and have them round up people from the shelters.'" The next day, buses brought 200 homeless women, children, and families to the Fowlers' Villa Christina, where they enjoyed face-painting, outdoor appetizers, and a motivational speaker. reference: – How do you conquer a powerful Mayan city-state? Forge a political dynasty, ally with smaller surrounding cities, and slowly envelop until you become leader of the Serpent Kingdom—at least according to one take on a newly unveiled Mayan altar, the AP reports. Discovered in 2017 at the Guatemalan site of La Corona, the nearly 1,500-year-old engraving depicts a king named Chak Took Ich'aak conjuring gods from a shaft shaped like a snake. Ich'aak later governed the nearby city of El Peru-Waka, suggesting that the so-called Serpent Kingdom or Kaanul dynasty forged a movement that grew until it defeated the towering city-state of Tikal in 562 A.D. "... In this case, around 1,500 years ago, I would call this the historical Mayan version of Game of Thrones," excavation co-director Tomas Barrientos tells Phys.org. Archaeologists already knew that Kaanul kings dominated the Maya lowlands for decades, but the altar—which likely dates to 544 A.D.—shows that La Corona "was the place where the most important historical Mayan political movement began to take shape," says Barrientos. Team leader Marcello Canuto sees the dynasty rising up with a mix of cultural appropriation, like conjuring old gods on the tablet to gain legitimacy; marriage, with a princess from neighboring Mexico; and other alliances with powerful forces. Otherwise, beating Tikal "would be the equivalent to Cuba defeating the United States in a war," says Canuto. "They could only have done that ... if they had had the backing of the Soviet Union." Announced Wednesday, the altar is on display at the National Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology in Guatemala City, per the Times-Picayune.

The altar, carved out of limestone and weighing more than a ton, shows King Chak Took Ich'aak "sitting and holding a scepter from which emerge two patron gods of the city," Live Science reports. It depicts a wedding between a princess from the Kaanul dynasty and a King of La Corona. "This altar shows us a part of Guatemala's history, and in this case, around 1,500 years ago, I would say it's one of the best altars of its kind in the world," BarrientoS tells the New York Times. "It's a high-quality work of art that shows us they were rulers entering into a period of great power and who were allying themselves with others to compete." La Corona "was the place where the most important historical Mayan political movement began to take shape" in the sixth century, when the Serpent Kingdom expanded from its capital of Dzibanche to La Corona, according to the Times. It's believed the altar dates back to May 12, 544 AD, the day Chak took over Tikal, the capital of the Kaenul dynasty, 20 years before he became a vassal and ruler of the larger city of Peru-Waka. But the gods associated with him are different from those associated with the area, the AP reports. The team led by Marcello Canuto of Tulane University says the altar suggests the Snake Kings acted like its namesake, which acted on the other rival kingdom of Tikal.

reference: – Despite reports Thursday that they wouldn't be charged with a crime, the five teens who allegedly laughed and filmed a man as he drowned in Florida earlier this month could now face misdemeanor charges. ABC News reports police have recommended charges for "duty to report" against the unnamed teens, who range in age from 14 to 16. News 13 explains that while Florida doesn't have a law requiring bystanders to report someone dying, it does have a law that requires people to report someone has died. Jamel Dunn, 31, drowned earlier this month. Cocoa Police Chief Mike Cantaloupe says it's the first time the law would be used in this manner, and the teens would serve as a "test case." News 13 reports the statute is most typically applied to medical examiners. The State Attorney's Office worked with police to come up with the charges, but the office will determine whether to prosecute the case. Cantaloupe previously called the teens' actions "utterly inhumane and cruel."
TreeSum_summary: – Police in Cocoa, Fla., say they'll file charges against five teens who laughed and filmed as a homeless man drowned in a pond earlier this month. Jamel Dunn's body was found July 7 at the edge of the pond, and police said Thursday that no charges would be filed because the teens didn't report his death, the Orlando Sentinel reports. But on Friday, Cocoa Police Chief Michael Cantaloupe said charges will be filed under a Florida law that requires people to report deaths. "It is the duty of any person in the district where a death occurs, who becomes aware of the death of any individual occurring ... must report such death and circumstances to the district medical examiner," the law states, per WESH. "As far as we know, the statute has never been used in this way," Cantaloupes said, adding it's possible Dunn would still be alive today if one of the teens had called for help. The teens, who are between the ages of 14 and 17, are being investigated by the State Attorney's Office, which will decide whether to prosecute. "We can find no moral justification for either the behavior of persons heard on the recording of the deliberate decision not to render aid to Mr. Dunn," it says in a statement. Dunn was determined to have entered the pond on his own after video from a neighbor's security camera showed him scaling a fence and entering the pond. "This is an isolated act of unspeakable inhumanity and in no way is a reflection of our community," says Cocoa Mayor Henry Parrish III.

Flat_1024_summary: – For two years, a 55-year-old woman in Spain had been taking an alternative treatment promoted by Gwyneth Paltrow: live bee acupuncture, in which she was stung by the angry insects and treated with bee venom, the New York Times reports. Then last year, she suffered an allergic reaction to the bee venom and died. According to a report published in the Journal of Investigational Allergology and Clinical Immunology, the woman "developed wheezing, dyspnea, and sudden loss of consciousness immediately after a live bee sting." Doctors say she suffered a "massive watershed stroke and permanent coma" due to severe anaphylactic shock. The death is believed to be the first reported death from the bee acupuncture treatment. Live bee acupuncture—also known as bee venom apitherapy—is a treatment in which a patient is stung by an angry bee and treated by a bee-stinging needle. The acupuncture can be dangerous for people with severe allergies. In the case of the Spanish woman, doctors say repeated exposure to the allergen increases the risk of a severe reaction. (Gwyneth Paltrow has a new line of lip gloss.)

Flat_1024_summary: – Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations to try to halt a disputed independence referendum in Catalonia on Sunday and fired rubber bullets at protesters outside a Barcelona polling station. Several people were injured. The officers fired the rubber bullets while trying to clear protesters who were trying to prevent National Police cars from leaving after police confiscated ballot boxes from the voting center. The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it's illegal. Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries, the AP reports. An AP photographer saw several people who had been injured during the scuffles outside Barcelona's Rius i Taule school, where some voters had cast ballots before police arrived Catalan President Carles Puigdemont condemned the crackdown. "Police brutality will shame forever the Spanish state," he said as crowds cheered. Tension has been on the rise since the vote was called in early September, crystalizing years of defiance by separatists in the affluent region, which contributes mightily to Spain's economy. Separatist Catalans have long complained of contributing too much to the state while not getting enough in return. Enric Millo, the Spanish government's representative in the region, said police and National Guard forces acted "professionally" to enforce court orders. The regional government said Monday that the vote would be allowed to go ahead even though the official electoral board has been disbanded. "We are under conditions to be able to celebrate a self-determination referendum with guarantees," said a spokesman.

Flat_Overlap_summary: – Paul Krugman and Ben Bernanke are locked in a "battle of the beards" over the value of the Federal Reserve and the US economy, writes David Leonhardt in the New York Times. The Nobel Prize-winning economist wants the Fed to raise its target range for interest rates from its current 2% to 4% over the next five years. Bernanke, for his part, says Krugman's proposals are "reckless" and would hurt the economy. "I wish more economic discussion was like this, as opposed to the fraudulence that permeates most of the 'debate,'" writes Dean Baker in the Wall Street Journal. Flat_1024_summary: – An off-duty California Highway Patrol officer is being praised for returning $120,000 to its rightful owner after finding it in the middle of the road, UPI reports. The unnamed sergeant was driving in Concord in September when she had to swerve to avoid two large bank deposit bags in the road. She took a U-turn to pick them up and found a large amount of cash equalling more than $120,000. She reported the money and the police were able to track down the owner. Her friend and children could not believe she returned the money, but the officer, who was raised by a single mother in Los Angeles, says it was an opportunity to be an example for her children and teach them a lesson. "There was no one on that street after I had come back, nobody would have known," she says. "But that's what determines a person's integrity, it's how you do when nobody is looking." The sergeant was praised by her superiors. "On too many occasions our personnel do not pause to be recognized as they feel they were simply doing their job."

Flat_1024_summary: – A hiker in Yosemite National Park fell to his death while climbing the iconic granite cliffs of Half Dome in rainy conditions, authorities said Tuesday. The National Park Service said the accident occurred Monday at about 4:30pm in the Northern California national park. The hiker's body was recovered Tuesday afternoon, reports the AP. NPS spokeswoman Jamie Richards said the man and a companion were scaling the steepest part of the trail where rangers recently installed cables to help hikers to climb the steepest parts of the 4,800-foot ascent. Richards says the companion was helped from the trail and was unharmed. The cables are installed each summer to assist the thousands of hikers who make the popular 14-mile round trip. Richards said investigators are still trying to determine how the fall occurred. She said it's unclear if the hikers were climbing in the rain, but that the well-worn trail over smooth rock was wet. It's the first fatal fall from Half Dome since 2010. NPS requires hikers to obtain permits to hike the popular trail to avoid overcrowding during the peak summer season.

Flat_1024_summary: – Former FBI agent John Connolly could be released from prison as soon as today after a Florida appeals court overturned his murder conviction. The three-judge panel ruled 2-1 that the statute of limitations has expired in the case of Connolly, who was convicted of second-degree murder with a firearm in 2008 in connection with the 1982 shooting death of Boston businessman John Callahan. According to the Boston Globe, Connolly was the FBI agent who ratted out James "Whitey" Bulger and Stephen "The Rifleman" Flemmi for murders they were allegedly involved in. He was sentenced to 40 years in prison in 2009 after being found guilty of tipping off Bulger's henchmen, Martorano, that a World Jai Alai executive was going to be killed. But the appeals court found that the time passed after Callahan's murder before Connolly was charged with a crime was too long. “It was undisputed that [Martorano] used his own gun to shoot Callahan and that Connolly never carried, displayed, used, or threatened to use the murder weapon,” Judge Richard J. Suarez wrote for the majority. “Mr. Connolly presently is right where he belongs, and I guess we’ll do what we can to keep him there.”

TreeSum_summary: – Before killing 20 children and six adults at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., in 2012, Adam Lanza told a woman he was in an online relationship with that could be "possibly beneficial to both parties," according to an FBI report. reference: – One thing you'll want to avoid on Thanksgiving—or at any time in the near future—is romaine lettuce. The CDC issued an alert two days before the holiday warning that no romaine is safe to eat as an E. coli outbreak spreads, reports NBC News. It doesn't matter where the romaine is from or even if you or a loved one has eaten some and not gotten sick. The advice from the CDC is the same: Toss it. A bag of mixed salad that includes romaine? Toss it. In fact, the alert includes advice on how to clean your refrigerator if romaine has been inside it recently. So far, 32 people in 11 states have gotten sick, and 13 required hospitalization. No deaths have been reported. "This advice includes all types or uses of romaine lettuce, such as whole heads of romaine, hearts of romaine, and bags and boxes of precut lettuce and salad mixes that contain romaine, including baby romaine, spring mix, and Caesar salad," the CDC said. "If you do not know if the lettuce is romaine or whether a salad mix contains romaine, do not eat it and throw it away." (Tainted water was blamed in a different outbreak involving romaine earlier this year.)
