reference: – An amazing, if grisly, feat continues to resonate after a report in Thursday's Globe and Mail of Toronto. The newspaper, quoting military sources, says a Canadian sniper in Iraq killed an ISIS militant from the mind-boggling distance of 3,540 meters, or 2.2 miles. The Canadian military has not confirmed what would be the longest kill shot by a sniper in history, but the story has in the meantime drawn attention to something else: the remarkable prowess of Canadian snipers in general. Some coverage: The training: If confirmed, that means the sniper record has been broken four times in the last 15 years, three of those times by Canadians, notes Maclean's magazine. One reason, it says, is because Canadian snipers "are not simply taught to hit their targets." The training goes beyond their shooting duties, making sure they're able to "design and run complex operations" if necessary. "That in itself may not make them better snipers but the gestalt of sniper-training and command-thinking combined could explain their skill." Long history: The CBC examines the history of Canada's military marksmanship, noting that Cpl. Francis Pegahmagabow of the 1st Canadian Infantry Battalion had 378 kills, making him deadliest sniper of World War I. A military historian says the skill carried into WWII. "The best snipers were usually country boys who knew how to hunt." Official statement: The Canadian military has not confirmed the kill, but it did confirm the shot. "A member of the Joint Task Force 2 successfully hit a target from 3,540 meters," it says in an email to NPR, adding that it won't divulge further details for troop safety. Really? The Globe and Mail says the shot was verified by video and data, but that hasn't emerged yet, and some are skeptical. The Washington Post talks to former US snipers who say that even seeing a human target would be difficult from that distance, even with advanced scopes. A theory floated by a former Marine shooter: "A spotter with an advanced optical device was able to verbally walk the sniper onto the target and correct his aim.” Yes: Canadian Cpl. Rob Furlong, who once held the record himself at 2,430 meters, counters the skeptics: “It’s not an impossible distance,” he says. “So to the naysayers I would just say, this can be done.” It's a "hell of a shot," adds former Canadian sniper Jody Mitic, who was written a book called, of course, Unflinching: The Making of a Canadian Sniper. A critic: In a post at Stuff.co.nz, John Edens thinks the shot was possible, given high-tech gizmos to account for everything from wind speed to the curvature of the earth. Plus, the gun used, a McMillan TAC-50 rifle, employs a 50-caliber bullet the size of a "large cigar." His beef, though, is with media coverage that he thinks glorifies war. "It's an achievement to a point, but it's not really one humanity should be proud of."

Flat_Overlap_summary: – The FDA has ordered a genetic-testing company backed by Google to stop selling its $99 saliva-based test, saying it hasn't been proven effective and could mislead people about their health. 23andMe has 15 days to explain how it will proceed, or face civil fines or injunctions, the Washington Post reports. The test, called the Personal Genome Service, can detect more than 240 genetic conditions and traits, including breast cancer, heart disease, and HIV. But the FDA says the company has failed to provide the scientific data necessary to prove that its test works as advertised. The move highlights the FDA's unease about direct-to-consumer genetic tests, which can provide people with detailed information but not necessarily the context necessary to interpret what it means or how they should proceed. Flat_1024_summary: – Visitors to Vancouver's Maritime Museum can walk around a replica of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police schooner St. Roch and get a close-up look at the ship's interior—but they're not allowed to touch the inside. That's because the inside of the schooner, which was used as a police vessel in the 1930s and '40s, is covered in graffiti, reports the Vancouver Sun. It's not clear who wrote the graffiti, but the museum's director says it's a result of the building's location, on a busy commercial street: "We don't want to be seen as a place that tolerates vandalism," he says. "We want it to be a place where people can come and learn about the history of the city." The graffiti, however, isn't sitting well with visitors. "They have a new exhibit called Scrimshaw which features numerous images of an inappropriate sexual nature on tusks," wrote one. "There was only one small warning sign beside one of the display boxes. But, there was no warnings in the entrance ways leading to the display nor when I purchased tickets for my family." Another complained that the "small collection of etchings and engravings on whale teeth and bone" was "quite explicit."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – A small collection of etchings and engravings on whale teeth and bone is on display at the Vancouver Maritime Museum, part of a larger show that also features example of maritime tattoo art. Nine of the etched pieces on display show images of a sexual nature, some of them quite explicit. The VMM has collected scrimshaw for years—most of the work was donated—but the pieces were rarely if ever displayed. Museum curator Patricia Owen says the opportunity arose when staff decided to present a show about maritime tattoos; it seemed natural to compare and contrast the two art forms. But the nine pieces with sexual content are displayed in a case raised high off the floor, well beyond scope of a toddler's inquisitive eyes, and lighting is prudishly dim. Next to the display is a sign: "Hide Your Eyes! These pieces of scrimshaw are not intended for children." Ann Pimentel raised the concern—and coined the unlikely phrase—after visiting the museum, the Vancouver Sun reports. She says she was "extremely disturbed" and "concerned for unknowing families and school groups especially with children that are impressionable and vulnerable. I will not be returning nor recommending this Museum."

Flat_1024_summary: – Investigators who used an online genealogical site to find the ex-cop they believe is a serial killer and rapist who terrified California decades ago may have made a mistake. Paul Holes, a retired Contra Costa County DA who helped lead the investigation, tells the AP that he used the open-source site GEDmatch to find relatives of suspected Golden State Killer Joseph James DeAngelo. He says the site returned a list of relatives—with names and emails—by degree of shared single nucleotide polymorphisms, or SNPs, which offer a genetic fingerprint. On average, you share 50% of your SNPs with a sibling, 25% with a half sibling, 12.5% with a first cousin, and 3.1% with a second cousin. The hits on DeAngelo came from third and fourth cousins, Holes says. "I'm not familiar with any other case used to capture someone like this," says Holes, who built more than 25 family trees using data from the site. "Although we were not approached by law enforcement or anyone else about this case or about the DNA, it has always been GEDmatch's policy to inform users that the database could be used for other," he says. Police sources tell the Los Angeles Times that DeAngelo, 72, was living close to where the murders and rapes took place in the 1970s and '80s.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The ex-policeman suspected of being the Golden State Killer shared his DNA profile with a genealogical website, law enforcement sources tell the Los Angeles Times. The sources say Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, was living close to where the murders and rapes took place in the 1970s and '80s. The DNA found at the crime scene led investigators to a distant relative of DeAngelo who had shared his genetic profile on GEDmatch, the sources say. Paul Holes, the retired Contra Costa County DA who helped lead the investigation, tells the AP that he used his own DNA profile from Ancestry.com to learn how to use GEDmatch. The site returned a list of relatives—with names and emails—by degree of shared single nucleotide polymorphisms, or SNPs, which offer a genetic fingerprint. On average, you share 50% of your SNPs with a sibling, 25% with a half sibling, 12.5% with a first cousin, and 3.1% with a second cousin. The hits on DeAngelo came from third and fourth cousins, Holes says. Experts say GEDmatch is a good example of the potential danger of using genetic information for law enforcement purposes without proper safeguards. "Even though it is easy to think of this technology as something that is used just to track down serial killers, if we allow the government to use it with no accountability or no further safeguards, then all of our genetic information might be at risk for being used for things we don't want it to be used for," UC Berkeley law professor Katherine Roth tells the Times. DeAngelo has been charged with two murders and is expected to be arraigned Friday.

Flat_1024_summary: – For almost 40 years, Bill Bresnan has been writing love letters to his wife, Kirsten, every day. “They’re essentially a love diary,” he tells ABC News. “For example, I could pick out a day in 1982, and it’ll begin with the restaurant we ate in or a movie we saw and then a reaction to that.” The Toms River, NJ, couple met on the Long Island Railroad in 1974 and have been commuting to and from Long Island by train ever since. Flat_1024_summary: – It's that time of year again: time to welcome 2017 and make up for lost time caused by Earth's slowing rotation, Phys.org reports. According to the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service, the extra second will be used to align astronomical time with Coordinated Universal Time, which is "extremely stable and has been determined by atomic clocks since 1967," making the year's final minute 61 seconds long. The extra second is called a "leap second," and it's added every 18 months to keep the time difference between atomic time and astronomical time at less than 0.9 seconds. For those living in time zones outside of UTC, the timing will be determined by the time zone they live in. Google has come up with a different, "extremely elegant" plan: It will run the clocks on its Network Time Protocol servers 0.0014% slower over the next 10 hours before and 10 hours after the leap second, and "smear" the extrasecond over these 20 hours. The problem is that most computers and operating systems don't understand a 61st second. "In order for that to work, literally every device involved has to understand that something weird is going on, and that's only happening this one time," Wired quotes Google's blog post. Google is encouraging anyone running IT operations to ask it for the time.

Amazon and Microsoft have already tried the same thing in the past, and cloud companies such as Amazon and Akamai are planning to do the same this year. reference: – Lethal injection is just such a pleasant way to die. At least according to Florida state Rep. Brad Drake, who wants to put an end to the execution method in the state. He argues that Death Row killers shouldn't be allowed to "get off that easy"; the electric chair would be more appropriate he says—as would a firing squad. Drake this week filed a bill that would put an end to lethal injection and give convicts facing death the choice of the latter two, reports the AP. "I think if you ask a hundred people, not even talking to criminals, how would you like to die, if you were drowned, if you were shot, and if you say you were put to sleep, 90% of some of the people would say I want to be put to sleep," says the Republican, who apparently equates lethal injection with taking a permanent nap. "Let's put our pants back on the right way," Drake urges, adding that his proposed switch would force death row inmates to think about their punishment "every morning." And they'd be getting off easy, because, as reported by the Florida Current, if it were up to Drake, "we would just throw them off the Sunshine Skyway bridge and be done with it." Mediaite notes that Keith Olbermann is not a fan of the idea. (Click for another odd political push in Florida.)

Schalit's father says his son will need time to recover from psychological and physical wounds. "I am happy to be back in Israel, to be with my family, and to be reunited with my parents," Schalit said in a brief TV interview. "It's been a long five years, but I'm in good health." reference: – To call it controversial is putting it mildly: Harvard professor Karen L. King in September 2012 debuted an ancient papyrus now known as the "Gospel of Jesus' Wife" at a conference in Rome. The papyrus makes an explicit reference to the woman's existence with the line, "Jesus said to them, 'My wife...'" Now, extensive testing by professors from Columbia, Harvard, and MIT in the fields of electrical engineering, chemistry, and biology has found no indications that it is a modern forgery, per an article by King published today in the Harvard Theological Review. The Boston Globe says it most likely dates to eighth-century Egypt, and the chemical composition of its ink is in line with the carbon-based inks the people of that country used at the time. But the Globe cautions that a master forger could have accessed the proper materials, and that traditional ink-dating methods couldn't be used because the papyrus is so small: a fragment roughly 1.5-by-3 inches in size bearing just eight incomplete lines (translation here). The Review also published a rebuttal by Brown Egyptology professor Leo Depuydt, who points to "gross grammatical errors" he says no native speaker of Coptic would make, the New York Times reports. (More criticism of the papyrus here.) The new findings certainly don't prove that Jesus was married, a point that King has never challenged; she'd like to see the debate shift to discussions of the document's significance, and "questions like, 'Why does Jesus being married, or not, even matter?'" King was in 2011 asked to review the fragment at the request of its anonymous owner, who says he bought it more than a decade earlier from a collector who said he purchased it, along with five others, in East Germany in the '60s.
TreeSum_summary: – The so-called "Gospel of Jesus' Wife" isn't a forgery after all, Harvard professor Karen King writes in the Harvard Theological Review. "I don't buy the argument that this is sophisticated. I think it could be done in an afternoon by an undergraduate student," she tells the Boston Globe. King's argument is that the eight-line fragment appears to have been copied from a much earlier Greek text, perhaps composed in the second century, and that the forger may have "wanted to put his or her own spin on modern theological issues," such as the role of women and celibacy in Christianity. King pored over the original carbon-dating and ink testing done on the ancient papyrus and concluded that "such a combination of bumbling and sophistication seems extremely unlikely. I haven’t seen any argument that I find at all compelling that would indicate that it’s not genuine," says the director of New York University's Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, one of the world's top papyrologists. King introduced her finding in Rome 18 months ago. Her paper is being published today.

But per CNN, another Marshall ended up stealing the spotlight: the congressman's son, who started dabbing—for the uninitiated, Wikipedia describes it as "a dance move in which the dancer simultaneously drops the head while raising an arm and the elbow in a gesture that has been noted to resemble sneezing," and often employed by the Carolina Panthers' Cam Newton to celebrate a touchdown. TreeSum_summary: – There's a new dance on the block, and it's being hailed as the "next big thing" in hip-hop. The BBC reports on the so-called dab, or the "dabbing," a move that involves dropping one's head into the bent crook of an arm, while raising the opposite arm out straight in a parallel direction. It was first popularized by Cam Newton during a Nov. 15 NFL game, in which the Carolina Panthers quarterback dropped his head into his teammates' faces after scoring a touchdown. The move has since gone viral, appearing in everything from James Corden's Carpool Karaoke to Ellen DeGeneres' show to even the White House. "What started as a regional down South adlib is quickly becoming a masterful maneuver in clubs and on street corners. It's called dabbin'," XXL magazine reported in August 2015. Hip-hop artists initially thought to have invented the dance include Migos, Skippa Da Flippa, Peewee Longway, Jose Guapo, and Rich the Kid, but OG Maco called out Migos for saying they were the originators when it was actually Skippa da Flippa. The controversy was cleared up when Migos confirmed Skippa as the originator of the dance.

TreeSum_summary: – The death of Melania Trump's mother-in-law has been ruled a heart attack, according to a rep for the first lady. The rep said Melania, who is in her mid-40s, "is with her family at this time and would like to thank the many people who have reached out with thoughts and prayers for her during this difficult time," the New York Daily News reports. Earlier, President Trump weighed in on the death of his father, Fred Trump, after the Telegraph reported that he was a "fierce presence" with "more than one heart" and a "revered presence" in Congress. "I have a very good relationship with my father and I don't see any reason why he couldn't be even a little more fearsome," Trump tweeted.

Flat_1024_summary: – The first study to show that insects have the ability to learn and pass on knowledge has been published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and it's being hailed as a "landmark" example of how science can apply social science to real-world problems. Researchers trained three groups of bees—two pre-trained, and two not-pre-trained—to pull strings from an artificial flower placed under a table. The bees were then shown clips of them pulling the strings, which they'd earned by foraging for the flower. Researchers found that bees who had already learned to pull the strings were more likely to continue. In one experiment, they spent 10 minutes looking for a blue flower with a string attached and were able to pull it off in five minutes. In another, they had observers watch as they pulled the flower— Bees don't just figure out where to find food—they're able to figure out how to find it. The study's lead author, a professor of entomology, explains to the New York Times that the blue flower is a "window into the world of bees," allowing the bees to see what's around them and what they need to do to get the reward. To test this, researchers had bees in two—one with more—and watched as other bees in the same colony pulled the string in different ways. When paired with their peers, the trained bees took 2.5 times longer topull the string. "cultural transmission does not require the high cognitive sophistication specific to humans, nor is a distinctive feature of humans," the study author tells the Washington Post.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – For years, cognitive scientist Lars Chittka has been pestering his colleagues at Queen Mary University of London for answers to a nagging question: Could we get our small-brained bees to solve tasks that would impress a bird cognition researcher? In a series of experiments, the researchers found that bumble bees can not only learn to pull a string to retrieve a reward, but they can also learn this trick from other bees, even though they have no experience with such a task in nature. The study "successfully challenges the notion that 'big brains' are necessary' for new skills to," the researchers write in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. To train 15 bumblebees to pull strings from a blue flower using their legs, researchers trained three bees in a group of three to pull an artificial flower from under a Plexiglas table with a solution that would reward them with a reward of their own. The bees then went out to forage for the flower, and when they came back to the hive, they were given the same reward and asked to pull the string. The problem is that the bees didn't get a clear sense of where the string was coming from until they pulled it back, reports the Los Angeles Times. The takeaway? "cultural transmission does not require cultural transmission," says a study co-author.

Just a week ago, Emirates led the competition 8-1 and needed just one more win to take the cup. But the Americans ran off a long string of victories, and even though Emirates had a slight edge in today's race, they managed to pull ahead by a small margin at the start and then hold off the Kiwis down the stretch. Oracle owner Larry Ellison skipped an Oracle conference to celebrate with his crew, and New Zealand Prime Minister John Key was less than impressed. "It was Ellison's vision that helped bring these catamarans to the competition, providing great entertainment that will surely be a boon to the sport," he said, according to USA Today.

Flat_1024_summary: – Those with at least one copy of the APOE gene are twice as likely to develop age-related macular degeneration, which is a leading cause of vision loss in older people, according to a study published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Researchers looked at the health histories of more than 5,600 people around the world, the New York Times reports. They found that those with one, two, or three copies of the gene, known as e2, e3, or e4, were twice as prone to develop macular degeneration than those with only one or two copies. They also had higher levels of cholesterol and other fatty materials in their blood, which can lead to the formation of yellow skin growths called xanthomas. "Our study shows for the first time that there is a direct relationship between APOE genetic variants and an increased risk of macular degeneration," the study's lead author says in a press release. "Further research is needed to clarify what role, if any, ApoE gene variants play in the development of age- related macular degeneration." The researchers say their study is the first to show a link between the gene and macular degeneration.

document:
Variants of apolipoprotein E have been studied extensively as risk factors for many different conditions. For example, APOE alleles have been shown to influence the risk of cardiovascular diseases. People who carry at least one copy of the APOE e4 allele have an increased chance of developing atherosclerosis, which is an accumulation of fatty deposits and scar-like tissue in the lining of the arteries. This progressive narrowing of the arteries increases the risk of heart attack and stroke. 
 
 ...
reference: – You have one of six possible variations of the APOE gene, having inherited one variant—e2, e3, or e4—from each parent. Reporting in the journal Neuron, University of Hawaii researchers found that the brain development of children as young as preschool age with two copies of e4 or one of e4 and one of e2 seem most adversely affected—an intriguing find in light of previous research that has linked the e4 variant to Alzheimer's. Researchers scanned the brains of 1,187 healthy people between the ages of 3 and 20 and found, for instance, that the size of the hippocampus tends to be smaller in those with the e2/e4 combination. They also found some kids with e4 didn't perform as well on tests of memory, though they caught up with their peers by age 10, reports HealthDay News. And while brain researcher Rebecca Knickmeyer, who didn't participate in the study but wrote an accompanying editorial, says the variants aren't necessarily predictive and people shouldn't start testing their kids, the research suggests that Alzheimer's may in fact be a developmental disorder, not strictly an aging one, reports the Los Angeles Times. That raises the possibility that adjustments to "diet or cognitive training" early on could change someone's "trajectory," per Knickmeyer. Three in four people have at least one copy of e3, which seems to offer a protective effect. About 14% of people have an e4 variant, which has been linked with an elevated risk of Alzheimer's, but Knickmeyer points out that there are many Alzheimer's patients without e4, and many with e4 who never develop Alzheimer's. (Some research suggests that memories lost to Alzheimer's are actually retrievable.)
TreeSum_summary: – Good news for those who suffer from Alzheimer's: A new study suggests that people with certain genetic variants are less likely to develop the disease, the New York Times reports. The study out of the University of California, San Francisco, found that people who had at least one copy of a gene variant known as APOE (e4, e3, or e4) were about half as likely to be diagnosed with the disease as people with at least two copies of the gene variant e2. The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, didn't look at a cause-and-effect relationship, but a researcher tells the Times that the findings suggest that "people with these variants may be at higher risk for Alzheimer’s because they have more of the disease-related plaques and tangles in their brains." APOE is one of six genes known to increase a person's chances of developing the disease.

Flat_1024_summary: – The Supreme Court wrestled with the future of the 1965 Voting Rights Act on Monday, with its more conservative justices appearing to tip the balance in favor of striking down a key part of the law. If the law is struck down, nine states, mostly in the South, would no longer need to get permission from the federal government before changing their voting procedures. The justices heard 90 minutes of arguments in a case brought by Shelby County, Ala., which says the law violates the Constitution's equal protection clause, the New York Times reports. The court "seems committed to invalidating Section 5 of the voting rights act and requiring Congress to revisit the formula for requiring preclearance of voting changes," writes ScotusBlog. "The vote seems quite likely to be five to four." The more liberal justices pressed both the narrow argument that an Alabama county was not a proper plaintiff because it inevitably would be covered and the broader argument that there was a sufficient record to justify the current formula. But the more conservative majority was plainly not persuaded by either point. It is unlikely that the Court will write an opinion forbidding a preclearance regime. But it may be difficult politically for Congress to enact a new measure."
Flat_Overlap_summary: – The Supreme Court today struck down a key part of the 1965 Voting Rights Act that has required the feds to make sure that states with a history of racial segregation don't change their voting rules before the change takes place. The decision is a huge victory for the Obama administration, which has been pushing hard to get the law passed in the wake of the Trayvon Martin shooting, reports the New York Times. But the court did not strike down the entire act, only part of it. It held that parts of it that needed "preclearance" from the Justice Department needed no such approval. The court "seems committed to invalidating Section 5 of the voting rights act and requiring Congress to revisit the formula for requiring preclearance of voting changes," writes ScotusBlog. It is unlikely that the Court will write an opinion forbidding a preclearance regime. But it may be difficult politically for Congress to enact a new measure."

reference: – Marijuana enthusiast Snoop Dogg launched a website yesterday, and of course it's all about weed. Merry Jane, which the rapper announced at TechCrunch Disrupt, is what TechCrunch describes as an "information hub" for all things pot; Snoop says it will be a sort of cannabis encyclopedia giving users "all they need to know." There will be shows and videos centered around the marijuana lifestyle, including a food show (cooking with cannabis or pairing meals with pot), celebrity interview videos, and a show called "Deflowered," which will feature people doing something for the first time. There will also be editorial content looking at marijuana news from legalization to pot policy to the business side and the politics of pot. And, of course, there will be a database featuring all sorts of cannabis strains so that users can decide which one is right for them and where they can find it. It sounds pretty high-tech, featuring "high-res rotating imagery for every product listed" and allowing users to search via type, flavor, or even symptom. Right now the site is in beta ("I'm givn away 420 sneak peeks a day," Snoop tweeted. "Sign up now at http://MERRYJANE.com & put 1 n the air !!") but it will be open to the public within the next few weeks. (Click to read about eight other celebrities with surprising side businesses.)
TreeSum_summary: – If you're a stoner, Snoop Dogg has just the thing. He's just launched Merry Jane, a lifestyle website that he says will be the " encyclopedia of cannabis," TechCrunch reports. The site, which launched at TechCrunch Disrupt in San Francisco yesterday, will have video content covering everything from cooking to how-to's, as well as news on the marijuana industry. "All they need to know," Snoop said at the event, adding that Merry Jane will be "the encyclopedia of the cannabis world." The site will also connect users to local marijuana dispensaries. "There are so many people in the closet, and we are giving them an opportunity to come out of the closet and just admit they like to smoke," he said. "I'm a smoker, my name is Snoop Dogg, and I've been stoner for a long time."

Flat_1024_summary: – Antonin Scalia has been found dead at a West Texas ranch, the AP reports. The Supreme Court justice was a guest at Cibolo Creek Ranch, a 30,000-acre resort south of Marfa. The 79-year-old Scalia arrived at the ranch Friday night for a private party with about 40 people, a US Marshals Service spokeswoman says. He left the party and retired to bed earlier than others. When he failed to appear at breakfast, a person involved with the ranch went to his room, where he discovered his body. A priest was called to administer last rites. A government source tells CNN that Scalia told friends he was feeling ill Friday night, and the group he was with left without him Saturday morning. Someone at the Ranch went in to check on him and found him unresponsive. The cause of death hasn't been revealed, but Scalia is said to have suffered a heart attack and died peacefully. The news—which comes as the court is hearing arguments this week on gay marriage, affirmative action, and affirmative action for the first time in nearly a decade—is being met with tributes from across the political spectrum. Scalia was "incredibly disarming and charming in his own way," says USA Today reporter Joan Biskupic, who wrote a biography.

The Supreme Court justice was a guest at Cibolo Creek Ranch, a 30,000-acre resort south of Marfa. When he failed to appear at breakfast, a person involved with the ranch went to his room, where he discovered his body. A priest was called to administer last rites. A federal official says there was no evidence of foul play and that Scalia died of natural causes. Scalia had been feeling ill and didn't get up for breakfast on Saturday. "He was an unrelenting defender of religious liberty, free speech, federalism, the constitutional separation of powers and private property rights," Texas Gov. Greg Abbott says in a statement, per CBS News. "All liberty-loving Americans should be in mourning." Scalia was the longest-serving justice on the court and the first Italian-American to sit on it. Here's a look at some of the coverage surrounding Scalia's death.

As Mediaite points out, Limbaugh is far from the only controversial radio host.

Flat_1024_summary: – Satellite images show North Korea is digging a third tunnel at its Punggye-ri nuclear test site, which "would represent a change in how we view North Korea's nuclear weapons testing program," writes Jeffrey Lewis at the Monterey Institute of International Studies. "The pace of testing to date appears to have been constrained—either by political pressure, a lack of fissile material, or both." But if the excavation at the South Portal is a tunnel complex, North Korea "might have plans to conduct more than two or three additional detonations in that area alone." The North "will probably seek to continue developing smaller nuclear weapons that can arm the country's ballistic missiles," Lewis writes. "They claim to have developed a miniaturized device, but we do not know how small these weapons are." Meanwhile, Pyongyang is threatening to conduct a "new form of nuclear test" in response to the UN Security Council's condemnation of its recent ballistic missile launches. "It is absolutely intolerable that the United Nations Security Council, turning a blind eye to the US madcap nuclear war exercises, 'denounced' the Korean People's Army's self-defensive rocket launching drills and called them a 'violation of resolutions' and a 'threat to international peace and security' and is set to take an 'appropriate step,'" the North's foreign ministry said in a statement, per Reuters.

Jeffrey Lewis, director of the East Asia Nonproliferation Program at California's James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies, tells the Los Angeles Times that if North Korea can access "regular amounts of fissile material, "if it could be preparing for a number of nuclear tests."

reference: – A father and former bicycle puller is gearing up for major surgery at the Dhaka Medical College Hospital in Bangladesh to remove more than 11 pounds of bark-like warts on his hands and feet that have earned him the nickname "tree man." The 26-year-old tells AFP he has suffered from what doctors call epidermodysplasia verruciformis for a decade, but that the growths dramatically increased in size and number four years ago. "Slowly I lost all my ability to work," says Abul Bajandar. "There are now dozens of two to three inch roots in both my hands. And there are some small ones in my legs." The genetic skin disease is so rare that one doctor says there are only three known cases in the world. At first Bajandar says he tried to cut the growths off himself but found it too painful, and when he went to a village homeopath his condition worsened. And while the six-person medical team is already starting to perform blood tests and biopsies, they describe Bajandar as too malnourished and weak for multi-stage plastic surgery, reports the Daily Star. "Doctors said I might need to stay here for six months," he said. His mother and sister are with him now, while his wife and 3-year-old daughter will join him soon. "Even here at the hospital, hundreds have already gathered" to try to get a look at Bajander, says his sister. Surgery is expected to start in three weeks, and the hospital is not charging Bajandar. (This baby's skin blisters when simply touched.)
TreeSum_summary: – A 26-year-old man in Bangladesh has been given the all-clear to undergo plastic surgery after doctors discovered he has a rare and incurable disease that causes tree warts on his hands and feet. Abul Bajandar was admitted to a hospital in the capital, Dhaka, on Friday and doctors say he is in good condition, the Daily Star reports. "The patient appears malnourished and is still too weak for immediate surgery," says a doctor at the hospital, where the surgery will be carried out over the next three weeks. "Doctors said I might need to stay here for six months," says Abul, who has been living in a cabin in the hospital's burn unit since Friday. He says he was diagnosed with tree warts, caused by a virus, when he was just a few years old. "My hands used to be good, but now they're not so good," he says. "I can't even hold a bottle of water." Abul's mother and sister accompanied him to the hospital on Friday. The Bangladeshi government has decided to waive the costs of the surgery, which will be performed by a team of doctors at the state-run hospital.

Michael Cohen, citing government raids on his home and offices, filed papers saying he plans to plead the Fifth in connection with the civil lawsuit "due to the ongoing criminal investigation by the FBI and US Attorney for the Southern District of New York," CNN reports. "Never before in our nation’s history has the attorney for the sitting President invoked the 5th Amend in connection with issues surrounding the President," he tweeted. He also tweeted a link to a Washington Post story that noted Trump slammed Hillary Clinton staffers in 2016 for invoking the Fifth during the investigation of her email server—but invoked the amendment himself during his 1990 divorce from Ivana Trump, dodging no fewer than 97 deposition questions, mostly about other women. It's a planet much like our own Earth—about the same size, with the same mixture of rock and iron, and it orbits a star like our sun—except that Kepler 78b is an infernal ball of fire. Located less than a million miles from its host star—that's 1% of the distance between Earth and our sun—its temperature ranges between 3,500 and 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. Adds an expert, per LiveScience: "This planet is an enigma. It couldn't have formed in place because you can't form a planet inside a star." But while astronomers are baffled as to how the planet got there, they're fairly certain it shows friendlier Earthlike planets are still out there.

reference: – A young actor and singer has been found dead in his suburban Los Angeles home at age 20, reports Variety. Jackson Odell, best known for a role as Ari Caldwell on the ABC sitcom The Goldbergs, was found unresponsive in his Tarzana residence on Friday. The cause of death was not clear, and the Los Angeles County coroner is investigating. Odell appeared on the ABC show in seasons 1 and 2, and he also appeared on The Fosters, Modern Family, Arrested Development, and iCarly, as well as in the 2011 movie Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer, notes the AP. Odell also was a singer-songwriter, with several videos on YouTube and songwriting credits on the 2018 movie Forever My Girl. Odell's family posted a note on his Twitter page saying they are trying "to make sense of our immeasurable loss privately."
TreeSum_summary: – A young actor best known for his role as Ari Caldwell on The Goldbergs has died at the age of 20. Jackson Odell was found unresponsive in his Tarzana, Calif., residence June 8, the Los Angeles County Coroner's Office confirmed to Variety. The cause of death has not been released, pending an autopsy. Odell, who also had credits on The Fosters, Modern Family, iCarly, and Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer, had been involved in show business since he was 12. The New York Daily News reports that Odell's body was found by a friend who went to check on him after he failed to show up for work.

Flat_1024_summary: – Violence is coursing through the world's newest country, and the US embassy in Juba is telling Americans to get out as soon as possible. The State Department today issued a travel warning, saying Americans should "consider their personal security situation and seriously reconsider their plans to remain" in South Sudan, the AP reports. The warning supersedes an earlier travel warning issued in October. Fighting has broken out between rebels loyal to former deputy president Riek Machar and forces loyal to President Salva Kiir. The UN warns that up to 100,000 people have fled their homes in the capital, Juba, and that "scores, if not hundreds, of casualties" have been reported, Reuters reports. "It's really not a minor incident," says a UN official. The US embassy said on its Twitter account late yesterday that that all of its citizens in the country should "depart immediately."

The UN says some 15,000 to 20,000 people have sought refuge in two UNMISS compounds in Juba. "It's dozens and dozens, scores of casualties, it's really not a minor incident," says a French UN rep.

Flat_1024_summary: – The SEC is planning a major crackdown on high-frequency trading, a practice that has been blamed for everything from the infamous "flash crash" of 2010 to the European debt crisis. Under the plan, all proprietary traders using algorithms to buy and sell stocks would have to register with the SEC, Bloomberg reports. "The SEC should not roll back the technology clock or prohibit algorithmic trading, but we are assessing the extent to which specific elements of the computer-driven trading environment may be working against investors rather than for them," SEC chief Mary Jo White told a conference yesterday. The SEC will also review the dozens of order types on stock exchanges, which it says can "create conflicts of interest and raise serious questions about whether such conflicts can be effectively managed," the New York Times reports. Meanwhile, the SEC is also planning to monitor so-called "dark pools"— venues that don't publish bids and offers—and other secretive trading practices. "We will not stand idly by as market makers and market participants attempt to undermine the integrity of the securities markets," White said.

reference: – Bogged down by some $465 million in debt, Reader's Digest publisher RDA Holdings has filed for bankruptcy—again. Last night's Chapter 11 filing was the publisher's second in 3 ½ years, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company says this second bankruptcy will only make it stronger, allowing it to focus on its North American business and cut its debt to $100 million. "It’s a very good new lease on life," CEO Bob Guth tells Bloomberg. Guth is the company's third CEO since its last bankruptcy, which, of course, was also supposed to give it a new lease on life; the bankruptcy judge at the time declared that the company would emerge "on a very healthy and viable basis." Instead, the pressures facing the print industry have weighed on the company—its most recent earnings showed revenue down 26% on the year.
TreeSum_summary: – The parent company of Reader's Digest has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the second time in three years, Bloomberg reports. RDA Holding Co., which owns the Digest, Allrecipes, and Every Day with Rachel Ray brands, says it has more than $1.1 billion in assets and $1.2 billion in liabilities and plans to emerge from bankruptcy as a smaller company. "We just had a complicated company that had to be simplified so that those iconic brands and those great customer relationships could thrive with continued emphasis on new formats and new audiences but with the same brand and the same products," says CEO Michael Berenbrink. The company's biggest unsecured creditors are the Federal Trade Commission and Luxor Capital Group of New York, with a $10 million loan and an $8 million claim, according to court papers. "The key message here is that we have a lot of confidence in the future of the business based upon the success of the ongoing operational transformation, but we haven’t had as much success with the balance sheet side of it and we need this process to help accelerate that," Reader’s Digest CEO Robert Guth tells Bloomberg.

Flat_1024_summary: – "Having an adult child of the president who is actively engaged in the work of the administration is new ground," Jamie Gorelick, an attorney for Ivanka Trump, tells Politico. "Our view is that the conservative approach is for Ivanka to voluntarily comply with the rules that would apply if she were a government employee, even though she is not." The New York Times reports Trump has moved into her own office on the West Wing's second floor and is in the process of getting a security clearance to access classified information. Gorelick says Trump will serve as her father's "eyes and ears" and provide advice on a wide range of issues. Ethics experts say Trump's move into the White House has raised conflict-of-interest concerns because she won't be subject to the same ethics rules as government employees—and because she hasn't sold off any assets to comply with those rules. "There's recognition that they're in very uncertain territory here," says Norm Eisen, the former ethics czar in the Obama administration. "The better thing to do would be to concede she is Subject to the Rules. It would create some outside accountability, because if she can voluntarily subject herself to the rules, she can voluntaryly un-subject herself to them." Trump says she will set up a trust overseen by her brother-in-law, Josh Kushner, and his sister, Nicole Meyer, that will be in charge of day-to-day operations of the Ivanka Trump brand. Ethics experts have raised concerns about the unprecedented situation in which a president's adult child is now serving as a de facto White House adviser, though a White House spokeswoman says Trump's role was approved by the White House counsel's office and the office of government ethics "worked through" the conflict-of-interest issues.

Flat_1024_summary: – "Imagine opening the door to your humidor and sinking into your favorite leather lounge chair—that's the sensation," Ford design manager Aileen Barraza tells the Dallas Morning News of the 2018 F-Series Super Duty Limited, Ford's latest luxury pickup. The truck, which debuted at the State Fair of Texas on Thursday, can top out at $94,455, making it the "most luxurious and advanced heavy-duty pickup truck ever created by Ford," the company says in a press release. The base model F-250 starts at $32,890, while the top-of-the-line F-450 starts at $87,100, Consumerist reports. But if you add in the state's 6% or 7% sales tax, that price jumps to nearly $100,000. "We created this new truck to answer the call for even more premium choices in the Super Duty range as we see more and more truck customers trending to more premium models," Ford trucks marketing manager Todd Eckert says in the statement. Included in the new Limited's amenities are heated and ventilated seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a 360-degree camera, adaptive cruise control, lane-keep alert, and a panoramic moonroof. The 6.7-liter Power Stroke V8 diesel engine has 440 horsepower and 925 pound-feet of torque, so it should pull even the largest trailers. The Limited will arrive at Ford dealerships this winter in single or dual-rear-wheel configurations.

Flat_1024_summary: – The leader of the Kansas Senate says she won't support a bill that would allow businesses to refuse service to gay couples on religious grounds, the Kansas City Star reports. Senate President Susan Wagle says the bill, which passed the House this week, "negatively impacts both small and large businesses," and she's sending it to the Senate Judiciary Committee for a "thorough review and revisions." The bill would let businesses and government employees invoke their religious beliefs as a basis for not providing services to same-sex couples, but critics say it could apply to thousands of government workers who might cite religious convictions to get out of doing their duties. "Religious liberty is alive and well in Kansas, and religion shouldn't be used to discriminate," the ACLU's Kansas advocacy director tells the Star. The bill's supporters say it's needed to protect people with a "sincerely held religious belief" against gay marriage. But gay-rights groups say the bill would allow discrimination against gay couples, and the ACLU is "pleased to hear that (Wagle) saw this bill for what it is," an effort to legalize discrimination in Kansas. Click for more.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – A bill that would have allowed businesses and government employees in Kansas to refuse service to gay people on the basis of religious objections has been withdrawn after a backlash from the state's business community, the Kansas City Star reports. The bill would allow people to sue the state if they refuse to provide services related to marriages or civil unions that are contrary to their faith. Supporters said it was needed to protect people with a "sincerely held religious belief" against same-sex marriage in the wake of recent court decisions. But critics said the bill did not go beyond marriage. "Religious liberty is alive and well in Kansas," said the ACLU's Kansas advocacy director. "and religion shouldn't be used to discriminate." The bill was withdrawn after Senate President Susan Wagle, a Republican, said she had sent it to the Senate Judiciary Committee for a thorough review and revisions. "A strong majority of my members support laws that define traditional marriage, protect religious institutions, and protect individuals from being forced to violate their personal moral values," Wagle said in a statement. "However, my members also don't condone discrimination."

Flat_1024_summary: – Bodybuilding star Rich Piana was given two doses of Narcan and placed in a medically induced coma after he collapsed while getting a haircut Monday, and now police say he had 20 bottles of steroids in his home at the time, TMZ reports. According to the police report, Piana's girlfriend, Chanel, told authorities the 46-year-old former Mr. California bodybuilding champ had been juicing for more than 20 years and admitted to using steroids. Flat_1024_summary: – There's no right or wrong way to smile, according to a new study published in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. Researchers found that people who tend to smile more often are more likely to be happy, and that the more often they smile, the more likely they are to feel better, LiveScience reports. But there's a catch: For people who don't naturally smile, a smile is likely just "an attempt to become happy," the study's lead author says. "In practice, I think people can think about their own beliefs about smiling, see how they feel about how frequently they smile and adapt either their beliefs or their behaviors to make themselves feel better," he adds.
Flat_Overlap_summary: – If you're feeling blue today, you might want to stop smiling. A new study finds that people who don't tend to smile when they're happy tend to feel worse when they do, reports LiveScience. Researchers at the University of California-San Diego set up three experiments in which subjects were asked to rate how happy they were on a scale of 1 to 10. The more often they smiled, the better they felt. "More generally, we think that making people who are feeling bad smile could backfire and make them feel worse, because they may interpret smiling as trying to become happy," says the lead researcher in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. "Smiling frequently would remind them of being not happy."

Flat_1024_summary: – Farmers, lumberjacks, and fishermen are among the professions with the highest suicide rates in the US, according to a new CDC report. The suicide rate for all professions was 84.5 per 100,000 people in 2014, the highest rate in the world. Among men, it was 90.5, while for women it was 47.5, the New York Times reports. The study looked at 12,312 suicides in 17 states in 2012. Researchers didn't explore the reasons behind the differences, but they say three factors could be at play: more Americans are working in these fields, the aging population is more likely to work in them, and the Internet has made it easier for people to find jobs and resources, the AP reports. "There's a lot of stigma around these types of jobs," says the study's lead author. "A lot of people don't feel that they can reach out for help if they need it." The highest suicide rate was seen in carpenters, miners, electricians, and people who work on construction. Dentists, doctors, and other health care professionals had an 80% lower suicide rate than the farmers, fishermen, and lumberjacks. It's not clear what the suicide rate is just for farmers. Or for mathematicians. The highest rate of suicide was among women in protective service occupations, with 14.2 per 100,000, while the lowest rate was among men in education, training, and library occupations, at 7.5.

Food-safety bill clears key Senate hurdle 
 
 By J. Taylor Rushing - 
 
 After a year of waiting in line, legislation to promote food safety on Wednesday moved toward passage during the Senate’s lame-duck session. 
 
 Almost a year to the day after a unanimous committee vote, the long-stalled food-safety bill by Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) passed on a 74-25 procedural vote. 
 
 The Senate’s Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) Committee passed the legislation on Nov. 18, 2009, in ...
reference: – A major food safety bill cleared a Senate hurdle today, but it's getting friction from a group you might not expect: locavores. They want small family farms to be exempt from the sweeping new regulations and are pushing for an amendment to that effect from Montana Democrat Jon Tester. Two high-profile names from the food world are on board, notes Food Safety News: Michael Pollan and Eric Schlosser. "S 510 is the most important food safety legislation in a generation," they said in a joint statement. "The Tester amendment will make it even more effective, strengthening food safety rules while protecting small farmers and producers. We both think this is the right thing to do." Another potential holdup is an amendment from Dianne Feinstein to put limits on the use of the plastics chemical bisphenol-A in food and beverage containers, notes the AP. Negotiations with both senators continue as the Senate proceeds with the bill, which would still have to be reconciled with a House version from last year. Time is running out to get that down in the lame-duck session. The Hill has more details on the proposed new FDA powers.
TreeSum_summary: – The Senate today took a big step toward passing food safety legislation that has been in the works for years. The cloture vote, which eliminates the threat of filibuster, cleared the way for debate on the bipartisan bill, which would give the FDA more authority to test food, order recalls, and penalize companies that sell contaminated food, reports Food Safety News. The measure is expected to pass the Senate later today or tomorrow, notes the Hill. Two controversial amendments, one from Democrat Jon Tester of Montana and the other from Democrat Dianne Feinstein, are still in play, but interest groups are working behind the scenes to hammer out deals. "I've always been taught that patience is a virtue. We're thrilled and we're hopeful that we'll get the bill to the floor soon," says the director of Pew's food-safety campaign.

Flat_1024_summary: – Twenty years after the world's worst nuclear accident, the Chernobyl exclusion zone is a much better place for wildlife than it was before the disaster, according to a new study. Researchers say a long-term census of mammals in the area—including wild boar, roe deer, elk, and wolves—found "much higher" numbers than they were before the April 1986 disaster, the BBC reports. "The numbers of animals we see in Chernobyl is similar to the populations in uncontaminated nature reserves," says lead researcher Jim Smith of the University of Portsmouth. "This doesn't mean radiation is good for wildlife, just that the effects of human habitation, including hunting, farming, and forestry, are a lot worse," a University of South Carolina biologist who wasn't part of the study tells Phys.org. "Once have left an area the wildlife appear to thrive—even if the habitat is laced with radiation." The study, published in Current Biology, compared four nearby nature reserves that were uncontaminated by the accident to the exclusion zone and found that the abundance of wolves is more than seven times greater there than in the uncontaminated reserves. "These unique data showing a wide range of animals thriving within miles of a major nuclear accident illustrate the resilience of wildlife populations when freed from the pressures of humans," a study co-author says in a press release. (An earlier study found that half of all mammals on Earth are contaminated by radiation.)
Flat_Overlap_summary: – Twenty-three years after the world's worst nuclear accident, the Chernobyl exclusion zone still has plenty of wildlife—including wolves, elk, wild boar, and roe deer, LiveScience reports. "It's very likely that wildlife numbers at Chernobyl are much higher than they were before the accident," says a co-author of a new study in Current Biology. "This doesn't mean radiation is good for wildlife, just that the effects of human habitation, including hunting, farming, and forestry, are a lot worse." The study compared four nearby nature reserves that were free of radiation from the accident, and found that the abundance of wolves is more than seven times greater there than in the uncontaminated reserves. "These unique data showing a wide range of animals thriving within miles of a major nuclear accident illustrate the resilience of wildlife populations when freed from the pressures of humans," says the University of Georgia researcher. But a biologist not involved with the study tells Grist, "Obviously I am not condoning nuclear accidents for the sake of wildlife! Far from it. But hopefully some good can come from it."

Unearthed grave sheds light on Batavia shipwreck mass murder 
 
 Updated 
 
 Secrets from one of the nation's most horrific maritime mass murders have been unearthed on a tiny island off Western Australia's coast. 
 
 A new grave has been discovered almost four centuries after the Batavia was wrecked on Morning Reef, within the Abrolhos Islands. 
 
 The Dutch East India vessel was on its maiden voyage when it wrecked with more than 300 people on board. 
 
 The survivors managed to swim to the ne...
reference: – More details from "one of the darkest chapters of Australia's maritime history" are coming to light, nearly 400 years after they occurred. On June 4, 1629, the Dutch East India ship the Batavia was downed by a reef on its maiden voyage. Most of the roughly 340 people aboard managed to reach nearby Beacon Island, off Western Australia, with the ship's captain setting off in search of help in a longboat. What happened in July of that year was gruesome: The West Australian reports that more than 120 people, among them women and children, were massacred by a group of mutineers led by undermerchant Jeronimus Cornelisz: Some were felled by musket fire or swords, others poisoned or drowned. Upon the captain's return, Cornelisz and many of his men were executed, reports the BBC. The Batavia's wreck was found in 1963, and a mass grave on the island was uncovered in 1999. Australia's ABC reports that the final day of searching the island during a 2013 expedition surfaced a tooth. Upon returning, archaeologists searched the area where the tooth was uncovered and have now found the island's 11th skeleton—with an archaeologist explaining it's the first to have been found using archaeology, while the others found to date were uncovered "by accident." Two musket balls were recovered near the remains, which are believed to be that of a youth. Jeremy Green, the WA Museum's head of maritime archaeology, says it doesn't appear the remains and the tooth are linked, however, indicating there may be another grave nearby. He frames the importance of uncovering more: "This was the first time that Europeans lived in Australia—albeit it wasn't in the mainland but it was here—so it's the oldest known European habitation in Australia." (The tragic story behind three partial skeletons was recently revealed, more than 160 years later.)
TreeSum_summary: – Beacon Island off Western Australia is home to "one of the darkest chapters of Australia's maritime history": the 1629 sinking of the Dutch East India ship the Batavia, which went down there with more than 300 people on board. The survivors made it to the island, but 40 of them drowned. Now, almost 400 years later, researchers say they've uncovered a new grave on the island—one that's "very close" to the one where a human tooth was found in 1999, reports the BBC. Beacon Island has been home to 11 skeletons since the 60s, but the latest find is the first to be identified as an adolescent, reports the West Australian. Two musket balls were found near the remains, which are being examined by a forensic team. "This was the first time that Europeans lived in Australia—albeit it wasn't in the mainland but it was here—so it's the oldest known European habitation in Australia," says Jeremy Green, head of maritime archaeology at the WA Museum. "It's got to be important." It's not clear how the teen died, but "we know many of those people died in the water. Presumably they were disposed of in surface conditions." Researchers hope to learn more about him and the other survivors, who were murdered by a group of mutineers.

Flat_1024_summary: – A Florida woman has become the first person in the US to test positive for the Zika virus after traveling to an area of Brazil where the virus is rampant, USA Today reports. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a global emergency, and the Florida Department of Health is advising women who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant to avoid traveling to areas affected by the virus. The Aedes aegypti mosquito is responsible for 90% of Zika cases in the continental US and more than 90% of Guillain-Barre cases in Latin America and the Caribbean. It's also responsible for 40% of microcephaly cases in babies born to women who contracted the virus while pregnant. "It's an explosive pandemic," the New York Times quotes Dr. Anthony Fauci as saying.

Two people in Texas have tested positive for the virus, the first such cases in the US, the Dallas Morning News reports. One man had sexual contact with a woman who returned from Venezuela, while the other man had sex with the woman after returning to the US. Both patients had traveled to Brazil, where officials have confirmed two cases of the virus through blood transfusions. In Brazil, more than 5,600 cases of microcephaly have been reported since October, USA Today reports. The virus can also cause Guillain-Barre, a rare condition that causes temporary paralysis of the brain.

reference: – Nelson Mandela is out of the hospital and recuperating at home after his latest health scare, but that doesn't mean the fight over the 94-year-old's money can't begin in earnest. Daughters Makaziwe and Zenani Mandela have sued to oust the directors of two companies that pull in boatloads of money from the sale of Mandela's handprints, reports the Star of South Africa. (Headline: "War over Madiba millions.") The daughters say the three men controlling the companies—including Mandela attorney George Bizos—were never properly appointed but have refused to step down. Bizos, though, who defended Mandela in court during the apartheid era, says that Mandela himself appointed them five years ago, reports AP. The daughters are just trying to "get their hands on the money," he said, which is a little confusing because the companies were set up to funnel money to Mandela's family in the first place.
TreeSum_summary: – Nelson Mandela's children have launched a court battle against two South African directors they say are blocking their father's wishes. Zenani and Makaziwe Mandela have asked the Johannesburg High Court to remove advocate George Bizos, businessman Tokyo Sexwale, and lawyer Bally Chuene from companies that channel "proceeds of Madiba's handprints" into the accounts of the companies for Mandela and his children's benefit, the Star reports. The companies are worth millions and have been the subject of a long-running dispute over who has the right to sell the handprints. The daughters say they were never officially appointed by Mandela as major shareholders or directors and that the directors have "failed to carry out their duties as directors with due care, skill, and diligence," according to court papers. They say the refusal of the directors to resign is "not in the best interest of beneficiaries of the shareholder (Mandela’s children and grandchildren)." Mandela is in poor health, the Telegraph reports.

Flat_1024_summary: – How long would it take to reach the other side of the planet if you jumped in and let gravity pull you through? For decades, physics students have been asked to calculate that time and have been taught that the correct answer is 42 minutes. Now, a more realistic analysis has lopped 4 minutes off that estimate. "This is the kind of paper we love," says David Jackson, editor of the American Journal of Physics. The new calculation, which appears in the March issue of the journal, doesn't merely add more detail about the structure of Earth. It also explains why you can replace one overly simple assumption with another equally crude one and still get a much more accurate answer. The gravity tunnel problem is a staple of introductory physics courses because it simultaneously demonstrates both striking features of Isaac Newton's law of gravity and a common but very important type of cyclical motion. To solve it, students must calculate how the force of gravity on an object changes as the thing falls through the tunnel. In that case, the strength of the gravitational force pulling you toward Earth's center varies in proportion to the distance from the center. For decades, physics students have been asked to calculate that time and have been taught that the correct answer is 42 minutes. Now, a more realistic analysis has lopped 4 minutes off that estimate. The gravity tunnel problem is a staple of introductory physics courses because it simultaneously demonstrates both striking features of Isaac Newton's law of gravity and a common but very important type of cyclical motion.
